Review title: Vengeful Spirit With A Life Of Its Own
Review_body: The Grudge, a remake of a Japanese film of the same name, finds Sarah Michelle Gellar as an exchange student in the Land of Rising Sun who accepts a babysitting gig. Little does she realize that puts her in a whole heap of trouble.It seems as though there was a murder in that house of a woman and baby a few years earlier and the spirit is restless. Anytime anyone goes near the place and that includes the Japanese police something dreadful happens to them. The vengeful spirit kills indiscriminately and it has taken on a life of its own and is called, The Grudge. Gellar sure could have used the martial arts skills from Buffy The Vampire Slayer though I'm not sure how much they would have helped against the undead.The Japanese version apparently has gotten considerable acclaim, but for me this is just another slasher flick.

Review title: Best of the Asian horror remakes
Review_body: After the success of the American remake of THE RING, I guess it was inevitable that Hollywood would start producing more versions of Asian horrors. This is their second effort, a virtual scene-for-scene remake of the previous year's JU-on: THE GRUDGE, itself a remake of an earlier film simply titled JU-ON. Confused yet? You will be – as far as I make it, no less than six films have been built around this premise so far, with a seventh (and possibly eighth, knowing Hollywood) on the way. Really, if you've seen the original Japanese version, you have absolutely no reason to see this movie. It's inferior in every respect, and the decision to use sub-par CGI effects in some scenes makes them laughable rather than frightening – the appearance of the ghost hovering above the bed just looks atrocious.The good news is that Sam Raimi produces under his Ghost House banner, which means things are a little less insipid than they would be otherwise. This film is an old-fashioned horror effort that mixes the plots of JU-ON and JU-ON: THE GRUDGE to a sometimes confusing effect. I liked the fact that the focus was on the scares throughout – no padding or time-wasting here, just straight into the fear factor. The inclusion of scenes from JU-ON (which I hadn't seen) kept me on my toes, although everything else was pretty much reproduced from the original, shot-to-shot. This may be because the Japanese director came across, but even so I'd have liked a little more loosening of the apron strings, a little greater variety. Maybe that's just me.The cast isn't great. Japanese actors have a great way of portraying realistic subtlety, so when you see Sarah Michelle Gellar sweating and acting with wide-eyed fear, it doesn't really have the same impact. She's always just acting. The other cast members are pretty bland, and Clea DuVall is STILL awful, ever since I saw her in THE FACULTY. Bill Pullman was pretty good though, while the inclusion of Japanese actors from the original, playing the cursed family, is a nice touch. Being a Sam Raimi production, Ted Raimi inevitably shows up, here playing the head of a care agency, and it's great to see him in a larger supporting role than usual. One thing I did like a LOT was that the film becomes more serious, and more scary, as it progresses. Scenes such as the 'jaw' scare are spot on, while the full-blooded climax doesn't disappoint – it may be that the film actually becomes scarier than the original at this point! So, all in all, this isn't a great film, but it is a pretty good one – better still if you haven't caught the Japanese version.

When someone dies in the grip of a powerful rage... A curse is born. The curse gathers in that place of death. Those who encounter it will be consumed by its fury.Peter Kirk (Bill Pullman) kills himself jumping off his apartment balcony in Japan.Yoko visits elderly Emma (Grace Zabriskie) living in a Tokyo house. She is attacked by a spirit. Karen Davis (Sarah Michelle Gellar) is a student nurse living in Tokyo with her boyfriend Doug (Jason Behr). Karen takes over Yoko's job with Emma after she disappeared. Karen finds little boy Toshio trapped in a taped up closet.The movie flashes back to when Emma is first shown the house with her kids Susan (KaDee Strickland) and Matthew (William Mapother) and his wife Jennifer (Clea DuVall).The only interesting thing in this movie is Japan. Sadly, it doesn't even take full advantage of that since most of this takes place inside the house. The spirits aren't that creepy and not scary at all. The kills aren't gruesome. It's just very tame. There really isn't anything to this movie. There is also a problem with all these tangentially connected characters. They have no emotional relationship with SMG's Karen. The disconnected nature really lowers the stakes of this movie. The spirit chasing KaDee Strickland in Japan is the most compelling sequence but again she has no real connection with Karen.

In Tokyo, when the American student Karen Davis (Sarah Michelle Gellar) is called by a Japanese social support agency to replace her Japanese colleague Yoko (Yoko Maki) in the assistance of the American sick woman Emma (Grace Zabriskie), she realizes that something supernatural lives in the huge house. Inspector Nakagawa (Ryo Ishibashi) investigates a series of deaths of visitors of the subjected house, and based on a Japanese belief, he convinces himself that the place is cursed."The Grudge" is a different movie of haunted house. I have not had the chance to see the original "Ju-on: The Grudge" yet, but this story is much related to Japanese culture. The beginning of the film makes reference to a Japanese saying about rage, which is unknown in Western cultures. The non-linear screenplay works reasonably, but could be better and better. It gives me the impression that something is missing to be a great movie. My vote is six.Title (Brazil): "O Grito" ("The Scream")

The same director is working on the remake, as did on the original Japanese movie. The main reason for the truthfulness of the original, are the producers on hand here. Sam Raimi and Rob Tapert as the main ones! They wanted to let the director decide what he was going to do, where he was going to go with the movie. And he went/stayed in Japan for the story/plot. Which is a brave move, because it could've easily flopped in the USA. People could be alienated and feel detached, because it's not their (western) world, they do know. People might also be confused by the time structure (jumping forward and backwards in time like in the original). If you can get over that, you will be scared! :o)

Review title: Bland Film... Not Sure Why So Much Money Was Earned
Review_body: A social worker (Sarah Michelle Gellar) goes to work in a house that has a horrible power inside it. The "grudge" lingers there and tries to kill all who come into its path.I didn't want to see this film when it came out, and I only watched it now almost three years later because it seemed like an obligation. I think it was as bad as I expected, maybe even worse. The best actor in the film (Bill Pullman) was given such a weak part that he couldn't have saved it if he tried.The actor who impressed me most was Ryo Ishibashi, who played the police chief. He has been showing up in more American versions of Japanese films lately, and I can understand why. He "gets it" and can play to either audience with equal fervor.Sarah Michelle Gellar would seemingly be a great one for horror (all those years of Buffy, and a handful of other horror films) but she never really seems to get out of the "teen movie" groove and into a more terrifying frame of mind. Ted Raimi, on the other hand, is better here than ever before. His work in "Skinner" and "The Damned Thing" was disappointing. But he was better here than he's been since "Intruder". And Clea Duvall is always a nice touch. William Mapother (best known as Tom Cruise's cousin) showed up, but he has never been good, not even on "Lost".I wasn't scared by the "comb noise" (the thing that comes out of the ghosts' mouths), but I freely admit I put my head under my blanket during the security camera scene. Ever since "The Ring" (which this obviously rips off) I have been afraid of sinister little girls who meander towards a camera at a jagged pace. Well, that and the fact little girls in general are very scary (and more so when they grow up).I was unclear why some of the victims were attacked (especially the sister/daughter working in the office). Her connection to the house was pretty minor. But maybe I missed something, and I'm not going back to catch it again.If thee was any reason to watch this, it would be for Ted Raimi or to get it out of your system or for the beautiful music of Christopher Young. I don't think many people pay attention to the score of a film, bu they ought to. Young is the genius behind the "Hellraiser" music (a good soundtrack, you should buy it). And he hasn't lost his edge in the past two decades. No one does horror like Young. Unfortunately, even the best music does not make a film good... and this one just plain stinks.

It is strange that the director of the Japanese original, Takashi Shimizu, would remake his own film into English (well, American), this obviously came two years after The Ring remake, but this has Sam Raimi (The Evil Dead, Spider-Man) producing. Basically Karen Davis (Sarah Michelle Gellar) is the American nurse who has moved to Tokyo, Japan, and is caring for the elderly and immobile Emma Williams (Grace Zabriskie) in her home. Of course this home has had some strange things going on over the years, and when Karen is caught up in this deadly curse, i.e. The Grudge, through flashbacks we see the other victims who suffered the consequences. Obviously we see Emma's family, her son Matthew (Lost's William Mapother) and his wife Jennifer (Zodiac's Clea DuVall), and then we see Peter Kirk (Bill Pullman) and his wife Maria (Rosa Blasi), all are eventually pulled into the horror where they are haunted or killed by the mysterious long haired girl or see the little Japanese boy. Karen is somehow taken back in time to see Peter's encounters with The Grudge, and in photos we see that the Japanese girl with the long hair has been stalking for some time, and obviously the film ends in the dark way. Also starring Jason Behr as Doug, KaDee Strickland as Susan Williams and Ted Raimi (Sam's brother) as Alex. The story is rather complicated, and not even the smallest scary moments that do grab your attention, such as a shadow becoming a live figure in a corridor, and hands appearing in Gellar's hair, can save this film from having a dreary story, and not all making much sense, a pretty terrible horror thriller. Adequate!

I haven't yet seen the Japanese original but as this version was the one on TV I decided to give it a go. I'm pleased that I did as it was better than I expected of a remake, I suspect it was helped by the fact that it was remade by the original director.While it isn't the best of stories it is certainly creepy, several scenes gave me goosebumps which is the main thing needed in a horror film.The basic plot is that there is a house in Tokyo that has been haunted since a mother and child where murdered by the man of the family and anybody who visits the house is doomed to die fairly soon afterwards. The ghosts are certainly creepy but unfortunately we didn't have enough time to get to care about the main character, a nurse played by Sarah Michelle Gellar, which made me less concerned about her plight.I was pleased to see that it didn't fall into modern horror cliché of adding excess gore and gratuitous nudity.

Review title: A vengeful specter kills everybody go into a haunted house
Review_body: In Japan when a nurse is assigned to visit a family she's chased by a vengeful and supernatural spirit that possesses its victims. Meanwile a man (Bill Pullman) commits suicide dropping himself from a high apartment. Karen Davis (Sara Michelle Gellar) a volunteer social agrees to cover another assistant. He goes to the ghastly house and find an elderly woman (Grace Zabrinski.) Then happen several flashbacks about the family (Clea Duvall, her husband and his sister KaDee Strickland). A series of terrible and mysterious deaths occur. A Police Inspector (Ryo Ishibashi) attempts to get to the bottom of the mystery. But Karen is also racing to saves her boyfriend (Jason Behr) and must now find to break the horrifying spell.This frightening movie displays terror, shocks, hard-edged drama and creepy images. While the look is suitable atmospheric and eerie, the argument stretches plausibility to the breaking point. This is an acceptable adaptation of the novel and movie that took successfully Japan. Nice cinematography by Yamamoto, Takashi Miike usual cameraman. Well produced in Japan by Robert G. Tapert and Sam Raimi and of course with intervention his brother Ted Raimi, as always. The motion picture is professionally directed by Takashi Shimzu in similar style to Hideo Nakata movies -The ring, Dark Water-. Shimzu is an expert on horror cinema with creepy phantoms of pale complexion and long hair . After that, he made ¨Reincarnation¨ also called ¨Rinne¨ again with palish phantoms and ¨Marebito¨ about a vampire in the Tokyo underground. It's followed by Grudge II again with Sara Michelle Gellar and Amber Tamblyn and similar equipment technical and artistic ; furthermore in production the third part. Rating : Acceptable and passable.

This is director Takashi Shimizu's fourth attempt at telling the Ju-on legend, only this time he's targeting a Western audience, and is armed with a bigger budget (courtesy of Sam Raimi) and a US star in the appealing form of Sarah Michelle Gellar. It doesn't make a great deal of difference...Rather than take this opportunity to iron out the creases evident in his 2002 film (and boy, was that sucker creased!), Shimizu regurgitates almost precisely the same mess, albeit with more polished and slightly bloodier effects and a louder soundtrack to help deliver those all important jump scares.Being in English and designed for mass consumption by the multiplex crowd, a little effort has clearly been made to try and make the plot easier to comprehend, but in the end, it is still pretty confusing and not in the slightest bit scary (unless, as I mentioned in my earlier review for Ju-on, you have a irrational fear of small boys in body paint or crap yourself at either the sound of a phone ringing or someone with a very croaky throat).

Review title: Same old story, this time set in Tokyo...
Review_body: A group of witless (or, perhaps, incredibly naïve) Americans, all linked by the same haunted house, are terrorized by evil Japanese spirits. Takashi Shimizu directed this remake of his "Ju-on", yet this thriller has a distinct case of "Ring"-itis (with a dash of "Poltergeist III"). Staccato clips of mutilated faces--and a much-publicized bit with Sarah Michelle Gellar taking a shower with a demonic hand in her hair--was enough to put the film over at the box-office, but it is a positively grueling experience, repetitive and pedestrian. Few genuine scares, a disappointing production design, and surprisingly bad performances manage to sink "The Grudge" like a stone, yet enough people cared about it to warrant a 2006 sequel. * from ****

Review title: makes little sense (and not in an interesting way), and laughable "scares"
Review_body: Takashi Shimizu had a great opportunity with a remake of his original film Ju-On The Grudge. While I haven't seen that film, I would have to wager that there's more imagination and originality (or some rip-off originality, in other words skill with known tropes of the Japanese ghost movie) than in his own directed remake. Maybe the script was written to somehow have some kind of warped appeal, or I would guess accessibility, for an American audience. What starts off with some potential - the hint of something very screwed up going on with Bill Pullman's sudden movement - just goes into a total jumble. And as a horror movie? Gimme a break.Tension could have been built on the situation - a nurse going to take care of a disturbed woman in a house that is haunted - but he undercuts everything he wants to get his audience to feel. Scares? How's about some music timed just so you know when exactly to expect something. A black cat? Yeah, why not just make the ghost-boy thing sound like a cat for creepiness which, in effect, is only creepy if you want cats. Plot? Why not just shuffle between past and present without any semblance of an actual flow of how a story could be told (meaning, while the flashbacks are inserted and are meant to be organic with the story overall, they aren't), or for that matter have us care about ANYONE in the cast.By the time the characters, or those that are there for exposition, get around to telling us what is going on or whatever, there's little point to care. The film-making is shoddy (i.e. the 180 degree rule is broken many times over and not in a forgivable or intriguing way), and the performances are wooden even when looking frightened or shocked (Gellar especially is disappointing, but Pullman, who shows up later after his first scene, is sorely miscast). Even when Shimizu tries for some average old "Boo" scares, like when the woman is in the office building and chased by the Grudge ghost, it's still silly. Just watch when she's going on that elevator and the ghost is in the background of shots. Either you'll go with it, and if so more power to you, or you'll laugh hysterically at the results. Count me in the latter.I'm not totally sure where this project went wrong - was it Shimizu having to retool it for the studios, or him not giving enough leeway with his revamp of his vision? Or maybe Raimi had some say in it and made things more confusing and/or dull than they would be with someone else. The Grudge gives us a lot of information that doesn't make sense or at the least give us some horror-fodder to chew on. It's cineplex trash of a sad order.

"Sarah Michelle Gellar (TV's 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer') stars as an American nurse who has come to work in Tokyo. Following a series of horrifying and mysterious deaths, she encounters the vengeful supernatural spirit that possesses it's victims, claims their souls, then passes it's curse to another person in a spreading chain of horror. Now, she must find a way to break this supernatural spell or become the next victim of an ancient evil that never dies, but forever lives to kill," according to the DVD sleeve's synopsis.Hopefully, some of the other comments will help you understand what this film is about, because I'll be damned if I know. The Tokyo setting and Japanese villains - especially little Yuya Ozeki (as Toshio Saeki) - are interesting, but underwritten. The storyline jumps around in time for the sake of simply jumping around in time. The ending is particularly inexplicable. "The Grudge" is an English language re-make of Japanese director Takashi Shimizu's original "Ju-on" (2002), which you can safely bet is better.*** The Grudge (10/22/04) Sam Raimi : Takashi Shimizu ~ Sarah Michelle Gellar, Jason Behr, KaDee Strickland, Bill Pullman

This is a cultural twist on the too familiar haunted house story...but with an abundance of attitude. You will jump; you will think your heart has stopped; and your goosebumps will have goosebumps. Based on the Japanese powerhouse JU-ON:THE GRUDGE(1963), in a modest house in Tokyo resides hidden terror. It is possessed by a plague on the lives of those who enters it. "The Grudge" causes victims to die in a powerful rage and like a virus becomes a chain of horror as it moves from one victim to the next.An American exchange student(Sarah Michelle Gellar)studying social work in Japan agrees to care for an elderly woman(Grace Zabriskie)victimized by more than her catatonic being. The house should otherwise be deserted when the young woman begins to hear the sound of scratching and upon investigating she is starkly introduced to supernatural horror. The story might lose something in translation; but what makes this movie so creepy and heart pounding is the superior collaboration of lighting, sound and camera editing. The atmosphere is confusing and profound. The only way to prepare for this suspenseful horror roller coaster is Prozac and a change of underwear.Also in the cast are: Jason Behr, William Mapother, Clea DuVall and Bill Pullman. Kudos to director Takashi Shimizu.

Review title: Above average American remake of a foreign film.
Review_body: This is due in no small part to the fact that the director of the original Japanese film, "Ju-On: The Gruge", Takashi Shimizu, is also at the reins of this effective shocker, which succeeds at melding a constant melancholy atmosphere with the traditional jump scares of the genre. It holds no surprises for anybody who has seen "Ju-On", but is still a good example of storytelling, as it moves from various points in time, telling of the assorted doomed individuals who come into contact with a Japanese house that had tragedy in its past. In 2004, an American exchange student named Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar) does some investigating of her own, determined to find the cause of the horrific visions she's experiencing. Shimizu brings a great sense of style to this film, and, working from a screenplay by Stephen Susco (adapting Shimizu's original screenplay), does a nice job of capturing the experience of foreigners living and working in Japan. Even in its "unrated", extended form it's never as gory or exploitative as some viewers may expect, preferring to go for mood and atmosphere at all times. The director is also highly adept at building the mystery, as he reveals plot details a bit at a time and follows his characters on their doom laden paths. Moreover, we can like these characters and maintain genuine interest in seeing what happens to them. Special effects are generally well done, and one extremely effective touch is in seeing a supernatural occurrence actually show up on a surveillance tape. The integrated cast does very well under Shimizu's direction. The actors who played the ill fated family in his Japanese film - Yuya Ozeki, Takako Fuji, and Takashi Matsuyama - reprise their roles here, and Ryo Ishibashi of "Audition" fame plays the investigating detective. American cast members include Jason Behr, William Mapother, Clea DuVall, KaDee Strickland, Grace Zabriskie, Bill Pullman, Rosa Blasi, and Ted Raimi, whose brother Sam's company Ghost House produced the film. This has to rank as one of their finer efforts, a remake that is entirely respectful of its source and is just as legitimately creepy. Highly recommended. Eight out of 10.

Review title: Japanese flavored horror has a timeline problem...
Review_body: THE GRUDGE never quite gets over its disorganized script problems.There's a glaring timeline factor that keeps the picture on the edge of a horror puzzle in which all the pieces don't really come together in a sensible enough way. Still, there are gripping scenes where you know something is about to happen, since there's an air of dread that hangs like a funeral wreath over the whole story.SARAH MICHELLE GELLAR has to handle most of the acting chores, succeeding in looking horrified and frightened the moment she enters the forbidden house where menacing spirits seem to be hiding in every shadow. BILL PULLMAN has an interesting opening moment but then disappears through most of the tale after his quick opening scene. We don't get to see him again until the film is almost over because the whole timeline of the story is so scrambled.Based on a Japanese horror film, it does a neat job of keeping the suspenseful elements as a hook that grabs the viewer, but some in the audience may become a bit impatient with the pace of the film which seems to have a sleepwalking slowness about it.Interesting, creepy, sometimes gory, but only a middling success. Well photographed and technically quite efficient.

This Movie was a Mega-Hit. Going for it was a ticket friendly PG-13 Rating and that forever Adolescent wanting to be scared at the Movies. It seems that all you need is an eerie visual or two that is slightly unsettling and creepy, an unworldly sound effect or two, jumble the Films chronology (for that most Modern of Style) and Millions of Bucks can be yours.This is an overrated Movie that has spawned sequels and imitators. It is in fact and imitator itself. it is not only an imitator it is a remake, by the same Director. it has just been Americanized. But all that is not the problem. This is just not very cleverly conceived. It is a variety of setups to announce scares and a string of similar looking shots not so strategically placed, to build tension.In the end, it is of course, open ended, almost a prerequisite for Horror Movies, and is so Story shallow and anemic that it is quite disconcerting that a few jumps and a creepy makeup style is what makes a successful franchise. Can Mediocrity really be this rewarding. Financially yes. Artistically no.

Review title: Decent remake of a Japanese ghost story.
Review_body: The Grudge is set in Tokyo in Japan where American foreign exchange student Karen Davis (Sarah Michelle Gellar) works as a volunteer carer, her boss Alex (Ted Raimi) gives her a job to look after an old woman in a house after her usual carer Yoko (Yoko Maki) disappears. Once there Karen finds a mysterious young Japanese boy taped into a cupboard. Later on Alex visits the house & finds the old woman dead & Karen in a state of shock & fear, the police are called & they discover the bodies of the previous American owners in the attic as the house seems to throw up more & more sinister findings. Then Yoko turns up minus her jaw. Karen decides to investigates the past of the house & makes some shocking discoveries...This Japanese, American & German co-production was directed by Takashi Shimizu & is one of a recent spate of classic Asian horror films being remade by Hollywood like the impressive The Ring (2002), the awful Dark Water (2005) & The Eye (2008), I would say that The Grudge comes somewhere between the two as while it's not as good as the remake of The Ring it's nowhere near as bad as Dark Water. Annoyingly like a lot of recent horror films The Grudge is available in both a 'PG-13' theatrical cut & an 'Unrated' version (just to weed more money out of the fans as usual) which changes & adds a lot of things, I will be basing my comments on the standard theatrical cut. The script by Stephen Susco was based on the film Ju-On: The Grudge (2003) which was actually written & directed by Shimizu, it must have been weird for him remaking his own film within a year from a script written by someone else based on his original. Anyway, this remake sticks pretty closely to the original in many ways keeping most if not all of the main character's (although it changes the nationality of some to American), most of the significant events from the Japanese original take place & to be honest there's not a lot of difference between them. The film can be quite confusing at times as it has quite a loose narrative structure, it introduces people & then quickly dumps them, it goes between different sets of character's very suddenly which is quite jarring at times but it does all come together pretty well at the end. The actual ending revelation is a little routine, I was maybe expecting something a bit more dramatic but it works & that's the main thing.Director Shimizu does a great job, The Grudge is one of the few big Hollywood remakes which you can say has a really creepy & eerie atmosphere. There are some terrific jump moments, sure they are older than dirt with the likes of cats suddenly jumping into frame or a telephone ringing at a tense moment but they sure do work & are fun. There is also some pretty creepy imagery of ghost's, I could certainly see anyone who gets scared easily having nightmares after seeing The Grudge. The version I saw didn't have any gore apart from a ripped-off jaw & the owner of said jaw turning up. It's very well made with some nice long sustained scenes of horror, The Grudge is a film which goes for scares & atmosphere rather than CGI which is nice. The sound effect that accompanies the ghost is also quite unsettling & creepy in a odd sort of way.With a supposed budget of about $10,000,000 The Gudge wasn't a mega-budget film & it's near forty million dollar opening weekend actually surprised studio executives who quickly agreed to make a sequel. Actually shot in Japan. The acting is fine, Sarah Michelle Gellar is nice on the eyes, the Saeki family are all played by the same actors who played the roles in the Japanese original.The Grudge is a good solid pretty creepy horror film remake, I liked it although I doubt I would want to watch it again anytime soon. Followed by The Grudge 2 (2006) & The Grudge 3 (2009).

Review title: If you've seen the Japanese originals, you've already seen this film.
Review_body: This review is really a word of warning, if you've seen any of the earlier Japanese versions of this story you've seen this movie before. If you've seen all four of the earlier films, you've really seen everything (except the frightening opening with Bill Pullman) and you'd best wait for home video.I understand that the film makers wanted to make sure that this film worked and made them money, so they repeated what worked, even casting the same Japanese actors for the kid and other roles; but it would have been nice if they had done more that was new beyond the opening sequence.This isn't to say that the film is bad, its not, rather, its just that unless you're walking in to the film fresh odds are you're going to be like me and know what each five or ten minutes is going to bring because of the set up of the sequence.For me it was a 6 out of 10, for fresh eyes probably higher.

Scary Japanese horror movies were making a killing at the box office after Universal Pictures released "The Ring," their terrifying 2002 remake of the 1998 Nipponese chiller "Ringu." Surprisingly, "The Ring" scared up so much money for Universal that the studio green-lighted a sequel. Not surprisingly, Columbia Pictures hopped onto the bandwagon, too, with their remake of "Ju-On: The Grudge" (2002), another legendary Asian supernatural saga in the "Ringu" tradition. As the second major Americanized rehash of a Japanese nail-biter, "The Grudge" toppled "Shark Tale" from the top box office slot with a shocking $40-million weekend haul.Despite its profitable numbers, "The Grudge" evokes few of the thrills and chills that made "The Ring" so riveting. As far as "The Grudge" goes, you might say that the spirit of this handsomely produced haunted house hokum must have been lost somewhere in translation. While "The Grudge" developed several spooky shutters, the hopelessly incoherent screenplay and the dire shortage of white-knuckled hysterics seriously undercuts its impact. Gorehounds will snooze, and only audiences that have never seen a horror movie may shriek. Although he didn't pen the lukewarm, R-rated, U.S. adaptation, Takashi Shimizu convinced Columbia to let him remake his own fright-mare with American leads on location in the land of the Rising Sun. Nevertheless, not even the same Japanese writer & director who called the shots on the three original "Ju-On: The Grudge" movies can conjure up more than just goose bumps with this atmospheric but anemic American version. Altogether, the result prove far less alarming because "The Grudge" delivers a less than satisfactory ending and the computer-generated, special effects look ridiculous.Sarah Michelle Gellar of TV's "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" plays a dull American exchange student in Tokyo. Our heroine fills in fro a social worker at a health-care agency when the latter disappears without explanation. As Karen Davis, Gellar finds herself assigned to care for an elderly catatonic patient, Emma (Grace Zabriskie of "Gone in Sixty Seconds"), who has been abandoned apparently by the Japanese caregiver entrusted with her welfare. Initially, Karen freaks out when she enters Emma's house and finds it trashed. Along the way, Karen hears ominous noises, too. Meanwhile, Emma's son Matthew (William Mapother of "Suspect Zero") and her daughter-in-law Jennifer (Clea DuVall of "Identity") vanish mysteriously not long after they rent the house for her. Eventually, not only does a swirling, airborne poltergeists with a cadaverous face materialize out of thin air while Karen is tending to Emma, but also Karen notices a tight-lipped little Japanese boy prowling the premises with a black cat.Eventually, Karen learns that a murderous Tokyo dad killed his wife Kayako (Takako Fuji) and son Toshio (Yuya Ozeki), and then committed suicide. The domicile where this diabolical crime occurred somehow committed to memory the fury and the malevolence of the murder so that the undead spirits of Kayako and Toshio haunt it. Now, they hold a deadly "grudge" against anybody who ventures into those quarters! Later, Japanese authorities discover the missing corpses of Emma's son and his wife drained of all their blood and hidden in the attic. When Karen launches her own investigation into these evil spirits, she encounters another expatriate American, Dr. Bill Kirk (Bill Pullman of "Independence Day"), who has been conducted his own probe. The only problem is that the Pullman character committed suicide at the outset of this epic, long before the Gellar character confronted the eerie happenings in this creepy but cobweb-free haunted house.Freshman scribe Stephen Susco's murky screenplay shuns the standard narrative flow of start to finish. Instead, this yawner unfolds as a series of flashbacks as it weaves itself chaotically around an array of characters, some dead and other alive, who cross paths but cannot communicate with each other. Shimizu doesn't let the normally charismatic Gellar strut her stuff, so she comes off looking and acting flat by comparison with some of her other film roles. Mind you, Shimizu knows how to set up scary scenes, but the pay-offs to his subtle but spooky shenanigans are less than harrowing. Half of the audience that I sat with Sunday afternoon where I saw this pathetic paranormal potboiler stomped out of the theater griping about how much "The Grudge" sucked.An ambiguous finale, passive performances, sketchy characters and a confusing storyline undermine whatever terror that the American account of this celebrated Japanese movie struggled to deliver. Don't budge for "The Grudge!"

Review title: Story and 'scare' overdose kill this professionally made, good looking horror movie.
Review_body: This movie is very good looking. The 'ghosts' are extremely creepy looking and the sound effects are horrifying. Everything a good horror movie needs you might say. Well, not exactly, unfortunately the movie also suffers from some bad storytelling and a 'scare' overdose that take away a lot of the movie its tension and scary moments. It makes "The Grudge" a good looking but lacking horror movie, that perhaps still has more goods as bads but still remains a bit of a disappointing movie with lots of missed opportunities.Problem is that they basically tried to put a scary moment in literally almost every scene. I don't know why but after a while some of the scene's loose their power to scare you. Maybe its because you get used to the atmosphere and the scare moments of the movie, or something like that. Instead of making the movie scary it made the movie predictable and too much of the same the whole time.The movie its story is told in a completely illogically way. the time-line is very messy, it jumps from the present to what happened a few hours or days or years before to some totally different characters. It's not that it becomes difficult to follow but it's just that it feels pointless and unneeded that the story is told in that particular way. It also distracts from the main story line and the main character played by the boring and untalented acting Sarah Michelle Gellar. As a matter of fact, the story is told in such a way that the main character is perhaps only on screen for 50% of its running time, at the most.Big plus of me was Ted Raimi in a typical Ted Raimi role. His more famous brother Sam was one of the producers of the movie. Too bad Sam Raimi didn't directed this, I'm sure he would had made something more of this movie.It's all too bad, cause "The Grudge" is a well made movie that had lots of potential to become just as good as the other Japenese horror movie remake "The Ring". The movie however heavily suffers from the makers ambition to make this the ultimate scary movie. You might say that this movie died of a scare overdose.Still of course the movie still remain perfectly watchable thanks to the visual look of it and some nice sequences.6/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

Coming back from the cinema after seeing this film, I'm not quite sure what to make of it. I guess it was on the way back, through the dark, empty streets, that I realized something was missing. Something important, maybe even crucial, something that needs to be there after just seeing a horror film on the silver screen. I wasn't scared. I wasn't looking over my shoulder, I wasn't listening for any strange sounds, I wasn't even looking twice on any person I walked past on the way. I'm a sucker for scary movies, I'll tell you that right away; but this didn't scare me. It startled me, made me jump in my seat, but that's it. That's what the 'horror' portion of the film is, a long series of jumps. There's nothing wrong with that... but that's just all it is. No real gore, no atmosphere, no psychological terror... just jumps. I'm not saying that any of the aforementioned qualities would make a better horror movie... but they probably would make it more 'full'. The truth is, sadly, there's nothing in this movie that will really stay in your mind for very long after you leave the cinema... if there's still anything after the end credits. Luckily, the director rarely resorts to the cheap jump scares... few of the shocks come from a cat jumping down from a shelf or a friend appearing behind the main character, reaching out and grabbing their shoulder. Most of the time, when you jump, it's because someone just died or something genuinely disturbing just happened. The worst thing about the jump scares is probably that you can only watch and still... well... jump, because after that, you'll know where and when the jumps will occur. What makes this watchable apart from the undeniable effect of the jump scares is that, on some level, it manages to appear deeper than it is, without being condescending. There are plenty of little details, stuff that only the most watchful eye will notice. The way the story is told is masterful in a way... very little dialog is used to explain it. A series of situations and powerful acting tell us far more than Hollywood-like dialog(which the film has slim to none of) could. The plot isn't deep, and it isn't really the driving force in the film, but there's enough of it and it's mostly good. The acting ranges, but most of it's pretty good. The characters are well-written and interesting, but most of them just aren't developed enough for us to care about whether they live or die, which is a fatal mistake on the directors part, because it kills a lot of the suspense. The non-linear time-line is presented so casually that many viewers will probably be thrown off(I know I was), and not know when exactly something is happening. One final note before I pass verdict; personally I thought it was a mistake to cast Joxer of Xena: Warrior Princess(Ted Raimi) in a serious horror film, but at least his role isn't very big. Also, he *is* the executive producer's brother, and, well, that's pretty much Hollywood in a nutshell. All in all, the film is pretty much worth watching, but probably only once, and with reasonable expectations. I recommend it to fans of the Japanese horror films, keeping in mind that this is an Americanized version(but done by the same director). However, even though I haven't seen them myself, you should probably see the original Ju-on film(s). Also, personally I don't think this is as good an American remake of a Japanese horror film as The Ring. Go see that first, as well. 7/10

Once upon a time a Japanese man was very angry because he read his wife's journal and found that she'd fallen in love with someone else. So he murdered her and his 6 year old son and then committed suicide. Then, for no apparent reason, or else some hokey old legend made up solely for the purposes of this movie, the child and mother became angry ghosts (or "spirits" if you prefer, but I'm going with ghosts). Maybe the dad did too - I don't think so, but I'm not too clear on it, and the sequence of events sometimes gets a bit confusing in this movie.Were these ghosts interested in being helped to pass over to a more peaceful realm. Not bloody likely! They were far more concerned with generating mayhem to be visited on anyone who ventured into the house where they had been killed, including inducing people to jump off balconies, sucking the life out of people, and ripping the jaws off innocent home helps. What's more, this mayhem didn't just remain within the house - it followed the visitors around, and even travelled down phone lines (or something) to suck their relatives into mattresses (I can't believe I just said that).In fact, these ghosts were so malevolent and powerful that they even saw off Buffy the Vampire Slayer. They didn't kill her, although the final shock shot left you thinking......that they all died unhappily ever after.Definitely creepy, and a lot of shock moments, but few surprises and little sense.

Review title: Doesn't translate well to an American audience
Review_body: The main theme of this movie is that a powerful negative force inhabits a place after someone has died a violent death, and that this negative force consumes all who touch the place in which the violent act occurred. This idea is not new, and many conjecture that what people believe are "ghosts" are in fact leftover energy from just such traumatic events. However, most American audiences want the "wronged parties" or "ghosts" to produce a moral outcome- either the punishment of the murderer(s) or the revelation of how the victims died. What most Americans don't really "get" or appreciate is this malevolent force striking out at random victims- the current occupants of the house, whoever they may be, however transient. This just spawns more innocent victims and seems pointless.On the positive side, the technical elements of the film were excellent, the parts of the film that were supposed to be scary were indeed scary, and the roles were well acted. In fact, for you Buffy fans out there, did you notice that Sarah Michele Gellar was reunited with two BTVS alumni? Jason Behr, who played her love interest, was Billy Ford in "Lie to Me" in season two, and the American wife who was caring for her mother-in-law before she was murdered by the "ghosts" was played by the same actress who played Marcie Ross in "Out of Mind Out of Sight" from season one.

Review title: As it is said, so shall it be.
Review_body: The Grudge, my god what an awful film.Has no contextuality, no realism, just random nothingness. Noises, things appearing and disappearing, face staring and no death scenes, blah. Sarah... Why did you do this to me? Bit of a Buffy reunion, shame it's on trash.

Review title: My Grudge is to Get My Money Back.
Review_body: The Grudge (2004): Dir: Takashi Shimizu / Cast: Sarah Michelle Gellar, Jason Behr, Bill Pullman, Clea Duvall, KaDee Strickland: Misleading title in a graphic horror film where many nameless victims are mutilated to the delight of an audience that desires to see more of this tripe. It is shocking to hear an audience cheer during such crap. Sarah Michelle Gellar plays a caregiver who discovers that the mansion she is visiting is haunted. There is an elderly lady who sleeps and then shrieks at ghosts, and Gellar is not long identifying her problem. Starts out well with a suicide but becomes routine after the umpteenth person is killed. The ending is a complete cheat but what really stands out is the film's inability to make any sense. Why not create an interesting thriller about trauma? Instead director Takashi Shimizu Americanizes his Japanese film for no other reason than to allow Hollywood to rape his craft. Gellar holds her own as the caregiver overwhelmed by haunting images and decides to investigate the history behind it all. Other roles are not so lucky and fall into that camera stalk and kill cliché. Jason Behr, Bill Pullman and Clea Du Vall are completely wasted in roles that are subdued by visuals. The special effects are done with appeal but unfortunately the screenplay was not given the same regard. The only grudge held should come from Japan. Score: 2 ½ / 10

Working in Japan, an American health-care worker discovers the home of her latest charge is the site of a terrible, ghostly curse and tries to stop it before it consumers her friends and co-workers.There's a lot to really like with this one as it gets a lot of right throughout here. One of the biggest issues, though, is the fact that as a remake it really doesn't do anything to help the story told from the original so that can hold this one down somewhat. By keeping the familiar story and the jump scenes along the way, this can make for a trying time here by being too similar for its own good and not really having a whole lot really changed in terms of fixing the storyline or the different plot points within this. Still, this familiarity does manage to bring about many positives including a far better pace than the original. There's far more life to the non-attack scenes and the burgeoning mystery about the ghosts within the house keep this one moving so it doesn't feel as though it takes a long time to get going or even between scenes. When the attacks really start coming in earnest throughout here, this becomes all the more enjoyable by building off such a solid foundation with those intriguing non-attacks keeping the film going. Likewise, those attack are quite enjoyable on their own merits as incredibly entertaining and chilling encounters, most notably the numerous encounters inside the house from the first encounter with the ghost inside the bedroom, the encounter in the bathtub as well as the flashback to the previous owner and the utterly fun finale that has a lot going for it by mixing action with the chills so well. That the other attacks outside the house are rather well done is another plus, from the office building ambush to the hotel encounter and to the spectacular encounter at the office with the deformed ghost makes for a rather solid series of encounters here to make this quite fun. The only place this stumbles is the final half-hour by detailing an affair that really drags this to a halt instead of charging through into a furious finale, not to mention really lowering the impact of the curse by putting too much background into it. That does manage to lower this one somewhat, but it's still got enough here to really make a big impact.Rated PG-13: Violence and Language.

Karen Davis is residing in Japan with her boyfriend, who is studying there. Temporarily assigned to be a carer for a woman with severe sleeping disorder, Karen goes to the patient's house. What she finds is something she would never expect. The house is plagued by the presence of murderous ghosts, the result of a curse. The curse is born from someone dying in a powerful rage. Now, Karen finds herself being tormented by that curse, as it eventually starts claiming it's victims.....In the early noughties, the cinema was rife with remakes of 'J-Horror', and even though some of them were good, it was just an excuse for Hollywood to make money, because some people just couldn't be bothered with subtitles.The Ring, Dark Water, Shutter, and this are prime examples.But at least this was directed by the originals director, so at least some respect has been maintained. Geller is in it, she's okay, but the movie goes to show that she could never carry a film. She more or less put a stake in her movie career with her performance, like rice with no salt, its does the job, but it's very bland.So thank heavens then for the rest of the cast, and the brilliant camera-work used when we see the ghosts.The lift scene, and the photo montage are standouts, in what other wise are jump scenes.Its one of those movies that the more you watch it, the less the horror will scare you, and the story will intrigue you more.Worth seeing, but if you've seen the original, don't bother.

Review title: A bit like "Ring", but a tad more creepy...the story however could have used some work.
Review_body: For the most part I liked this movie...it was a film with many creepy images and quite a few killings as well. Still though the story just was not up to "The Ring's" story. In this movie there really is no motivation for the killings to occur they say things about rage and despair, but the only one who would have felt that really was not part of the supernatural side of the movie. Still though it was entertaining enough and I love the fact it was set in Japan. It also makes me want to see the Japanese version as I know it will be better as this one was probably Americanized quite a lot. I preferred "Ringu" to "Ring" also. All in all though I enjoyed it, though I wished they would just release the Japanese versions here. Also, there is one part of the movie where one woman is having a hard time finding here way around Japan and I found this a little hard to believe. Many Japanese are rather good at English if not fluent and many things there are written in both English and Japanese (I notice this when watching other movies from there).

Review title: A surprisingly good remake for a change!
Review_body: I've been less than impressed with the recent crop of Japanese horror films. Perhaps it's just because I don't like ghost stories much, but I think that for a bunch of films that are so highly acclaimed; they fall massively short of the mark, especially since they're so similar to one another. Another thing I've been less than impressed with is the way that America have been snapping up everything from Asia that they can get their hands on and remaking it. The Ring was remade with disastrous results, but nevertheless we find ourselves here with the latest remake; The Grudge. I haven't seen the original version of this film (and am in no rush to), but to my surprise this film is actually quite good. The Grudge stars Sarah Michele Geller (from that Buffy rubbish) and it follows her as she goes to work for a woman in Japan who needs caring for. The Grudge professes that whenever someone is killed in a fit of rage, a curse is broken and the spirit lay dormant for someone to enter that curse. Something that Buffy has just done...The Eastern setting helps to add mystery to the already mysterious plot. It is customary for American remakes to be moved to America, but the fact that this one didn't get relocated is much to it's credit. The film's effects are really good, and some parts where the ghosts are shown are genuinely quite creepy, due to the effects. However, the film goes a bit overboard with it's scares at times, and it goes for the money shot too often. For example; tension is mounting and then suddenly! ...the phone rings. It's such a waste, and although it does help to build the unease; the film would have been much better served if it kept the tension building, rather than diffusing it every five seconds with another nonchalant happening. The music in the film is very good, however, and it always serves in adding to the bewilderment that the film is keen to capitalise on. The Grudge relies a lot on it's sense of dread, and the music helps to capture that.The film isn't a complete whole, mostly for the reasons mentioned. However; as remakes of Japanese films go, this is a very good example and I recommend this one over most other films in it's class.

Possible spoilers. "The Grudge" is about the grudge that happens whenever a person enters the house where an evil event happened. I believe, it is a theory where the negative energy remains. Misery loves company, like some of the people I work with at the post office. (I know that's off topic) The director knows how to create tension. This film is one long slow burn. Anticipation of the event maybe worse than the event itself. The grudge lives for fear, and fear it creates. The Japanese director adds a new feel for the film. A ghoulish and mysterious feel. Fresh film, and strong story line that unravels in the right order. Made for the younger crowd, but a true horror film fan will love it. Worth seeing in the theater. I give it a 7 out of 10.

Review title: Slightly disappointing,but still watchable horror film.
Review_body: Sarah Michelle Gellar plays Karen,an exchange student studying social work in Japan who innocently agrees to cover for a nurse who didn't show up for a work.When she enters the assigned home,she discovers an elderly American woman,Emma,who is lost in a catatonic state while the rest of the house appears deserted and disheveled.Suddenly Karen hears scratching sounds from upstairs.Soon she learns the secret of the vengeful curse that has taken root in this house.I was able to see "Ju-On",before I saw "The Grudge" and I can safely say that this American remake is nowhere nearly as horrifying as the original.Sadly it relies more on shock tactics,such as having ghosts jump out at unexpected moments.However "The Grudge" still has its share of few effective scares and thrills.Overall,if you like Japanese horror movies like "Ju-On" or "Ringu" you can give this one a look.7 out of 10.

Greatly enjoyed the great photography in Japan and the entire story about a young gal who is an exchange student; who is given an assignment to take care of an older woman in a rather strange home that has some very deep dark secrets where murder and horror occurred within its walls. A curse has been placed on anyone who enters this haunted house and takes on the theme that when someone is murdered and killed there soul remains in the home and passes on to the next person it can enter and takes complete control of any human body. This film seemed like it just went on and on and repeated itself will many flashbacks and I quickly became very bored and I could hardly wait until the film ended, which was HORRIBLE.

Review title: I don't know which is worse, getting a root canal or watching this film!
Review_body: Sarah Michelle Gellar! What has happened to you?! Did you loose your acting ability when you left "Buffy"? *SOB!!!* I'm so sick of these stupid un-scary Japanese flicks. The trailer looked so cool. I was excited to see this film, but now I wish I just saved my money for another movie. The characters have no development in the film, and the "scary" moments are not exciting. 92% of the film is silent. I thought I would go crazy from this film. I would never recommend this movie in a million years. I am saddened by Sarah! You have brought shame to my life! OK, I'm a dork.1/10

my friend and i watched the grudge on DVD,and neither one of us was impressed.it was basically a one note movie,involving a grey looking ghost/child who crawls all around on all fours and scares,even terrified its victims by opening its mouth end emitting what can only be described as a low pitched scream.some of the victims become so traumatized, they end up nearly catatonic and cannot speak of what they've seen,or heard.i mean really,this whole premise is hard to believe,because once the ghost shows itself,it is not remotely scary,forget about terrifying.the acting was not convincing in the least.i did however like the dark atmosphere of the film, which gave it a sense of foreboding...for all of five minutes,after which the novelty wears off.there are two things which are absolutely terrifying about the whole thing.the first is that i will never get back the minutes of my life spent watching this movie.the second is that someone thought it merited a sequel.as for the grudge itself---beige i.e bland and dull.pointless 1.5* for the 5 minutes of atmosphere

Review title: The most scariest ghost/horror movie I have seen.
Review_body: "The Grudge" is quite possibly the most scariest ghost/horror movie I have ever seen. Sarah Michelle Gellar takes on the main role as nurse Karen living and working in Tokyo. While working she is exposed to a supernatural curse involving a vengeful spirit which locks a person in a powerful rage before claiming his/her life and spreading its curse to another person.This movie starts out with Karen moving to Tokyo with boyfriend Doug (Jason Behr), where we get a taste of drama as they adjust to their new lives in Japan. The suspense builds when they encounter mysterious events in the house Karen is a caretaker in and, what follows, are one creepy moment one after the other as main ghosts Kayako (Takako Fuji) and Toshiro (Yuya Ozeki) take center stage, wreaking havoc with those unfortunate enough to cross its path.Takashi Shimizu did a great job directing the movie that grabs the audience attention with scenes that send chills down your spine, has moments that make you jump, and has disturbing images that will stick in your mind after the movie is over. The mysterious yet dramatic atmosphere of the movie created an eerie feeling of the ongoing horror and the built-up suspense, which are contributed by the cast members' realistic and dramatic acting. Some of the plot lines dangled and are unexplained, but that is a minor flaw.Overall, this is a movie with the right balance of horror and drama - no over-the-top stuff. If you are a fan of horror movies, "The Grudge" is highly-recommended.Grade B+

At exactly 17 minutes and 45 seconds into "The Grudge," the ever-reliable cat jumps out of a closet and scares somebody. I tell you this only so that you will know when you will be able to take a quick refreshment and/or restroom break and not miss anything. It also pretty much underscores the modus operandi of this film, which is "don't bother with something new when something old will do." For although "The Grudge" is a remake of a recent Japanese film ("Ju-On," made by the same director, Takashi Shimizu), there really isn't anything here that we haven't seen hundreds of times before in haunted house movies made east of the International Date Line.The bland Sarah Michelle Gellar plays a young foreign exchange student living in Japan who volunteers as a care worker in her spare time. When she is sent to the home of a strangely "lethargic" woman, Gellar begins to suspect that there is something not quite right about the residence. From then on, she and several other people, who also share a connection with the house, are haunted by a ghoulish specter who keeps popping up in the strangest places and at the most inopportune moments to exact her revenge for being done away with in an untimely manner (although none of the people she pesters had anything to do with her demise).Although there are a few mildly suspenseful moments scattered throughout the film, "The Grudge" is simply too derivative and too hackneyed to register much of an impact on our psyches, with a great deal of its imagery ripped-off from that seminal horror film "Carnival of Souls." The story makes very little sense when you start to analyze it seriously and, after all the huffing and puffing to arrive at a stunning climax, the ending deflates like a slowly leaking balloon. I haven't seen the original version, so I have no idea how it compares to this one. But I can hardly imagine it was anywhere near as undistinguished and lackluster as this one is (or else why remake it?). Even with the same director at the controls, perhaps something simply got lost in the translation.

The film's title refers to a Japanese myth involving the spirits of people who have died in "the grip of a powerful rage". Anyone who comes into contact with these spirits will die. The plot of The Grudge is very simple. An American exchange student, Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar), living in Japan takes a job with a health care center. When one of the other workers doesn't show up, Karen is given her first solo assignment helping an older lady in her home. When Karen arrives, she immediately realizes that something is not quite right. What she doesn't realize is that this house is possessed by spirits who will kill anyone who sets foot inside.Let me start by saying that I have not (as of 2/11/05) seen the original Japanese version. I plan to do so, hopefully, very soon. With that being said, I enjoyed The Grudge much more than I had expected. This is my first experience with Shimizu as a director, but I came away impressed. His has a nice ability to tell a story regardless of the language. The Grudge is one of the best examples of a non-linear story presentation that I can think of. As the movie progressed, it was a treat to watch Shimizu bring the pieces of the story together.Another plus for The Grudge was Shimizu's decision (probably based on budgetary concerns as much as anything) to primarily use "real" effects and less CGI. The make-up on the Kayoka character, for example, created a far more unsettling image than the use of CGI could have. It was obvious that Kayoka was a real person, not just a computer image. The overuse or inappropriate use of CGI has ruined many modern horror movies.There were, however, some areas where the movie could have been better. Gellar is one of the most unappealing leads in Hollywood. I've never understood what all the fuss is about. I always found her extremely annoying.While the movie has many truly creepy (some were downright scary) scenes, the movie relies far too heavily on "jump moments". You know what I mean - a character opens a door and a cat jumps out (The Grudge actually features a cat jumping out of a closet). I've always thought that jump moments were a cheap way to illicit a response from the audience. A few jump moments can be good, but too many just becomes tiring.Given that I wasn't expecting much, The Grudge was a lot of fun. I am looking forward to the sequel and to going back and discovering the original Japanese film - Ju-on: The Grudge.

***SPOILERS*** A house of horrors movie that goes beyond it's four walls to end up killing something like a dozen people by the time the movie is over. Set in Tokyo Japan " The Grudge" can't seem to get going as the story wonders for almost an hour until we get some insight to whats happening in the film and why. Even before the opening credits we see Peter Kirk(Bill Pullman), an American working in Japan, calmly wake up and step out on his high-rise apartment balcony and then jump to his death to the surprise and shock of his terrified wife Maria, Rosa Blasi. We have no idea what Peter in killing himself has to do with the story were seeing until almost the last twenty or so minutes of the movie. It's then that we realize he's the cause of the double murder and suicide that cursed and haunted the house that the movie's about. About three years ago a man went berserk and killed his wife son and even his pet cat then killed himself after he found out that his wife was having an affair with another man. Since then everyone involved with the house that these killings were committed ended up either dead or missing by being effected by the rage thats still within the four walls of the house. Even though were told in the movie's prologue that this rage would effect everyone that comes in contact with it with the same rage that the man who murdered his family and killed himself had. Only one person Matthew Williams, William Mapother, was involved in a murder. Killing himself after he murdered his wife Jennifer, Clea DuVall. The other deaths, because of the person being in the house, were caused by either the ghost of the wife and son of those originally being murdered and by another possible murder victim Yoko, Yoko Maki, a nurse in the killing of her boss Alex, Ted Raimi. None of the murders of the people who were effected by the rage were caused by, as far as I could tell, the ghost of the actual killer, the father. Even the pet black cat had something to do with the later killings. Unlike in almost all"House of Horrors" films the terror in "The Grudge" continues after those involved long left the house. It seems to follow them where ever they go, like Jennifer's sister Susan, KaDee Strickland, and the star of the movie Karen, Sarah Michelle Gellar. The movie has a number of jolting scenes in it, mostly very predictable. One that really shook me up while watching it involved Karen and her boyfriend Doug, Jason Behr, while they were riding on a Tokyo bus.Even though the father of the household who caused all this rage to engulf the house is not involved in any of the killings we do see him in a black and white flashback brutally murdering his entire family.

Karen is a home-care worker that calls on the house of an old lady. Instead she encounters the evil that consumes the house and that if anyone who decides to enter their domain will feel their pain. So now she is racing the clock to figure out the past of the house and in doing so hopefully rid the curse she is now apart of.What I got was basically a rehash of what happen in the original, though there were some subtle changes in the story by Shimizu- but it basically stuck to the main idea, with the time-line of the story going back and forth with different characters that are caught up in the curse, while the home-care worker was the centre piece in the story. Like the original the story at times was uneven- but the atmosphere and images were persistent and simply stood out. To me the story was far less thought provoking, as the remake had less ambiguity, by tying up most of the loose ends and a detail background of the ghosts is explained- but because of that it lacks any kind of mystique that the original had. While the original needs multiple viewings to truly grasp the story, the remake isn't the case.Just like the original also you could say the director over-killed the use of the ghosts, though I would say the scenes in the original were more creative and memorable the scenes of the ghouls were spooky at first with small and subtle glimpses- but after a while it just became repetitious. Though there is some nicely built up tension and fast paced thrills in certain scenes by Shimizu. The music score was too transparent to make it alarming and less effective to be freaky- but the eerie sound effects were definitely perfect in setting the mood.The acting takes a back seat, not awful-but nothing that good. Sarah Michelle Gellar as Karen is alright- but really there is nothing fascinating about her presence, Bill Pullman is wasted in a small cameo role, Jason Behr as Karen's boyfriend seems fairly uninterested and deadpan, while Ted Rami lacks any sort of detail as Karen's boss. Some of the original cast of Ju:on make appearances- but overall there is no real character development, as they come and go with little to do.The settings are quite good, with a very gloomy Tokyo, the haunted house itself is truly menacing and hollow you can just feel the coldness and evil lurking. The violence is nothing graphic, while the chills and scares are either pretty subtle (e.g. striking images or sounds) or the usual BOO! With something popping out though that type of scare was pretty predictable .The ending for me was a bit of a cop out, with the usual let's leave the door open for a possible sequel- but overall I didn't mind this slickly done remake... though I didn't find it as creepy as I did the original.The reason for the constant comparisons with the original in the review is that I watched it the night before seeing this. Anyway it's worth checking out.3/5

I suppose with this film being a remake of a Japanese horror film by Takashi Shimizu, who also did this remake, there will be the inevitable comparisons to "The Ring." Say what you will but The Ring was horrifying, and although the original Ju-On: The Grudge was hailed as the scariest film of all time The Ring (the remake not the Japanese version) was the scariest film I have ever seen hands down and I've seen a lot. The Grudge was excellent. It is the story of a family, a wife and husband and a young boy, who lived in a house in Tokyo. The wife falls completely obsessively in love with an American Professor played briefly by Bill Pullman. The husband discovers his wife's obsession by reading her diary and in an unnatural fit of rage he murders his wife, his son, and their cat before killing himself. According to Japanese folklore when a person dies in a state of rage or deep emotion they leave a curse on the area where they died and it effects everyone who comes into that area. A new family moves into the home, an American businessman, his wife, and his mother. His mother is suffering from old age but the house pushes her into dementia as she barely clings to life being haunted by the dead Japanese wife, and son. The wife begins to torture and eliminate anyone and everyone who sets foot in the house where she was murdered. Sarah Michelle Gellar plays Karen a volunteer caretaker who comes in to look after the elderly woman who has moved into the home. The story is much more complicated than it needs to be and yet at the same time doesn't really ever fully explain clearly what is happening. The scenes of horror creepiness are great and definitely send chills down your spine but they are far apart and are filled with rather slow paced middle story. The movie is almost more of a drama that has moments of scariness. In saying that the scenes of the dead mother and boy are deliciously filmed and are definitely worth a good jump. Sadly Shimizu does at times resort to the "cheap scare" tactics by making you jump in your seat rather than really going for the kind of psychological horror that I had hoped The Grudge would bring. Sarah Michelle Gellar plays the best role I have ever seen her in. She really brings out the acting jibe in this one and granted she hasn't had a lot of opportunity to flex her acting ability but this one did it for her. She played her role perfectly. The Japanese cast including the little boy Toshio played by Yuya Ozeki were brilliant and creepy. Ozeki should have plenty of practise playing this role as this is his third reprisal in the role of Toshio having played him in the original version as well as it's sequel. Point of interest for some the entire Japanese family that plays the evil cursed ghosts are reprising their roles for the third time.I don't think anyone who enjoys a good scary film will be disappointed by The Grudge. It certainly didn't leave me scared to death and I actually felt after leaving the theatre that the film was mostly forgettable which is unfortunate but I hope to see it again as I do believe it will be around a long time as a horror classic.8/10

Review title: Pretty creepy (if you haven't seen the original - apparently)
Review_body: I watched 'The Grudge' in 2004 and was really impressed. Then I learned it was a remake of a Japanese horror film and everyone who'd already watched that couldn't stop talking about how much worse this Hollywood remake was. However, seeing as I've never seen the original (shame on me), I guess I can still enjoy the movie for what it is... a tight little horror story.Sarah Michelle Gellar does her best to play 'Karen' - a character not quite so skilled in killing the undead when she begins her new job in Japan of taking care of a housebound old lady (Grace Zabriskie, from 'Twin Peaks' who seems destined to play these crazy, tortured souls!). Unfortunately, the house she lives in is haunted by a particularly nasty ghost (and just a plain weird ghostly little boy). Soon, Buffy... I mean Karen, finds she can't go anywhere without hearing an ominous throaty drone which seems to indicate that the ghost is about to make an appearance.Despite Sarah Michelle Gellar being the obvious star, there are also sub-plots involving other victims of the spook, namely Clea DuVall and Bill Pullman (don't let the opening scene where he kills himself fool you into thinking there isn't more to his story than just a cameo in the first shots). Because of this the movie does jump around a bit from one set of characters to the next. You have to stick with it to piece together how they are all related before the story finally gets picked up (proper) by Sarah Michelle Gellar, who's left to 'finish' the tale in the third act.I totally enjoyed the spooky atmosphere created and the setting of a Japanese city made a nice change from an American metropolis. There isn't too much blood and gore; instead you get spooky kills where much is left up to the viewers' imaginations. And, although you do see the ghosts pretty well, props to the film-makers who came up with the creepy drone-repeating click noise it makes when it's getting ready for the kill. I haven't watched 'The Grudge' in years, but the one thing I always remember is that noise!Now, I know a lot of similar style ghost stories came out in the 2000s (mainly after the success of the Hollywood version of 'The Ring') and 'The Grudge does suffer a little from being released after 'The Ring' as to setting the standards for movies. Yes, a few moments you may see coming, but it's certainly a lot better than many of the similar genre movies that came out after it and it's as watchable as ever today (even if the mobile phones are out of date!).

I am interested in different type of cinema experiences, and my curiosity has been paid back lately with several Japanese-American productions, trying to play on the exoticism of the Japan setting, while bringing in more Hollywood cinema language and well-known actors. 'The Grudge' is no 'Lost in Translation', but it is still an interesting experience because the same director re-made his original all Japanese film for the American and European audiences. I will not comment on the differences or play 'who is better' game, as I did not see the original. I will just say that 'The Grudge' played quite well for me. There is not to much action in this film, but the horror theme is made credible by the cultural differences. Yes, we as individuals are intimidated by foreign cultures, we feel strange in a different landscape and not understanding the language, so horror is one step closer. Some of the plot line are expedited in a too simple manner, some characters are disappearing without too much explanation and before having created any emotional bound with the user, but still the scary experience is consistent, does not make any sentimental concessions and worked well for me. Acting is average plus, so was directing, and this simple piece of horror gets a 7 out of 10 on my personal scale.

Ugh! What nonsense. American remakes of Japanese horrors are all the rage at the moment. Between this, The Ring and a forthcoming remake of the rather weak Dark Water it seems as if Hollywood has tapped into a new well of unimagination.Which is weird, considering how pointless this remake is. Its only purpose is to serve those who cannot be bothered reading subtitles as the same director and some of the original cast remain as well as the fact that it's set in Japan. If they were bothering to remake it then why change 2 things? The presence of English dialogue and mostly new actors seems a vague reason to redo this film.As PG-13 rated horrors go, this one is still scraping the bottom of the barrel. Seriously, The Grudge is the dredge of horror. I've not seen the original, despite being 'asked kindly' to do so. But I could still see every scare coming. You just know because of the camera angles suddenly changing to an off-centre shot to accommodate something new. Either that or a scene of silence is built up so much that a sudden jolt is the only logical end.Unlike The Ring, there is no mystery to this film. It's all very straight-forward and, in the end, just boils down to typical slasher fare. Or scare-em-to-death fare as no one is physically killed in this film. Other than the Yoko character. Her fate made no sense and did not fit in with the internal 'logic' of the script. And can someone explain Bill Pullman's actions at the beginning for me?A very poor film indeed. Very repetitive, very slow and utterly pointless. As a horror film, The Grudge has as much integrity as Darkness Falls.This film is basically a cure...for NOT being asleep.

Review title: Simply Some Of The Freakiest Stuff I Have Ever Seen In My Life!, With An Amazing Performance From Sarah Michelle Gellar!
Review_body: This is quite simply some of the freakiest stuff i have ever seen in my life, with an amazing performance from Sarah Michelle Gellar!. All the characters are fantastic, and i thought those weird noises were very frightening, plus Sarah Michelle Gellar is simply amazing in this!. This is my 2nd viewing after 1st having seeing it in theaters, it frightened me to death, and i started to panic, upon 2nd viewing it wasn't quite as scary, however it still scared the crap out of me, and i found the score pretty creepy as well, plus i thought Gellar and Jason Behr had very good chemistry together. The plot is hard to follow at times, as your wondering what the hell is going on, however it explains itself pretty good at the end in my opinion, plus the people who are calling this funny, are absolutely messed up in the head. It relies on a lot of jump scares, and boy do they ever work, and i thought the makeup effects were great, plus the ending was awesome!, and paves way for a sequel, and one of my favorite scenes is when KaDee Strickland's character Susan looks under the sheet, and has a surprise waiting for her. This is simply some of the freakiest stuff i have ever seen in my life, with an amazing performance from Michelle Gellar, and i say go see it immediately!. The Direction is wonderful!. Takashi Shimizu does a wonderful job here, with amazing camera work, fantastic angles, constantly adding scary images, and very scary atmosphere, and doing a great job on making us the viewers scared (in my opinion)!. There isn't much gore. except a severed jaw, grotesque faces, blood here and there, a graphic fall victim, and other minor stuff. The Acting is fantastic!. Sarah Michelle Gellar is AMAZING as always, and is amazing here, she is STUNNINGLY GORGEOUS!, fantastic in the acting department, was vulnerable, had very good chemistry with Jason Behr, wa s very caring, and proved she can carry a lead role like a champ!, i loved her! as usual (Gellar Rules!!!). Jason Behr is very likable, and id what he had to do very well, he had very good chemistry with Gellar, and just did a great job. William Mapother is okay here as Matthew and did his job adequately. Clea DuVall is so so here, i am not a big fan of hers, so i wasn't really a fan of her in this one either, she did OK i guess. KaDee Strickland is hot and shows up to collect a paycheck and that's pretty much it. Bill Pullman is fantastic here, he looked awesome, and was just too cool, wished he had more screen time though!.Ted Raimi has a small role here and he did good. Rest of the cast do fine. Overall Go see it immediately,it's some of the freakiest stuff i have ever seen! Ju On is next! i can't wait. ***** out of 5

24 October 2004.
