The cinematographic and directorial technique were great in this movie, but the ending was a pretty miserable failure...unable to really provide the audience with any satisfying new twist on the hundreds of horror movies that have come before. The avoidance of the gory and literally, ghastly onslaught of over the top scenes and sights was a nice touch. This more subtle, sedate, but always ominous mystery builds throughout the movie with nice flashbacks and a great scene of juxtapositions between past and present that rates with any horror movie. The sound effects, the musical background (with some familiar strains from "Wait Until Dark" were effective. This movie wasn't scary in the classic sense, the emotional dread was more saturated like a wet, humid, cloying feeling. Not all of the strands of the movie were tied up by the end, there were lingering questions, and the climax was more of huge letdown. Seven out of Ten Stars (for good directing, but lost potential for a spectacular, memorable hit).

Review title: I tried so hard to enjoy this, but I couldn't...
Review_body: More than just a bit confusing, to say the least. Jumping between couples and time also adds to the confusion. The film plays like a bunch of random ideas thrown into a blender and mixed together. The child character is oh-so-cliched, as are the 'stalking' images on the victim's photographs. During the climax the heroin is so passive, its as if she simply allows everything to happen without any resistance whatsoever. Yawn.

The Grudge is a very good and scary film that has a great cast including Sarah Michelle Gellar, Jason Behr, William Mapother, Clea DuVall, KaDee Strickland, Grace Zabriskie, Bill Pullman, Rosa Blasi, Ted Raimi, Ryo Ishibashi, Yoko Maki, Yuya Ozeki, Takako Fuji, and Takashi Matsuyama! The acting by all of these actors is very good. The action and thrills is really good and some of it is surprising. The movie is filmed very good. The music is great by Christopher Young. Great direction by Takashi Shimizu. The film is really good and the movie really keeps you going until the end. This is a scary and thrilling film. If you like Sarah Michelle Gellar, Jason Behr, William Mapother, Clea DuVall, KaDee Strickland, Grace Zabriskie, Bill Pullman, Rosa Blasi, Ted Raimi, the rest of the cast in the film, Horror, Mystery, Thrillers, Comedy, and interesting films then I strongly recommend you to see this film today!

This movie is the Western remake of a Japanese horror film based on the idea that a powerful curse appears in a place where someone full of rage dies violently, and that curse can destroy everything around. This is what happened in a certain house in a residential neighborhood of Tokyo, where there are mysterious deaths happening. After a visit, the young American Karen Davis begins to feel haunted and will research the history of the house, in search of a way to ward off the evil that pursues her. Directed by Takashi Shimizu, this film is different from almost everything I've seen in horror: what frightens us is the depth of the permanent tension felt throughout the film. Okay, I've never seen the original so I cannot see how close it is, but it did not fail to impress me. The script is good, the story is interesting and make me remember of "The Ring", with all the focus on investigating that dark history. Sarah Michelle Gellar is the protagonist, but she does not make a particularly interesting performance, like none of the actors. Despite this, it's a worth watching horror movie.

Review title: The Grudge begrudgingly latches onto croaky jump scares without logical cohesion.
Review_body: This, is an unusual horror to review. It's rather uncommon for the same director, in this case Takashi Shimizu, to remake his own original film for an entirely different audience. Most would push their original creation onto the masses and convince them, with glorified persuasion, to withstand subtitles and invest the time into the chilling ghost story.Yet Shimizu thought it would be apt to direct his own film again. Admirable? Yes, it ensured he received total creative control over the studio and producers. Necessary? No. Somehow, by remaking the exact story with essentially the same spine-tingling sequences, Shimizu downgraded the atmospheric aura of 'Ju-On', resulting in nothing more than a Japanese ghost boy releasing his inner cat and his ethereal mother croaking the life out of anyone who visits the cursed house. That's the plot synopsis, right there.Well, there's a tad bit more to the mystery, however Shimizu's insistence on haphazardly fracturing the narrative between present day and the past week consequently confused audiences rather than enthral. There's no logic behind the structure. No foundational development. And certainly no characterisation. So the abrupt switching back and forth held no purpose, other than to illustrate a host of jumpy death sequences. Some effective apparitional imagery heightened the tension, particularly the surveillance footage sequence and bedroom scene that made me frightened of my own bloody duvet when I was an innocent boy, yet negated by the bland acting from every single actor.Buffy has no more vampires to slay or Daphne has solved all remaining mysteries (take your pick...), and so she's left wandering aimlessly around Tokyo with just one facial expression. Confusion. Pullman contributed nothing. And even Kayako herself, Fuji, was grossly misused during moments of tension-raising buildup. The final expositional flashback sequence, revealing to us why the house is now essentially cursed, was rushed and overwrought. Then concluding the entire feature on a frickin' jump scare that looked cheaper than Kayako's mascara. By the time the credits roll, you'll be thinking to yourself "...why are these Americans in Tokyo anyway?".I just...don't understand how Shimizu can make his remake so unprogressive in terms of quality. He had another shot at bettering his original, overcoming previous criticisms, yet failed miserably. I'm open to the idea that The Grudge is a product of its time, comprising of several horror traits that the previous decade had commonly exploited. And I appreciate it stuck to its J-horror roots. But damn, this has not aged well in the slightest. The core is there. I can visibly see the contents. Yet, either due to Shimizu's inability to improve in directorial control or studio interference, The Grudge growled like a ghoulish kitten instead of exhuming a ghostly lion's roar. Y'know, because Toshio opens his CGI mouth and a cat noise comes out? Urgh, whatever. Couldn't think of anything...

The plot behind "The Grudge" is chilling but it takes too long before it gets interesting. The situations are slow moving but that's not necessary bad because it helps to grow interest on the main characters. Sadly, as most of the important events are told in flashbacks you keep forgetting about the lead female. Still, it's not a bad idea. This could be considered as a ghost revenge flick. Here, the supernatural elements are consequences of a tragedy occurred in real life. To be honest, this is the typical Horror movie that relies most of it's suspense moments on CGI. The movie is filled with false scares and CGI effects of ghosts. Don't expect tension or suspense. Think about "The Ring" but with a little more blood and you have basically the same movie. Even the ending (which is beyond ridiculous; almost as bad as in the "Amytiville Horror" remake) was inspired by those kind of movies. The direction and visuals are pretty good actually. The locations were perfectly selected for this kind of movie. The f/x were really good when required. The problem with CGI is that most movies like this one tend to abuse of it. Also, I didn't know Sarah Michelle Gellar was such a bad actress. She delivers a wooden, emotionless performance. The rest of the cast just does what they can. It's not that bad at all...Do yourself a favor and don't watch this over rated ghost movie. For a better movie of the likes of this movie, watch "The Others", or "Supernatural". "The Grudge" is dedicated for a younger audience but still it's a very mediocre effort. Even for a remake...

Review title: Effective Japanese horror dulled by unnecessary remake and unnecessary CGI.
Review_body: In perusing all the negative comments about The Grudge spread out among the IMDb, I'm amazed at how many people, even professional critics, have gotten the basic premise completely wrong. The curse that the movie is centered around is not created when someone dies in a horrible way, it's created when someone dies "in the grip of anger." The terrible rage that has consumed someone at the time of their death is what creates the curse, and then that rage consumes anyone that it comes into contact with, at which point it also renews itself.Not that it matters, however, for the most part, people have been tending to be right about the rest of the movie. It's a remake of a Japanese film of the same name, which was released barely a year before this one and was directed by the same guy and is, by the way, leaps and bounds better than this one. You know all this stuff. The infamous opening scene of the American version is certainly surprising and promises an interesting movie, but then the movie veers off in a completely different direction and for most of the time it seems like that first scene is completely unrelated.Ultimately, it is little more than your standard haunted house story, which is probably the oldest and weakest story in the horror book. If you make a movie about a haunted house these days, there better be something truly interesting about it, otherwise it is guaranteed to sink unnoticed into obscurity.Sarah Michelle Gellar, a veteran of bad American horror movies, enters the mix adding her unique brand of weak horror acting. She's a college student finally granted her long- standing wish to travel abroad, but unfortunately she gets placed in this house helping to care for an old woman suffering from dementia, which basically means she spends most of the time staring into empty spaces at ghostly things that no one else seems to realize are really there. Gradually, we come to realize that she's not just losing her mind, she's being driven insane by ghostly forces that simply won't leave her alone. Enter another couple, Jennifer and Matthew, who are also living in Japan temporarily, as the husband has business there. Clea DuVall, the most talented actor in the entire movie, plays Jennifer, and the becomes immediately unhappy with the whole situation. She is having major problems adjusting to life in Japan, unable to communicate, unable to read any of the packages on the food at the supermarket, etc. Basically many of the same troubles I had when I moved here to China two years ago. As is to be expected, weird things start happening.You get the idea. I have heard people defend the movie by saying that there is nothing to complain about, the ghosts act perfectly naturally by lashing out at anyone who comes near because of course they're angry about how they died and want to take it out on someone! Yeah, I can understand that, but a movie about that and nothing else? And not only one, but TWO movies? Is it too much to ask for more than exactly the same kind of story that he been being told for hundreds of years?Since I am an American living in an Asian culture myself, I had hoped that they would take the opportunity to use the combination of American actors in a Japanese film to give us some kind of cultural analysis, maybe even something that would compare the Japanese and American horror styles. The opportunities were endless, but they were all ignored in favor of simply Americanizing a Japanese horror film. And having seen more than my share of both styles of horror, I can tell you that Americanizing Japanese horror is not the way to make it better!

Review title: Finally, a remake of a Japanese horror film worth watching.
Review_body: The Grudge (2004) was a treat. A remake of the Japanese hit Ju-On that is about as good as the original. The only thing that I found wrong with this Japanese redux was the content matter was toned down, other than that nit pick it was a great horror film to watch. This is the film that The Ring (2002) was supposed to be, Instead of being filled with a bunch of cheap thrills and nonsensical images, the direction and the shocks were actually effective.A foreign exchange student living in Japan is also a care giver in her spare time. During one assignment she goes to a house that has a reputation. A horrific murder occurred there several years ago. The father went insane killing his wife, son and even the pet cat!, now they all inhabit the house!! The real estate agent was more than pleased to get the house sold. But the house is cursed by several restless spirits. Who ever enters the house feels the wrath from the former residents. The four ghosts appear before the visitors. But in reality they might only be one mean entity. The anger and hate the people felt before they died managed to form into one evil presence.What I enjoyed about this film was the fact that the director was trying to make a film that is sort of an introductory to western audiences about Asian ghosts and legends. Instead of making a confusing movie that would annoy viewers (like The Ring (2002).If you like horror films then by all means watch the Grudge. You should watch the Japanese original Ju-On. Despite what others say, they go hand in hand.Highly recommended!

Review title: Japanese Ghosts and the haunted house
Review_body: Japanese directors have it seems, acquired several successful techniques about movie making from the Americans. Most noticeable the dramatic art of fear. The gist of their story is of a particular house in Japan which has become the haunted residence of a violently murdered family. Having experienced a brutal crime, the spirits now infect any and all visitors who come in contact with the possessed property. The victims range from a visiting nurse to an American family, all of whom succumb to the mysterious menace. What the film lacks however, is story cohesion. Interlacing several mixed vignettes which drag a reluctant audience towards a set of Vandalistic monsters, who's intent is on absorbing their victims, rather than devouring them. Next, is the provocative appearance of the child spirit, which evokes a morbid prurient interest, but little else. Furthermore, with the exception of Bill Pulman and Ryo Ishibashi, as the detective, terror is held to a minimum. All and all, a tolerable horror story, but falls short of American standards. **

Karen Davis (Sarah Michell Gellar), an American nurse working in Tokyo, is hired to cover for a caretaker who had not shown up to work. When Karen arrives she finds the house in total disarray and her patient in mute shock. Unwittingly, Karen discovers the presence of murderous, vengeful ghosts, bent on destroying anyone who enters the house - and then passing along their plague to their loved ones.There's a legend in Japan, you see, that says that when a person dies in a state of sorrow or rage, that emotion remains behind to haunt others. Can Karen escape the curse and prevent it from ensnaring her boyfriend Doug? Whoa, not so fast, there. This is Buffy the Vampire Slayer, here, true, but she's not Superman. Surely Karen can't topple an ancient curse, right? Horror movies are all the rage now, which is good. Even better, the emphasis seems to be on suspense as much as it's on gore and whatnot. The Grudge trucks with the former much more than with the latter, which is also a good thing. It's an amusing, entertaining little film, and there's no slight intended. Rather than overwhelm the viewer's senses with loud noises and blood, director Takashi Shimizu opts instead for what lurks around the corner and under the bed. Yes, you do see some gross things (including an undead being that looks like it walked off the set of The Ring), but watching the movie isn't like stepping into a house of horrors in which what you see is what's scary. As with the scariest movies, what you don't see can kill you.Gellar is pretty good, considering she's been in movies like I Know What You Did Last Summer. The Grudge is leagues ahead of crappy teenyboppers-in-peril movies like that one (and Scream 2, in which Gellar also appeared), in terms of both style and story. Really, it's like the difference between Scooby Doo and Columbo. Sure, it's a fairly easy gig, playing a victim in a horror movie. And, of course, if you're pretty much the only "name" actor in the movie, chances are pretty good that your character is going to survive it, in one form or another. Even so, I was pleasantly surprised at how well Gellar essayed her character's abject terror, so kudos to her.Really, if I hadn't already seen The Ring, I might have thought this was even better than it turned out to be - although I did think it turned out better than I had anticipated. It might seem a little derivative of The Ring to folks out there, but it seems to have derived only the good stuff.

Review title: Ju-on-The Curse (Creep ed me out) Ju-on-The Grudge (Scared the hell out of me) The Grudge (less scary then both)
Review_body: I have now re-watch all 3 version of the some-what same plot lol.This remake was not as bad i thought it . the last time I saw IT.it did have some hint of suspense from the Ju-on movies But it not on the same level as Ju-on-The Grudge as that movie scared the hell out of me.Which was really good for a remake have hold of it, it had some really decent scare scene thought out the whole movie but there some good scenes that have great tension but the scares are a little to tame and make it look a little sillyI did get the feel that this was more of remake of Ju-on-The Curse (2000) with bit from both Ju-on-the Grudge 1 and 2.The acting this movie was really good from the whole cast 5 out of 10

Review title: Japanese Americanised re-make of a Japanese pilfered horror (but still quite good)
Review_body: Creepy ghostly phantasms appear out of nowhere, a nasty house, fairly standard horror-flick components, but nicely put together in a superficial and derivative mix that somehow is not only fairly entertaining but not entirely without artistic merit. Most of the attraction is maybe from the Japanese style episodic nature of the story telling, the judicious but unashamed special effects, and the equally Japanese tradition that says you don;t have to explain all the details of the story. I must admit I did (I am told) fall asleep at least once, but I honestly don't think I missed too much. Like about half the rest of the people there, I was practicing the spectre-like a-a-a-a-a-a at the back-of-the-throat-sound on the way out. This is the kind of silly horror film you jump in, have nightmares about, giggle stupidly when recounting it to your friends, and generally enjoy before having fun slagging it off.

The Grudge scared me senseless when i saw it at the cinema way back in 2004, this is TRULY a great Horror movie, it's terrifying & extremely atmospheric, the tone is dark & spooky all the time.Sarah Michelle Gellar is really good as the lead & gives a really good terrified performance, she's a very underrated actress.
The Japanese locations are very creepy because we're not used to it, Americans in a foreign country dealing with something supernatural is a very scary situation & it plays out perfectly.The Grudge is scary as hell with it's sense of dread, there was tons of supernatural Horror films out during this time as it was a great time but this is one of the absolute best.
This is a Horror-mystery with strong performances & brilliantly directed by Takashi Shimizu.

Review title: Creepy and Well Done Japanese Remake.
Review_body: "The Grudge" follows a young nurse, Karen, (Sarah Michelle Gellar) who lives in Tokyo, Japan, and is sent to work at an old house where an elderly woman is living. Unfortunately, the house has a horrible past and a curse was laid upon it - a curse that is brought upon anyone who dares to step into the house. What would have been a routine job for Karen becomes a nightmare where she must fight against good and evil and try and stop the curse from claiming her.This movie came out at the perfect time- just before Halloween, when most people are looking for a scary movie to watch. I will say that I enjoyed "The Grudge". Sure, it does follow some horror clichés (example: after hearing strange noises in the attic, you go explore with a lighter as your only light source) but I still enjoyed it for the most part and it works out as a decent horror movie overall.This film uses loads of "jump" scenes to scare you which are effective, but there were continuous "jump" scenes throughout this movie, which tend to be overused in today's horror films. This film could've been better if it had used more scare tactics, but "The Grudge" does have some really disturbing scenes that are also effective. I guarantee you will jump at least once throughout the movie, it has some unexpected scares. The only problem people may have with this movie is that it's hard to follow, and the film ends when you wouldn't expect it to. If you pay enough attention though, you should be fine, otherwise if you don't you will be lost. I've only seen a little bit of the Japanese original so I can't really compare and contrast the two, but if you're looking for some good scares, go see "The Grudge". It's well-written, well-acted, and has some splendidly scary scenes (the staircase scene was just flat out disturbing). I think I liked it better than "The Ring" myself. 8/10.

The Grudge (2004) is an okay horror film. Sarah Michelle Gellar stars, and I think Sarah does do well in her role, but the cast/acting isn't really the issue I took with the movie. The problem I had with it was that it had many times where it was slow and just boring, didn't do a great job with keeping your attention. I also didn't enjoy Bill Pullman in his co-starring role, he didn't seem believable to me. The beginning isn't bad, but as the movie progresses towards the middle of the movie, it really does slow down. The visuals certainly aren't anything to write home about, just pretty average. I like Gellar, and I have enjoyed her in many roles, but I think this movie was a mistake, it just didn't entertain me and it seemed pretty average, maybe even below average at some points. 5/10 for The Grudge. My recommendation is to skip this one and keep looking if you're looking for a good horror movie that'll entertain and scare, there are plenty better ones out there.

Full of potential but lacking really any execution- The first remake of the japanese horror flick Ju-on: The Grudge is not only a dissapointment, but mostly a waste of time. The film is very unique with its way of telling the story, and though it can be hard at times to follow, and a bit messy, I can't help but praise it for trying to do something new. Sarah Michelle Gellar leads the huge and often random cast of characters we get to see in the film, and almost none of the actors prove to be memorable. There are a handful of few that try their best with the roles provided, those people being: KaDee Strickland, Bill Pullman, and Ryo Ishibashi. I do give the film credit to sticking to its setting of Japan, like so many other Japanese horror remakes decide against, but I can't feel like it made much of a difference, and it seems to just give this film less and less of a point to have been made. I haven't seen the original, although I do plan on watching it sometime soon. But I can't help but feel The Grudge (2004) is for the most part a dull imitator of its original, and has nothing really to offer horror fans and movie goers alike. It does have some decently creepy scenes throughout, but nothing too good to actually hold the film together. Interesting plot points begin, and end just as soon as the appear, and I can't help but feel that somewhere lost within this film is a potentially conceivable and very compelling horror story. In the end, The Grudge is forgettable, and has very little to offer. It tries at times, but isn't enough to provide for a decent viewing.My Rating: 3/10.

Review title: It succeeded in being scary. Lots of good scares and creepy atmosphere.
Review_body: There have been about a hundred American remakes of Japanese horror films recently, and the Grudge is the only one that worked for me. I saw this in the theaters and the mood in the film, and the audience was genuinely scared and tense. In fact, this is probably the most scary atmosphere I've seen in a recent horror film. The plot, the actors and everything else comes second to the scares and the atmosphere. Most movies would bother me if that was the case, but this one didn't. It was trying to be a horror film, and that's all it was, and a darn good one I must say.For some reason all the American remakes of Japanese flicks still take place in Japan, with American actors. Sarah Michelle Gellar plays Karen Davis, a nurse who begins to take care of an elderly old lady at her house. The old lady is killed by a strange presence in the house, and Karen is plagued with a curse which is killing all the people around her and scaring the audience half to death.Jump scenes are a technique used by almost every "teenager" or "slasher" horror film, and they only cause quick scares that only catch those paying attention at that moment. There are a few jump scenes here, but most of the scares are built from the super creepy environment and the thought that we know something will happen, just when is it coming? The grudge ghosts were also pretty scary. When "The Ring" came out and it was touted as some sort of remake masterpiece for modern horror I felt I must see it. I was very disappointed. "The Grudge" opened to mixed reviews, none really praising it, and for scares and overall artistic direction, "The Grudge" was a triumph. The plot makes no sense, and that's one of the big problems with this movie. With a more logical plot, maybe this would have been a well reviewed movie. But throw the plot away for this one, I still enjoyed it! My rating: *** out of ****. 95 mins. PG-13 for terror and violence.

Review title: Fans of the genre probably enjoy it
Review_body: 'The Grudge' is a horror film about a haunted house, although the characters are able to leave the house. Not that it really matters, once you have entered it you are doomed. Sarah Michelle Gellar is one of those people, Bill Pullman belonged to them three years earlier. The opening sequence involves the Pullman-character and it felt so good I thought this film might be pretty good. For me it was not, the first scene stayed the best, but I realized that a lot of people might enjoy this. I mean, you want it to be scary and I guess it could be for many. At least the person I was watching it with found it to be quite scary.My main problem here is that even when it is scary for some, the moments are created through the ways we have seen so many times before. Empty places and people alone, instead of walking away they take a look. Funny how people in the film are instantly scared when they hear a noise, even before they realize strange things are happening. The music tells us something will happen, the camera stays close to the character so things can enter the screen quite suddenly and then... well, most of the time something that has nothing to do with the story gives a reaction to most members from the audience. 'The Grudge' has these moments, although most of them actually do show us events that involve the story. I just didn't care much since we have the same approach here.Up to a level I guess I enjoyed it. For me some of the fun came from guessing what would jump in front of the camera, but again, my friend was actually scared at times. Therefore I must admit this film does the job better than most horror films. Films like 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre' or 'Wrong Turn' depend on gore, this one at least has the nerve to depend on the old simple tricks (keeping it a PG-13 rated film), apparently succeeding from time to time. If you normally enjoy this kind of film you will like this very much. If you want an interesting and intelligent story you should avoid this, it is as simple as that.

Review title: Good Remake of a J-Horror Classic
Review_body: This film I remember seeing for the first time not too long after seeing the American remake of The Ring. This one did throw me off a bit due to the story being told out of order, but it made me feel uncomfortable. Since then, I've seen this one a handful of times throughout the years and have seen the original Japanese version along with all of its sequels. I am coming back to this as I haven't seen this one in some time, but it did fall into the Podcast Under the Stairs Summer Challenge Series as I'm still working through that list. The synopsis here is an American nurse living and working in Tokyo is exposed to a mysterious supernatural curse, one that locks a person in a powerful rage before claiming their life and spreading to another victim.As the synopsis states, we're in Japan. We are in the apartment of Peter (Bill Pullman) and his wife Maria (Rosa Blasi). He is out on the balcony and looks troubled. Maria wakes up and asks what he's doing. He doesn't respond, instead he slides over top of the railing falling to his death.We then shift to a woman of Yoko (Yôko Maki) as she makes her way to a house that she helps out in. There is an old woman who doesn't talk much of Emma (Grace Zabriskie). We learn that she has dementia and needs to have round the clock care. While Yoko is cleaning up the house, she goes upstairs to find Kayako (Takako Fuji). She is making a weird sound and pulls Yoko up before we cut awayIt then takes us to an apartment shared by Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar) and Doug (Jason Behr). He is up trying to look for clean shirt to go to class. She wakes up to help him. We learn that doesn't have class today, but she has to pick up a book from a care center she volunteers at. As she stops in, her supervisor of Alex (Ted Raimi) asks if she can fill in for Yoko. She will check in on her patient as her first solo visit. Yoko didn't show up today for work.The house she goes to is that of Emma. Karen finds the house tore up much like Yoko did. Emma is laying by her bed where we see she urinated. Karen cleans her and the rest of the house. Upstairs she finds the closest door is taped shut. She hears noises inside and clears it away. Inside is a little boy named Toshio (Yuya Ozeki). Karen calls Alex to report everything she's encountered. When she goes back to Emma's room, she is talking to someone. When Karen asks about it and she states she just wants her to leave her alone. That is when something comes from the corner of the ceiling, terrifying them both.From here, the movie starts to fill in the events that got us here. This includes meeting Emma's son of Matthew (William Mapother) and his wife of Jennifer (Clea DuVall). They're moving here for Matthew's work and Emma will be staying with him. Also there is Susan (KaDee Strickland) who is Matthew's sister. We see as they're looking at the house there isn't something right. They don't necessarily completely understand and move in. Weird things start to happen to them. We also see a detective, Nakagawa (Ryo Ishibashi) as he tries to piece together what is happening. He knows the history of the house, but as a detective, he can't believe it is supernatural. It becomes a nightmare for all those who encounter this cursed house.That's where I'm going to leave my recap and I'll shift this over to my thoughts on what this version does. I've already said that I saw this early into the ghostly J-horror movies and I really liked it. The last time I saw this movie, my rating went down a bit as I do think the actual Japanese takes are better. This one does have in its favor that the director is Takashi Shimizu, the writer and director of the original. I've come back up on this one for the following reasons.The first thing would be I like that this is still set in Tokyo. We have these Americans as the main characters to bring that audience in. This movie also plays on the idea of them being outsiders. Karen needs to ask directions and after being helped, we see the mother that she talks to hiding her daughter from her. We also get where Jennifer isn't enjoying her time here. None of them know the history of the house that the curse is in so that helps as well.That is where I want to take it next. The movie does have the title card in the beginning explaining what ju-on is. Where I think this movie has a bit of a misstep is not giving us a bit more of Toshio, Kayako or Takeo (Takashi Matusyama). We know how Kayako plays into things here with Peter. We also know what Takeo did. It is a bold move by Shimizu to not explain what a Japanese audience would recognize as normal haunting elements in their country. I get along fine seeing this since I have seen Ju-on: The Curse, it's sequel, along with the first remake of Ju-on: The Grudge along with the sequel there. Many Americans might not know this comes from this mythology. I also think most audience members would care as much as I do.Last thing with the story that I want to delve into woudl be that of Nakagawa. He is a detective, but I also like that he is willing to entertain the idea of the supernatural. Part of this could be that he is Japanese. As an American though, I'm used to the police not believing and many times it works to the story. I like here that it is breaking the norm though. He was also friends with the officers that worked the original case so he did get to see what happened there as well.I'll shift this over next to the acting. I really like Gellar's performance in this movie. I'll admit, I have a crush on her, but she also plays this out of place young woman very well. She has a good heart, wants to help those around her and is just nice all around. She fits the role very well. I think that Behr is fine as her counterpart. Mapother is solid along with DuVall. Strickland has one of the more creepier sequences in the movie and her fear is quite believable. Ishibashi is good in his role as the detective. I'm glad that htey got Ozeki and Fuji for their roles here. The latter is so creepy and pretty much always plays the role of Kayako. I also thought the cameos by Zabriskie, Pullman, Raimi and the rest rounded this out for what was needed.Then there would be the effects. The practical effects are good. We get a bit of blood here that looks real. The make-up that they do with Toshio and Kayako is really good. Once again the latter is very creepy here with the look on her face. How she moves really helps as well. This version does have some CGI, but I'll be honest, it worked for me. I didn't have any issues there and I was pleasantly surprised. There is also the cinematography which was well done on top of that.The last thing would be the sound design. The use of the creepy sound of Kayako works for me. I know that it is recording a comb, but it is effective. I don't believe this version explains why she makes that noise which is a safe. Toshio making noises like a cat is also quite creepy on top of that. The soundtrack aside from that fit for what was needed and does help to set the mood for sure.In conclusion, this movie I feel I unjustly came down on trying to defend the original where this is just a different take and incorporating different elements. That isn't to say that everything works. There are some things that I think are left out that could really help this movie in my opinion. The acting is good and the effects, both practical and CGI, work in the movies favor. I'd also say that the sound design and the soundtrack help to set the mood with making this movie creepier. I'd say this movie is a good movie overall, just lacking some elements for me to go higher.

It helps seeing both the original, JU ON, and THE GRUDGE back to back to see why remakes just don't work most of the time and what one should never do in a horror film if the first version was already perfect. Rarely have they ever done so: except for Hitchcock's own re-telling of THE MAN WHO KNEW TOO MUCH in 1956, most of the times they have failed miserably. This one retells the same story, eliminating two major plot arcs from the first (the three missing students who were at the house with the haunted detective's daughter, and Mariko's storyline who served to expand on the curse, here served by Bill Pullman's storyline), and adding a boyfriend to Sarah Michelle Gellar's Karen, as well as creating yet another brief role in the beginning -- the caretaker of the old lady, unseen in the first.THE GRUDGE is no exception to the rule of the unnecessary remake: While it does have one or two minor moments of silent dread as when Clea duVall's character meets her fate in the haunted house, the use of black tendrils and shock moments don't quite help bring the real horror, and Sarah Michelle Gellar conveys absolutely nothing in her scene when she is found crouched in a corner by the dead old lady (Grace Zabriskie), which negates the intense blankness that one could see in Megumi Okina's harrowed face in the original. I have a sneaking suspicion that this was a joint effort to capitalize on the success of JU ON and bring it (quite badly) upon the more complacent and less demanding American public. And while some of the elements of the Sakei family tragedy answers some questions, the essence of horror is to leave these questions partly answered, or unanswered. This always makes the insanity of what happens even more haunting, unsettling.

Review title: Some story fumbling but an effective horror film
Review_body: In horror films, spirits and ghosts are popular creatures used in hauntings and spook fests. Sometimes though, the incarnations featured in the US don't come across unique or creepy. With that, every now and then international influence helps rejuvenate an industry. Movies are no different when it comes to the US as well. Which is why this film was made, when Sam Raimi saw the original movie released in Japan under the title Ju-On (2002). Usually when a story is adapted into a foreign market, there is a loss in translation due to cultural differences. That doesn't seem to be the case here though, as this Americanized version of the film seems to be handled with just as much care.Directed by Takashi Shimizu who also directed the original Japanese film, the story is about transfer student Doug (Jason Behr) and his girlfriend Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar) who moved to Japan to receive caretaker credit. When an assigned caretaker doesn't report into work for a specific residence, Karen fills in only to discover something isn't right about the location of the house. Adapted by Stephen Susco in his first theatrical writing credit, the story is clearly disturbing in way that'll keep its viewer watching with intrigue. The person who lives at the house is Emma (Grace Zabriskie), the mother of Matthew (William Mapother), Susan (KaDee Strickland) and mother in law to Matthew's wife Jennifer (Clea DuVall). When Karen reveals to local police detective Nakagawa (Ryo Ishibashi) that she saw a creepy child named Toshio (Yuya Ozeki) is when the plot thickens.Most of the characters depicted in this story are an interesting bunch. Sarah Michelle Gellar best known for her roles in Cruel Intentions (1999), Scooby-Doo (2002) and Buffy the Vampire Slayer TV Show, plays a likable lead even though she's not totally the main focus. The reason for this is the slightly disjointed execution from director Shimizu. In order to explain why this residence has a lingering spirit, the movie takes its audience through a series of different flashbacks at different times. They are not hard to follow, but the moments at which they begin and end feels like they're in the wrong place. Or at the very least could been shown at a different time in the story. Runner up to Gellar's performance was Ishibashi's role as detective Nakagawa. Rounding out the cast, the movie also has appearances from Bill Pullman, Rosa Blasi, Ted Raimi, Yôko Maki, and Takako Fuji.What also makes the story to this horror film entertaining is the inclusion of Japanese mythology. Based loosely on the belief on how it occurs, the title of the film appropriately lends to the nature of the disgruntled antagonist. Perhaps the only other component to the film that won't please in particular the gore hounds is the level of violence. It's not much, but considering it's a PG-13 rated film, that's rare. Plus, the original Japanese version didn't have any. Besides, ghostly apparition films are more psychological than they are gory. The effects are also very well put together despite its budget and year that it was made. Very little of it is CGI and the parts that actually show the spirit, look like stop-motion but are indeed the talent of the actor, which is very impressive to say the least.Camerawork was also skillfully shot for this picture. Hideo Yamamoto served as the cinematographer. Yamamoto also worked on the original One Missed Call (2003), another popular Japanese horror film and a year later would do the same for Tetsujin 28 (2005). As for music, the score was composed by famed gothic composer Christopher Young. Although part of the sound heavily relies on dark brooding soundscapes, Young did compose two main themes which in their own right are memorable for the franchise. Considering Young also composed other great works like Hellraiser (1987) and Species (1995), it's nice that director Shimizu chose him to provide the music for this film. Thankfully an album exists and has just the right amount of creep factor to it to entertain.The way the story is told can feel out of place and gore may seem light to those who want it, but that's not much compared to the entire experience. The plot which includes some Japanese culture is captivating, the visuals are good and the music is entertaining for the genre.

"Once you have become a part of it...it will never let you go. I'm sorry."I remember thinking that The Grudge was a pretty good horror flick when I was a teenager. Scary, as well. Boy, I must have been easily entertained back then.I suppose it would be pretty frightening if an evil spirit attached itself to you in real life, and there was no way to break the curse. But seeing it happen as The Grudge portrays it is pretty meh. This movie simply isn't scary. It relies on the simplest of jump scares, and it's only very often that they actually startle you. Scenes suddenly end and move on to the next, without ever explaining what happened to the characters in the missing time. People see things that would have any normal human being freaking out, and then carry on with whatever they were doing, as if nothing untoward happened. I haven't visited Japan, but I'm pretty sure that seeing vanishing, drowned ghost boys is so common there, that it doesn't cause much comment. Sarah Michelle Gellar plays a role that is so bland, that it hardly counts as a character. And she's the most fleshed-out of the entire bunch. Even the short runtime seems too long for what actually happens. The Grudge may have been passable back in 2004, but no longer. See Ju-on, instead. Or any of the other superior horror movies that have been released since then.

Review title: I had a good time watching this movie, even though I'm not a very big fan of horror movies
Review_body: I'm not familiar with Japanese horror movies at all and to be honest I'm not really a big fan of horror movies in general. Why I don't like horror movies all that much? Certainly not because I'm easily scared. It's because most of the time all that is considered as horror is rather stupid, predictable and too messy.A more than average, even intelligent horror movie is sometimes very rare and hard to find. The average horror movie is about at least one pretty, young blonde girl being chased by a madman and being cut open with a giant blade while almost screaming her lungs out. Another common theme is vampires or cannibals trying to get into a house with probably very juicy looking people, so they can eat them alive. One thing they all have in common: You'll see gallons of blood flowing and you almost start wondering if you shouldn't have put a bucket under your TV.The only reason that I did go to see this movie was because one of my friends absolutely wanted to watch it. I didn't expect much of it, but big was my surprise after seeing this movie. I actually had a good time! The beginning of the movie is "impressive" to say the least (Bill Pulman jumping of the balcony without saying a word to her, as his wife says to him that he is up early) and the story was very interesting. I liked the idea (based on a Japanese legend) that if someone dies in great anger or sadness, his or her soul remains at that place and functions as some kind of curse that wants to destroy all people who come into that same place. Finally a horror movie with a more original approach (yes, I know that it is a remake, but I haven't seen the original, so for me this is all new). This was actually a rather clever, well-crafted horror movie, but if there is one thing that I didn't like about the movie, it is Sarah Michelle Gellar. I've never been a fan of her and in my opinion she only got this role because she is seen as THE perfect lure for the teenage male audience. You know, the guys who probably all have at least 2 posters of her hanging on their walls, fantasizing about her when being alone (I don't even want to think of what more they do with it)... If the role of Karen had been played by for instance Nicole Kidman I would have liked it a lot more. But OK, it wasn't so, I better stop whining about it.Overall this is a very good horror movie that has a lot of suspense to offer. Most of the time you know that something is going to happen, but the hint is given in such a way that it doesn't bother (the same technique Hitchcock used to use in his movies). "The Grudge" shows that a good horror movie doesn't need to be filled with monsters or gallons of blood, but that things you don't know or see can be more terrifying. I liked it a lot and I give it an 8/10.

Compelling horror movie with a particularly jarring sound effect that while sounds like a noise you make in the back of your throat, is surprisingly effective at conjuring some truly nightmarish images. SMG stars (don't let that deter you though) as an aged carer living in Japan while her boyfriend chases his dream (Behr) when the woman for whom she's caring (Zabriskie) dies suddenly from unexplained forces that continue to haunt SMG and anyone with whom it comes into contact. Local police regard the crimes as being sub-human and inevitable, able to do little as the tainted house and its far-reaching curse claim more victims.More than a little reminiscent of "The House Where Evil Dwells" (1982), this American version of a highly successful Japanese movie ("Ju-on" 2002) is quite tense and although not especially gory (perhaps one memorable moment in the hallway of the school), still packs a punch. SMG is cute in her pixie, upside-down smile kind of way, and the supporting cast including Bill Pullman, KaDee Strickland, Ted Raimi, William Mapother and Grace Zabriskie are all pretty effective.Director Shimizu (who also directed the Japanese version) seems pretty capable in building almost unbearable suspense, delivering more than your average 'haunted house' picture. If there's one, mild criticism it's the Bill Pullman character connection was a little under-played, with only limited explanation for his character's relevance, though he does enjoy a couple of the more surreal and terrifying moments. Simple stuff, well told.

Review title: "The Grudge" is a decent Americanized Remake of the Japanese original, but it pales in comparison, and has many small issues holding it back from being a great remake...
Review_body: This is one of those reviews that's hard to write, if for no other reason than I feel that the score I am giving this film (a 6 out of 10) may be somewhat misleading. And it was a hard choice. I bopped back and forth between giving it an "average" score of 6 and a "pretty good" score of 7. But I had to fundamentally stick to my guns and give it the score I feel it deserves.Takashi Shimizu directs this 2004 American remake of his own 2002 release "Ju-On: The Grudge." (Which itself is the third film in an ongoing horror-movie series over in Japan, although it is the most well- known entry overseas, where the first two films have yet to see release) And it is a fairly faithful adaptation of his prior film, albeit with some large changes both in content and style to accommodate the mostly American production and the aim at a wider western audience.The film, much like Shimizu's original, follows a non-linear series of short story-vignettes set in Japan. These vignettes piece together like a puzzle to tell a much larger story of the effects a ghostly curse has on various people unfortunate enough to feel its grasp. The dominant focus is on Karen Davis, portrayed by Sarah Michelle Gellar, an exchange student in Japan who volunteers as a caregiver for elderly and disabled people to fulfill a college credit requirement. We also follow the impact the vengeful spirits have on the Williams family, an American family who was forced to relocate to Japan for work-related reasons. (Portrayed by actors including KaDee Strickland, William Mapother, Clea DuVall and Grace Zabriskie)The acting is uniformly good, although (similar to the original) some of the characters are under-developed and serve as little more than canon- fodder. Gellar sticks out as the only character with much development, and she does a great job with the material. Strickland, Duvall and Zabriskie also do great work with their small roles, which unfortunately almost exclusively boil down to nothing more than a few lines of dialog before screaming in fear during the scares. The other big standout is Japanese veteran actor Ryo Ishibashi as a troubled police detective all too familiar with the curse of the house. While he only has a few scenes, he's a lot of fun and does command the screen quite well.The production is also very competent, although I find it to be more troubled than the original. Shimizu, who was given a larger budget for this film and obviously a lot more "toys" and sets to play with behind- the-scenes, does set up his scares quite well. And his visual direction is generally well put-together. However, I did find that he almost degenerated slightly at times. His original film was a much more claustrophobic, slow-burning thriller, and it made the scares land so much harder as a result. This film feels more sanitized to me in terms of direction. His camera-work has a lot less "character" to it, and does feel a touch bland at times. But I won't complain too much.The rest of the production is quite nice. The set and costuming is very natural, the photography is basic and works for the atmosphere, and the music from veteran composer Christopher Young is quite nice.I suppose my fundamental problems with this film, despite a strong production and a capable cast, is that it feels like an unneeded and slightly inferior remake. Outside of the Americanized casting (which really felt pointless- why not just cast Japanese actors, or set the film in America with American actors?), the film is strongly similar to the original, with the only major changes being a few scenes that were dropped or added. And due to the more sanitized direction and loss of the "character" of the filmmaking, it just feels like an inferior rehash too often.I'm not saying it's a bad film. It's a very decent remake, and I do enjoy it, but it just didn't quite live up to the promise and quality of the original film. I know I shouldn't be thinking about that and that I should rate this film on its own merits, but it's just too big an issue to ignore. And honestly, if the original film had these issues, I wouldn't hold it in nearly as high a regard.As it stand, this is a remake worth checking out, as it is still definitely one of the stronger remakes to emerge from the "remake craze" of the past 15 years. (Which was arguably kicked into high gear by the outstanding American remake of "The Ring") But it isn't one of the best. (Though thankfully it is exponentially better than any of the trashy Platinum Dunes remakes that have been polluting cinemas for almost a decade now)I give this a decent, slightly above average 6 out of 10. (I'd give the original a good/very good 8 out of 10) It's creepy, it'll definitely give you chills... it's just not as good as the original.

Review title: Nail in the coffin for Japanese horror
Review_body: I hate to throw out lines like this, but in this case I feel like I have to: the American remake of THE GRUDGE is by far the worst film I have seen in theaters in the last 5 years. There, I said it. And now that I have gotten that out of my system, please let me explain why."When someone dies in the grip of a powerful rage, a curse is born. The curse gathers in that place of death. Those who encounter it will be consumed by its fury." That is the premise of THE GRUDGE and I will admit it sounds intriguing. Unfortunately, the filmmakers take it no further. Those who encounter the "curse" are indeed consumed by its fury and that is all you get. You want more? Well too bad. Some critics and fans are pointing out that the sole purpose of THE GRUDGE is to scare you. The problem is that when there is no plot to speak of, creepy images and sounds can only go so far. Director Takashi Shimizu, pulling a George Sluizer and remaking his own original film(s), valiantly attempts to build atmosphere in the first hour  by repeating the same scene over and over and over and over. It pretty much unfolds like this:-person walks into house-something flashes by the camera and/or a strange sound is heard -person goes to investigate-sound starts to get loud-person sees a ghost-loud scream and/or cat screech-cut to blackBefore the audience is even given a hint of plot, this exact same scenario unfolds 5 times in the first hour. The first time was actually somewhat creepy. Each subsequent use became laughable as the film went on. By the time the end of the film rolled around, my friend and I were laughingly wondering if this scene would end "with a loud scream and a cut to black." We were never proved wrong.The film has no liner storyline, instead unfolding in a series of vignettes that leave the audience jumbled. I have no problem with non-linear storytelling when it is done right. The film jumps from time period to time period with no rhyme or reason. I haven't seen a movie in such a state since the opening of the theatrical version of HIGHLANDER 2. And this storytelling technique mars any sort of mystery that film could have possibly had. If you already know the ghosts have scared two characters to death, how is it shocking when their bodies are found in the attic? And why should we care when a detective tries to investigate the mysterious disappearances when we already know what happened to everyone?Obviously greenlit the second the American version of THE RING made $15 million its first weekend, THE GRUDGE is nothing but calculated imitation disguised as an actual movie. The scariest things about THE GRUDGE are that it made $40 million dollars its first weekend and some people consider it the "scariest movie ever made." I wonder what happens to those who get consumed by the fury of paying to see THE GRUDGE?

Review title: Can we have a plot, anyone?
Review_body: Japan has a somewhat unhappy love story with Western culture and Takashi Shamiza is part of that. They might be good in learning the techniques, but usually miss the humor and the irony. Just trying to make copies isn't enough, however good the copy might be.There have been less clever horror movies than this one. There are some jump scenes here that (almost) make you freeze, even if you know that such a scene is coming, but the plot isn't narrated in a good way. Sarah Michelle Gellar doesn't look scared enough and why does she have to go and check out the strange sounds in the house? Hasn't she seen any horror movies before? The script isn't logic, not even according to spooky film standards. This movie is just an average one in its genre, which means it's not a must. Not at all.By the way, it's strange finding that this has a PG-13 level in USA. People dies here, but that's all right for children to watch. Had there been any bare breasts, the R rate had probably been put on without discussion, even if the film was a total feel-good one. But maybe God wants it that way.

The Grudge is a very simplistic horror flick with very little in the form of a plot. Basically Sarah Michelle Gellar is a nurse who goes to work in Tokyo, she encounters an evil spirit that posses its victims and claims their souls, before moving on to the next victim. The premise behind this is that when a person dies a terrible death, it leaves behind a curse that in turn takes another life in a terrible way, and so on.I thought the film created a creepy atmosphere, and had some cool imagery, but overall it was just way to dull for long periods. I don't think its the Japanese style that caused it, because i really enjoyed the Ring; perhaps this is just an inferior film - yep, i reckon that's the reason.5/10

Review title: Barely mediocre; doesn't do justice to the original version
Review_body: The makers of this film should be butchers at a grocery store, chopping up meat. They're experts in the field of hacking up a good thing. In short, this is an unnecessary remake. Typical of its ilk, it fails to even approach the movie it imitates. The few moments that are effective are those culled directly from Ju-On, the original Japanese version. The classically creepy security video camera sequence, which ran chills down your spine in Ju-On, becomes in this homogenized remake no more interesting than watching a security camera aimed at a vacant parking lot. That's only one example of many scenes that are made bland.It's good the film is set in Japan; it gives a cultural edge to the story that makes the legend and the curse believable and formidable. But that begs the question: why redo it at all? The scenes inserted with Sarah Michelle Gellar and Bill Pullman, apparently intended to add some back story about the people who had once lived in the house, really add nothing to the actual focus of the story. Not to mention that Gellar's acting is, quite frankly, sadly lacking. She looked like she was doing skits from a Sesame Street episode, rather than a horror flick.If it's on free TV, then it's just watchable. However, for a real horror movie experience, the original version is far better.

After seeing the Hollywood remake of THE RING, I wasn't expecting much for this remake but I was pleasantly surprised by the end result. It doesn't add to much, there are no performances worth mentioning, the action is static and there is an element of predictability permeating the entire project but even with all these negative aspects, I still enjoyed the final result and THE GRUDGE works surprisingly well not as an all-out horror story but more as an impressionist styled horror.I'm usually bored with the current crop of PG-13 horror films. They're extremely anemic in quality and offer nothing new for the fading genre that's filled with unnecessary remakes and sequels. And THE GRUDGE would appear to fall into this category but it doesn't because the "deconstructed" direction works beautifully here. THE GRUDGE remake is a fine addition to the genre and I actually wish more horror films would take this impressionist approach, which is all too rare for something from Hollywood, than the SCOOBY DOO level spooks inflicting most horror films, which wouldn't impress a 5 year old.THE GRUDGE remake is well worth seeking out.

Review title: Just as good as the Japanese films (but with an ending rant against remakes of foreign films)
Review_body: Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar), an exchange student in Japan who is just beginning to do some social work, is sent to aid an elderly semi-catatonic woman, Emma (Grace Zabriskie), after her previous caretaker, Yoko (Yoko Maki), disappears. Karen soon learns that something is not right in Emma's home, and she attempts to "see how deep the rabbit hole goes".Maybe it's a delayed influence from the success of M. Night Shyamalan's films, but slower-paced, understated horror films are a recent trend. In some cases, such as Hide and Seek (2005), the approach works remarkably well, and in others, such as White Noise (2005), the pacing tends to kill the film. I didn't like The Grudge quite as much as Hide and Seek, but this is still a very good film--it earns a 9 out of 10 from me.The Grudge has a couple significant differences from other recent examples of that trend, however. One, it is well known that this is a remake based on the Japanese film series that began with Ju-On (2000) (in particular, it's extremely close to the first half of Ju-On: The Grudge, aka Ju-On 3, from 2003). Two, as with many Japanese horror films, the slower pacing here isn't so much in the realm of realist drama as with surrealism. As is also the case with a large percentage of European horror, The Grudge should be looked at more as a filmed nightmare.Director Takashi Shimizu, also the director of the five Japanese entries in the Ju-On series to date (the fifth is currently in production), and writer Stephen Susco have largely dispensed with linearity and are not overly concerned with logic or plot holes when it comes to the horror behind the story. The idea instead is to present a dreamlike sequence of scenes, with dream logic, where the focus is atmosphere, creepiness, the uncanny, and for many viewers--scares. How well the film works for you will largely depend on how well you can adapt yourself to, or are used to, this different approach to film-making (although admittedly, some of the seeming gaps are filled in by previous entries in the Ju-On series). Traditionally, American audiences consider as flaws leaving plot threads hanging and abandoning "rules" for the "monster". A more poetic, metaphorical, surreal approach to film isn't yet accepted by the mainstream in the U.S.However, even if you're not used to it, it's worth trying to suspend your normal preconceptions about films and give The Grudge a shot. This is a well written, well directed, well acted film, filled with unusual properties, such as the story interweaving a large number of "main characters" (which is done better here than the more episodic Ju-On 3), good cinematography, subtle production design touches (check out Gellar's clothes, which match the color and texture of the exterior of Emma's house, when Gellar first approaches), and beautifully effective horror material.Even though it is more slowly paced that your average horror film of the past, the pacing usually enhances the eeriness, and there is no shortage of bizarre events to keep horror fans entertained. The supernatural premise of the film is absorbing, and based on interviews on the DVD with Shimizu, have prodded me to pay more attention to Japanese beliefs and folklore. Although the most interesting subtexts would probably arise with a more intimate knowledge of Japanese culture, it's interesting to ponder why so many Japanese horror films feature scary children and adults who look like scary children.I subtracted one point for the film slightly veering into clichéd mystery/thriller territory with a "here's what really happened" flashback, but even that was fairly well done, and otherwise, this would have been a 10 out of 10.Now that I've said all of the above, let me finish with a mini-rant: It's not that I'm anti-remake, but it is ridiculous that U.S. distributors and studios feel that we need remakes of foreign films to make them appropriate for consumption. The original versions of these films should just be playing in U.S. theaters in wide release. There is no need to present an almost identical film but just substituting white American actors for non-white or foreign actors. Yes, The Grudge is a fine film, but ultimately, I'd rather see something original using this talent, and be treated to the latest foreign horror films--not just Japanese, but also Indian, Spanish, Chinese, etc.--at my multiplex. In the hope that someone with some pull at the studios reads this, it is also more cost-effective to do this, as (1) you can completely avoid production costs, and simply make domestic distribution deals from which you receive profit, and (2) you can make money off of fans like myself who otherwise pick up the foreign film DVDs in foreign manufactured or even bootleg versions.

Sarah Michelle Gellar is a nurse who visits a home which inhabits a evil spirit; the film is genuinely to over hyped by the media and cast. It has some genuinely good moments were you find your self jumping or the hairs on your back of your neck stand up. One thing that is very engrossing is the setting, Japan looks beautiful and captivates the audience with the story. The movie is directed by the same director who made the Japanese version which is a first for Hollywood. It has some similarities to 'The Ring' which is a little disappointment because people expected to find something a little different.Its not a film that will have you sleeping with the light on but has some decent scares.

Let me say right off... ...this film has some style in the technical portion of the "film style" category. That is why you're watching. And it has some kind of a story, one of which you want to find out about, which is why you continue to watch. Where this fails is that the story which seemingly wants to go somewhere, gets chopped up and mashed up and jumbled up and all you're left with is some style - which the average movie watcher cares little about anyway. I do notice style and that is why I gave this movie a very high rating. Yes, a 5 is a high rating for such a boring and non-entertaining film. And the 5 is for how much better a film about Americans in Japan this was than "Lost in Tranlation". Why this wasn't nominated for Oscars - who knows?And..it was probably because I picked up an interesting idea of why it was "The Grudge" -- but where it failed was I didn't get WHO the grudge was on. Everybody? Why would that be? That's why the film was a let down for me.I rented this film ... and the first time I ran it...I have to admit...I fell asleep. I finally gave it my full attention and found my mind wondering off. I was thinking questions like: "When was Godzilla going to show up?" and "Okay..so what does that have to do with anything?" The Godzilla thing was because I am so conditioned to see the big green guy in Tokyo to make it interesting - and the other was because I wanted so much for the film to go somewhere and it ended up -- somewhere.But that "somewhere" was a place I did not want to be.

Review title: This movie has always creeped me out
Review_body: 'The Grudge' isn't the best horror film and it isn't the scariest either, but there's something about it that always manages to get to me. From the very first scene, which is appropriately bizarre, to the last, 'The Grudge' is a very creepy movie and I can't quite put my finger on why.It is successfully unnerving partly due to the eerie and tense atmosphere that surround the whole story. There are a few jump scares but nothing that will scare the average horror fan, but it does have the ability to make you feel uneasy and does a good job at building and maintaining tension.'The Grudge' is nothing special or new and there are certainly scarier horror films out there, but it does have the ability to put the viewer on edge every now and then. I've seen it several times and it still creeps me out.

I will be completely honest with you, I watched this film with my finger on the fast-forward button pressed heavily so that the jumpy scenes wouldn't make me change my pants. I thought that this was one of the spookiest films that I have seen. Director Takashi Shimizu has done an excellent job remaking this film for American audiences. While some will argue that this is nothing more than just corporate Hollywood turning the cranks on audiences' wallets, I thought there was quite a bit of originality to this film. The institution of us seeing the demon or spirits before the characters do was something that I wasn't familiar with in other horror films. Normally, there is this big "jumping out of the darkness" scene that frightens everyone because they were not expecting it, but in The Grudge there was this element of "here I am" that frightened me more than most films do.Takashi Shimizu, the mastermind behind this film, also created the original Ju-on series that became extremely popular in Japan. This allowed his vision and purpose (with a larger budget) to continue. I enjoyed the fact that the original director was on board and that our American crew was in Japan. This took me away from the idea that this film was going to be nothing more than just a pro-America horror film. It took me to this unfamiliar place (building the fear) and showcased the talents of some unfamiliar/familiar American film actors working next to a complete Japanese crew. I thought that this kept the entire film grounded. It wasn't set in New York, there wasn't the scene of raw nudity at the beginning  there wasn't the normal American structure to this film because we were not in America  we were in Japan. This really helped me build the excitement and utter terror that I felt while watching this film. I was impressed.The acting, well, you don't go to a horror film expecting to see Oscar caliber acting. Gellar and Pullman knew that the horror genre is slowing coming into the limelight as a prominent figure in cinema (it was lacking for a couple of years there) and I think that is why they chose to do this project. Pullman wasn't anything to write home about, thought I was impressed to see him in this film. Gellar was the exact same. She did her part, collected her money, and went home. This wasn't what frightened me about this film. I didn't rent this movie to be blown away by the acting. I expected average acting and that is what I got. What I did go into this film expecting was to shake, shiver, and be frightened to turn off the lights after the film. That is exactly what I found. Takashi Shimizu did an excellent job of building that right amount of suspense, using amazing lighting, perfect sound, and some very freaky visuals. His knowledge and ability to bring us something new was extremely impressive and honest. Here is a director who was handed the money to make the film that he wanted, and while not everything was probably to his liking, it did open the door for more fans to enjoy his work. It also opened the door to more projects from his mind to be released. This could be the new face of cinematic horror, and I cannot wait to see what he has in store for us.Overall, I loved this movie. It was the exact level of fright that I was looking for. There were scenes that I never saw coming, there were elements that were unexpected and vividly raw, and it thankfully did not follow the ever-classic Hollywood horror formula. There was originality and emotion in this film that most horror directors do not give when dabbing in the horror genre. This was a great story, and I cannot wait to gather friends for a late night horror scream-fest featuring this film. From the opening scene, to the bus scene, to the opportunistic final moment, I had my finger on the fast-forward and I was scared. This did what it set out to do for me, and for that I can only praise this film! Grade: ***** out of *****

This, the latest in the trend of remaking Japanese horror films, is a chore to watch. I can only hope the original is better than this, because if the original resembles this remake in any way, it signifies that Hollywood really has too much cash for its own good. It defies belief that a film could make one feel that a good half of its running time is redundant or unnecessary, yet another twenty minutes of well-made footage would make it seem a lot more coherent.Sarah Michelle Gellar, much like her hubby before her, seems to feel her star fading with every second of this feature. In this effort, she plays a young exchange student I will refer to as Buffy simply because she never gives the character enough of an individual personality to distinguish it from the role that made her famous. So anyway, Buffy works for what appears to be a healthcare service for invalids in Japan. Her task is to clean up the mess that these invalids make on themselves, or so the scenes here imply.Strangely, the job she goes to in this film involves a grandmother who she finds with no sign of relatives around. The way the family has disappeared is hinted at, but only revealed after what feels like eight hours has gone by. Adding to the pace problem is the fact that the time seems to jump back and forth like a breakdancer, accompanied by more fades to black than even Peter Jackson resorted to in order to compensate for his poor storytelling skills. Indeed, cause and effect are very hard to follow in this film. So much so that the deaths seem inconsequential.What The Grudge does have going for it are some very creepy effects shots. The sequence in which the shadow creeps up to a CCTV camera and its eyes suddenly become visible is one of the few parts of the film that lives up to the hype. If only the ending shot didn't seem like such an obvious pilfering of The Ring. When the dialogue comes along, it is either indecipherable or just plain boring. It is never a good idea to bore your audience so thoroughly in the first hour of your film and save all the explanations for thereafter. In all fiction, there is generally an unspoken rule that if you fail to hook your audience in the first couple of minutes, you never will succeed.I gave The Grudge a two out of ten. If Sarah Michelle Gellar was hoping to resurrect her career with this first-draft mess, then she is sorely mistaken. You could find much better things to do with ninety-plus minutes, including the performance of housework.

I found the story not having much sense but scary enough anyway. Loved to see Sarah Michelle again after so long. She's good. Bill Pullman was pulling good strings too. I have a little grudge against the story though, that I hope will not grow on me...

I went to a screening of Takashi Shimizu's "The Grudge" at the USC Film School. The screening also included a question and answer session with the Screen Writer, Steven Susco, which was very cool. I met Steven-- he is a great guy and talented. As context, Susco really adapted the story of Shimizu's "two" "Grudge" movies that were produced in Japan. In this American version of "The Grudge", Susco attempted to fill in some of the narrative or contextual gaps that plagued the original films-- which were otherwise very popular and successful in Japan. Susco worked with Shimizu on the screenplay, and Shimizu also directs this remake of his original work. As part of the post-screening discussion, Susco related a story involving the reason for a certain character making a particular sound. We then all realized that reason was not revealed in the movie-- which was very annoying. Realize this is taken contextually. The other rather interesting insight, was the point of view that in Japanese horror movies as opposed to American, the protagonist does not necessarily find a resolution in Act III. That maybe an oversimplification of Japanese culture, but it is an interesting point. Even with it's shocking opening sequence with Bill Pullman as Professor Peter Kirk, and his wife played by Rosa Blasi, "The Grudge" does it's very best to scare from abrupt sounds and sights, and creepy imagery. The production values are solid. I suppose it is all scary, but the fact that you never have an emotional investment or affinity for the lead character is truly scary. In this the movie ultimately fails, because you never really care about Sarah Michelle Gellar's Karen Davis. Her Karen Davis is a university student in Tokyo who is caught up in perpetuating curse or "grudge". She is thrust upon this fate when she substitutes as caretaker of an ailing and aged woman, whose family are also Americans living in Tokyo. Shimizu and Susco interleave flashback and visions to explain some of what happened. In all of it, Gellar's Karen comes off as the complete "victim", and there is nothing really heroic in her actions. This is where "The Grudge" really didn't work for me. Granted this not really Gellar's doing, and more a pitfall of the story-- there is nothing courageous in the fight. And if hopeless was the intended message of this movie, then that is disappointing and not at all inspiring.

1 of the All-Time Truly Classic Horrors! A Top 50 Scary Movie Ever! The Grudge (starring Sarah Michelle Gellar) takes place in Tokyo, is really consistently creepy and it's also very chilling throughout with a lot of random scares plus it is so freaking freaky! Though The Grudge has a great dedication to sticking to its side characters with brilliantly drawn-out and interpret storytelling, Gellar's the star. SMG is so cute, a real spectacular woman indeed. Sarah is beyond gorg. The Grudge creates a circumstantially immersive storyline which allows for a no-need-to-wait-for-the-scares premise which I just love. They just keep coming. Similar to The Exorcist maybe. This is a classic movie which happens to be about how when a person dies in an absolute fit of rage then a curse is born at the place where that person's death occurred becoming a temple for a haunting, very dark spirit manifesting itself as tiny little disturbed, kinda cute but really paralyzingly spooky and terrifying Japanese kids with straight unkempt hair, ghostly, blurry white skin with crazy googly eyes and supernatural powers too. Actually, the curse consumes the spirit. The Grudge is really good and a really nice flick to watch to relax to. Like one of the best nighttime thrillers! The perfect date movie! Sarah Michelle's great! I love The Grudge! Sarah Michelle Gellar is ideal for this role and is so underrated in life and in the marvelous movie world! Words cannot describe The Grudge just go see it for yourself. It's not good to hold on to grudges, I love Sarah Michelle Gellar.(Bill Pullman, Jason Behr, KaDee Strickland, & Clea DuVall costar)

Japanese folklore features a wide array of different monsters, or Yōkai, but you'd never know from Hollywood movies. This remake is another horror about one of those black-eyed, ghostly kids crawling on walls, meowing and killing a score of one-dimensional characters. It has three or four unsettling moments - which worked better in the original Ju-On - but also a paper-thin plot and an utter lack of characterization. These are not people, they are walking props for the next jump scare.One of the few ideas which work well is how the film is not told in a linear fashion, but unravels slowly with strategically-placed flashbacks. This back-story is not particularly compelling, but at least the movie doesn't spoon-feed the audience right from the start.Watch the original, Nakata's Dark Water or Verbinski's The Ring instead.5/10
