Review title: Following the Japanese horror primer, the film presents flaws but it is ready to innovate western terror and teach us to enjoy the best of supernatural terror
Review_body: In the wake of the success of Samara and The Ring, Western interpretations for stories of vengeful spirits began to enter the agenda of American achievements, an industrial segment that is very interested in reformulating pre-established materials in other cultures. With The Grudge, filmmaker Takashi Shimizu brought to the United States some elements of Japanese horror, to later take them back to the Japanese environment. Let me explain: one of the questions posed by the filmmaker during the making of the film was the setting of the story, with American characters, but with dramatic development in Japan, a strategy to maintain its connections with its culture, after all, Shimizu didn't even speak English at the time and an interpreter followed the entire process in the studio.The Grudg eis a remake of Ju-On, a low-budget film directed by the same director Takashi Shimizu. It tells the story of Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar), a social worker who is on exchange in Japan with her boyfriend (Jason Behr). One day she is assigned to babysit a slightly autistic old American woman (Grace Zabriskie) when former assistant Yoko (kitten Yoko Maki) mysteriously disappears. The day she takes care of the old lady Karen sees a spirit that leaves her in shock and kills the old lady. From then on, the film is told with a fragmented narrative, with comings and goings in time, even showing how the old woman's family acquired the house in Japan, in addition to all the curse that surrounds the place.As we know, in the mythology of The Scream, when someone dies in a situation involving hate, a curse soon sets in. In this case, it is the house where those involved in the story live that served as the basis for all the evil in the plot, that is, the murder of Kayako (Takako Fuji) and Toshio (Yuza Ozeki), entities that constantly appear to claim the lives of those that cross their respective paths. From its discovery to the process that follows, the narrative comes back and forth, presents some fragmentations, kills a number of people along the way and ends its journey of horror with the unfortunate endings, typical of oriental productions, stories that in their translations into Western audiences, gain more explanatory clothes, with a view to meeting the demands of spectators on "this side" of the planet.Under the supervision of Sam Raimi and Robert Taport in production, the remake brought the aesthetic elements of the version that serves as a starting point, reworked features and developed with more resources. Thus, the film does not fail in its attributions as a language: Hideo Yamamoto's photography direction is effective, as are the sets and art direction, signed by Kyôko Yauchi and Tatsuo Ozeki, respectively, members of Iwao's production design team Saito. The visual effects of Kory Jones reinforce the scary character of Kayako and Toshio, entities that take on greater contours thanks to the formidable sound work of the production, from the score to the sound design. In music, Young, experienced, employs the necessary elements to allow us to deepen the "climate", reinforced with the sounds developed by the team of Paul N. J. Ottosson.When it comes to directing the western remake, The Grudge (The Grudge, 2004), Shimizu has a number of technical advantages at hand. Improved visual effects make scares more effective, as happened with The Ring (by Gore Verbinski, 2002). The non-linear narrative remains the same, the broad reach of the spiteful spirit. Many plans are even identical to the original ones, of course greatly improved and using as few special effects as possible. According to director Shimizu in the 'making of'that accompanies the DVD, the more you use digital effects that don't look real, the more the horror element is used, and that's absolutely true. Unlike The Ring, The Grudgeis not an overdose of visual effects, the ones that exist are necessary to the story. But the director is faced with a paradox: he needs to give space and value the star Sarah Michelle Gellar in a story that, as we have seen, has strength for not enshrining any character.Gellar doesn't seem to be able to fully live the experience of the film, the actress seems emotionless on screen, not thrilled in her escape and even less in the great peak of the film, contrary to what we ended up seeing in the supporting cast. Clea DuVall looks like a fish out of water in the city, but stars in a beautiful clash scene with Kayako, Ted Raimi has very little screen time, but has an exciting conclusion when faced with the spirit of Yoko, but the award for best sequel Damn it to KaDee Strickland, who shows more screen presence in her clash with Kayako than Sarah does in the entire movie, making us wonder what the movie would be like if the executives had reversed roles, given KaDee the lead role and Sarah the supporting role, perhaps this had been the crucial choice to correct the problems that exist in the film. Another great merit of the production is that it has kept its original antagonists, Kayako and Toshio are perfect as they are, and the choice not to Americanize the characters makes it even more engaging.Where there really is a problem is in the dramatic area, prior to development, because the conduction of the irregular material itself presents an excellent command of language by Shimizu, a filmmaker who, after the cinematographic and television versions of the characters in this universe, already knows exactly what do and where to do to make your movie gimmicky. The story just isn't more engaging because the dramatic needs and character profiles aren't very well developed. And when that happens, there is no catharsis. Without catharsis, we don't care who dies or lives. In the realm of terror, after all, it would be tedious to stand in front of a movie just to get sporadic scares, without any dramaturgical connection with the creatures that circulate before the story, a kind of representation of ourselves, human beings who can also be affected by unexpected and unexplained situations of fate, such as the great characters in the tragedies of our millenary tradition. In all versions of The Scream, evil prevails, realistically. There is no escape.This American adaptation is a very atmospheric, thought-provoking story with good horror moments, such as the shower scene, the scary elevator approach and the part involving a staircase, in addition to its technical trump cards, with studio "Japan" Well built by technical production team. What leaves the film with less impact is the randomness of its plot, as all versions of Kayako, whether Japanese or American, present the same narrative scheme. The holes also bother. Why do some characters access the house and not die like others? Is this a requirement aimed at our interest in fictions with all narrative schemes connected or does O Cry actually fail in its mission to build the dramatic elements of the story, perhaps relegated to give more space to scares and excellent dissemination of terrifying sound representations?The Grudge is not that movie with a beginning, middle and end, it reports an event in the house, but it does not seek to bring a little pattern that has a well-defined beginning and ending, on the contrary, the film does not have a beginning and no end, leaving it open enough space to have prequels and sequels that don't feel forced while tying together enough to work alone. Following the Japanese horror primer, the film is ready to innovate western terror and teach us to enjoy the best of supernatural terror, showing us that terror doesn't have to end with happy endings, leading us to a remarkable ending that proves that terror doesn't it needs scary images, screaming trails or scandalous scares to be really scary.

Here are just some of the reasons why I will never have to worry about the ghost in The Grudge actually causing me some harm or in anyway scaring me to an institutional type state. One: Whenever I hear a noise in a darkened creepy place, I never go to investigate. No way. No how. Hear something banging in the attic someone else can go look. Hear rumblings in the cellar you go. I have seen too many movies, read too many books and heard too many stories to put on a brave face and investigate just for the sake of securing my curiosity.Two: My cat never jumps in front of me making a very loud noise while a booming musical score peaks for dramatic effect. My cat is tame and hides from me unless it is hungry. It is not an evil cat. It doesn't snarl and I am sure that if there were evil in the house, the cat would be the first thing to hightail it outta there. My cat pulls a stunt like that one time, and it is off to the shelter where it can terrify another sorry assed stranger.Three: If I ever see something boarded up, it stays boarded up. Who am I to start tearing down something that someone obviously felt necessary to either stop something from getting in or worse, getting out. Hell, if I went home and my bedroom was boarded up, I am sleeping in the kitchen until such time as I can move. End of story.Four: If I ever see police tape around a house, I ain't going' in. Who do you think I am, Agent Mulder? Yellow tapes means something bad has happened and bad begat badder. It means stay out, and I tend to follow instructions rather well.Five: If I ever felt a hand coming out the back of my head in a shower, it is see ya' later bathroom! I wouldn't stop to pack a bag or call a friend. One experience like that and I am out the door never to return again. Whether I ever shower again or not is another story, but you can be assured that I want nothing to do with that particular room again. If I am in a strangers house, it's a 'don't call me, I'll call you' hasty exit. If I am in a foreign country, it is a direct route to the departures lounge and if (and God I hope not) it is in my own home, you are welcome to a viewing as there would be a FOR SALE sign in the front lawn within hours of the incident.With these five simple plans of action listed above, I can't imagine that I would be in the minority, and yet, these situations and character actions occur at random intensity in the off-putting new film The Grudge starring Buffy star Sarah Michelle Gellar. Based on the Japanese film Ju-On The Grudge, the Hollywood edition at least made us stand up and take notice when they announced that director Takashi Shimizu would remake his own film in English. Also interesting was the casting of Gellar not-so-fresh off her long television run as Buffy the Vampire Slayer and in need of a character stretch after playing Daphne in the two gawd-awful Scooby-Doo pics. With Ju-On being a slightly better than average ghost story, the recipe for success was there for the taking.That just makes it all that more unfortunate that the film would fail so miserably. Instead of scaring us or bringing anything new to the table, the movie falls on the laurels of past horror films and gives us a story shot out of sequence (for no reason that I can ascertain) that is more frustrating than thrilling. Gellar looks absolutely lost as the main character, Kare Davis and Bill Pullman has a useless role that was probably offered to him just so they could add another name to the marquee. On the terror meter, The Grudge also has very little to offer. The noises that the ghosts make are almost laughable and the blood and gore content was carefully plotted so that the PG-13 rating could apply.Being October and so close to Halloween, we can expect these types of films to show up in our local playhouses in the next few weeks in hopes of a box office bonanza. Too bad they didn't try to capitalize on a good story as well.

Review title: The U.S. remake is action-oriented, and pacier but is tamer than the original Japanese one.
Review_body: It seems to me that Takashi Shimizu was bound by certain constraints when he made this one. And it seems to me this film does not bear his mark whatsoever or do full justice to him.The original Ju-on had a much deeper story to it and is also more disturbing. If you haven't seen it, I suggest you do so NOW!The actors in the remake are the dumbest bunch of losers you could get with a dime. And I never did like Sarah Michelle Gellar.The C.G.I. effects run rampant in this version to the point of the film becoming a joke. I saw the U.S. version first and the original Japanese film much later. And boy did I feel CHEATED by the U.S. version. Plot: Karen Davis (Sarah Michelle Gellar), an exchange student who takes a job as a care worker to obtain social studies credit. Karen finds a closet that's been taped shut with cat-like noises coming from it. When she rips off the tape and opens the door, she finds a little boy (Toshio). The boy refuses to come downstairs so she asks him for his name. "Toshio," he says, in a toneless, eerie voice. Emma begins stirring and muttering in the other room. As Karen calms her, a dark shadow of hair emerges from a corner of the room...which soon reveals to be a face of woman covered by her hair. The woman's hair, which was covering her face, flies back to reveal the whites of her eyes. The irises roll into place and focus on Karen as she backs away in fright and then faints due to sheer terror. Karen wakes much later in Hospital. Karen tells her story to detectives, emphasizing the appearance of a boy. Over the next few days, she is constantly tormented by Kayako, in her shower, on a bus (while with Doug), etc. Frightened but determined, she starts research on the history of that house on the Internet by searching in Google. Eventually, she learns of the murders from the website of a Japanese Newspaper. On the same page, she also comes across the news of death of The American Professor, Dr. Peter Kirk. She now decides to know the entire history from Dr. Kirk's widow, Maria Kirk.... The U.S versions have 2 more sequels Grudge 2 and 3. Grudge 2 is again directed by Takashi Shimizu and is also a poor sequel to his original but adds more depth to the story.Grudge 3 is directed by Toby Wilkins taking Takashi Shimizu's place. Out of all the three Grudge films, Grudge 3 is the best one and has the most horror and is also the most disturbing one I have seen.Bottom line: SEE OR BUY THE ORIGINAL. IT IS A MILLION TIMES BETTER AND MORE REALISTIC. ALSO REMEMBER THAT THERE IS A SEQUEL JU-ON 2 (2000). If you want a COMPLETE COLLECTION, there are 5 Japanese FILMS and 3 U.S FILMS in all.

Review title: Just as good as the Japanese original - but this isn't necessarily a great thing
Review_body: The American remake of the Japanese Ju-on, this time know as The Grudge, is just as good as the Japanese original - but this isn't necessarily a great thing. This is because I found the original Ju-on very slow and not very scary - and this can be said about the American remake. I think the main reason for this is because Ju-On and The Grudge both has the same director, Takashi Shimizu. And with all due respect, though I never found Sarah Michelle Gellar to be a great actress, she does a good enough job in the main role as the American nurse Karen Davis living and trying to fit in a foreign country. This outing deserves a good enough 7 out of 10.If you really want to see a far superior Japanese-style psychological horror, then try The Ring.

*Possible Spoilers*A lot of people are going to argue with me on this one, but I thought 'The Grudge' was pretty damn scary. Granted, I'm kind of a fraidy cat, but I'm generally a wuss when it comes to scary imagery and general creepiness; and 'The Grudge' was full of that. Directed by Takashi Shimizu (who also directed the original Japanese version 'Ju-On: The Grudge'), 'The Grudge' is about a bunch of Americans living in Japan who all come across a house that is cursed, thereby cursing themselves. It starts with an American couple who move in with the husband's mother. After the caregiver for the invalid mother goes missing one day, Kare, (the horribly vapid Sarah Michelle Gellar) a nursing student, takes over for the day and the fun begins.'The Grudge' is told in a non-linear style, which is somewhat confusing. It is hard to tell how much time has passed between events. Also, there are a couple of things that are either left unexplained or inconclusive (the fate of the meowing child three years ago comes to mind). However, when you take 'The Grudge' for what it was meant to be, a spooky/scary film, it is certainly effective. Combining surprise scares with creepy imagery, Shimizu not only threatens to scare the pants off of the viewer, but threatens to have you wet them first. Unfortunately there were a couple of shots that were ruined by being featured in the trailer, such as the meowing kid and the now famous 'shower scene', but there were some things that surprised the hell out of me and caused me to take issue with going to sleep that night, especially in my bed. And that is probably the best thing about the film; as Hitchcock did forty years ago with 'Psycho' (and no, I am not remotely comparing 'Psycho' or Hitchcock to 'The Grudge' or Shimizu), ordinary or 'safe' places were no longer safe in 'The Grudge'. If the house is cursed, why should anything happen outside of the house? Right? Wrong.No, 'The Grudge' is not a bastion of superb film-making or even a great horror film, but it is effective and did what it set out to do  either scared some people (like me) or made a lot of people have a hell of a lot of fun at the movies (everyone else who saw the film with me). I feel that the mission was adequately accomplished, and therefore, I give it a 5/10.Shelly

Review title: This movie haunts me even to this day -- 9/10
Review_body: Crap, this movie haunted me for years. Make it stop please make it stop.4.5/5.

Review title: How ridiculous, even Sarah Michelle Gellar can't save this
Review_body: The Grudge is not a very good film at all, the plot is awful and without logic. Is it scary though? Yes, in parts there is some creepy imagery with the ghost girl (reminds me of the ring a bit, but not as good) and there's a couple of effective jumpscares. However, there's nothing frightening here that is memorable or different, it's all been done a hundred times before and despite there being a couple of creepy moments ultimately it disappoints in almost every department.2/10: Nothing special or new and there's not any interesting characters

Review title: Great Thriller That Gets It All Right
Review_body: The Grudge, starring Sarah Michelle Gellar, Bill Pullman and Clea DuVall is a great horror movie. Solidly directed by Takashi Shimizu (director of the original 2003 version) he does a great job of remaking his original horror for English audiences who have never heard of the original. Oh, and it's still scary.The plot isn't to hard to follow. Basically there is a house and anyone who enters is cursed to die. Which leaves us with social worker Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar) who is called to look after someone in the house. Things get bad when they are both attacked. From here there is a series of flashbacks, giving us an insight to the previous family.Well acted by the cast, this movie manages to deliver some pretty good scares, psychological and jump. The music score also adds to the horror of this movie. Anyone who likes Japanese horror like Ring or Dark Water should definitely watch this.Plus this movie has no CGI so it's a much more authentic watch.4/5.

Review title: Extremely confusing with no scary scenes
Review_body: The Grudge I'd have to put, would be avery weird horror flick with no plot, no character development, and rarely any scary scenes. I saw this movie almost two weeks ago and all I couldn't really understand the stupid movie throughout. It was confusing and everybody just kept dying. It's idiotic to put it in words. I saw it with my girlfriend and that was the only entertaining part of the movie, lol. Anyways, there could've been a better plot and scary scenes. There were some parts that you had to grab on to your seat and maybe jump once, but overall that doesn't make it scary and I don't believe I ever jumped in the movie. Could've been a lot better.Hedeen's outlook: 4/10 No Stars F

Review title: A Good American Remake Of The Classic J-Horror
Review_body: Karen, a young social carer, is sent to a home for her first assignment to look after a woman who suffers from dementia when Yoko, the woman's regular carer, fails to show up. Not long after she arrives at the house, Karen hears noises coming from inside a bedroom closet that's been taped up, so she opens it and finds a young boy and his cat. After contacting her boss, Alex, for help, she waits at the house, but it's during this time that an unspeakable horror manifests causing the death of the woman and sending Karen to go into a state of shock. After being released from hospital, Karen learns of the murders of Kayako Saeki and her son Toshio, and, along with Detective Nakagawa, she starts to realise that the vengeful spirits of the Saeki family somehow still reside inside the home and anyone who ventures into it may well become the next victim.The Grudge, as we all know, is an American remake of the Japanese hit Ju-on, and is, in my opinion, just as good. This version sticks pretty close to the original and a lot of the scenes are the same, but a few have been added for this version that weren't in the original i.e. you see more of what happens to Kayako & Toshio, and watch out for the exceedingly creepy Yoko.The story is told in the same non-linear style, but for some reason didn't seem as confusing. Also, being a Hollywood film, you'd expect a CGI-fest for the Kayako scenes, but again, like the original, these were kept to a minimum with actress Takako Fuji doing all her own creepy contortions & movements. This may be because it was the same director who done Ju-on, who knows, but it's good that CGI never over-shadowed the story.I enjoyed the original Japanese version, but to be honest I personally thought that this remake was actually the scarier of the two. There will be die-hard Japanese horror fans that will stupidly ridicule this version just because it's an American remake, but if you've not seen it just ignore the trolls and judge it for yourself.

Review title: "There is something evil here" - Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar)
Review_body: The Grudge is a very disappointing movie. I'm not going to beat around the bush, I didn't care for a single thing this film had to offer. Well except for.... well I'm not going to spoil anything for you. The picture is so close in feel and look of "The Ring" that it's almost laughable, and in the end it isn't anything close to as original and terrifying as "The Ring" was. This is just kind of a hunk of fall crap, that scores it's screams and scares from merely cheap shots. But the cheap shots aren't what really frustrates me about "The Grudge", it's the fact that they never explain what is going on and more importantly why. The filmmaker spends so much time flashing weird circus crap in front of you, that he forgets to add in an actual reason why all the supernatural events are happening. There are enough unfinished and unexplained events that take place in The Grudge to fill up a 500 page novel. The acting is nothing to shout from the hilltops with glee about either. Sarah Michelle Gellar phones in her performance like she's ordering a pizza, and the actor who plays the detective investigating the horror of the Grudge is in desperate need of a career change. Maybe he should try working at McDonalds instead of acting. The only decent acting we come in counter with during the entire span of the film is from Bill Pullman, who's in the film for only the first two minutes. In conclusion, The Grudge runs for 96 minutes, but if you ask me it seems like 96 days. I've never been so anxious in my life to get out of the theater and finish up my homework at home then I was when I went to see The Grudge. Don't waste your time or money on The Grudge. Time is better spent picking fluff out of your navel, then going to see Takashi Shimizu's latest travesty. Grade: D (screened at AMC Deer Valley 30, Phoenix, Arizona, 10/23/04)my ratings guide - A+ (absolutley flawless); A (a masterpiece, near-perfect); A- (excellent); B+ (great); B (very good); B- (good); C+ (a mixed bag); C (average); C- (disappointing); D+ (bad); D (very bad); D- (absolutley horrendous); F (not one redeeming quality in this hunk of Hollywood feces).

Review title: I Just Couldn't Grasp the Plot of this Film!
Review_body: The Grudge (2004, Dir. Takashi Shimizu) Story Karen Davis is an American Nurse move to Tokyo and encounters a supernatural spirit who is vengeful and often possesses its victims. A series of horrifying and mysterious deaths start to occur, with the spirit passing its curse onto each victim. Karen must now find away to break this spell, before she becomes its next victim.Actors OKwhere do I start? Sarah Michelle Geller was good I guess. I didn't really see her as being brilliant, but she wasn't terrible. I'm not familiar with Jason Behr, but his performance in this was actually quite good. Bill Pullman was amazing as ever. I'm not familiar at all with any of the Japanese stars, but they had good performances. Also, the two ghosts were portrayed wonderfully.Music The soundtrack wasn't very special. I had heard it all before in horror movies and made no lasting impression on me. Personally, the soundtrack was quite disappointing for me.Special Effects The special effects are actually the highlight of this film, as they use very little computer generated imagery as possible. The movements of the actors playing the ghosts and the makeup make them look more frightening that CGI would achieve in this film.Conclusion I usually enjoy horror and suspense filled films, but I really just couldn't grasp the plot of this film. I just couldn't follow the story easily. I lost track of the characters and what they did. To me, it just felt as if they were just throwing in random English and Japanese characters. I'll be interested to see what I think of it's sequel or even the original, but unfortunately 'The Grudge' did nothing for me."Sorry, did I wake you?" Doug (Jason Behr) "Bottom drawer."  Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar)

Review title: The Scariest Ghost Ever!!! Do You Dare?
Review_body: I've just finished watching the Hollywood adaptation of The Grudge 3, and decided to go back and write my review about this one, the first and best of the trilogy in my opinion.After I saw "The Ring" (another excellent adaptation of a Japanese original) I was certain that Samara was the scariest thing I'd ever seen. Then - I saw Kayoko, the evil ghost of The Grudge, and felt the same chilling terror. I've got to hand it to the Japanese film makers - they sure do know how to make bone chilling horror.It's not that The Grudge has a unique original story, or state of the art footage, or exceptionally impressive acting. It's a ghost story pretty much like any other. What it does have is one of the scariest ghosts ever seen on screen. If The Ring's Samara was simply terrifying to look at, the ghost of The Grudge also makes a terrifying sound I doubt you'd ever be able to forget. I'm a grown man of 27, and after watching this - I wished I wasn't sleeping alone that night. If that doesn't mean a horror movie has done its job, I don't know what does. If the horror loving generation before me had nightmares about the little girl from The Exorcist, I think myself and my peers will forever hold Kayoko as the scariest thing we've seen.I would recommend this movie to anyone who likes to really be frightened and enjoys an exceptionally well made ghost movie. Not for the feint of heart though!

Review title: One More Visit To Re-Make Hell...
Review_body: THE GRUDGE (2 outta 5 stars) Okay, maybe if I hadn't seen "The Ring", "The Eye", "A Tale of Two Sisters" or a zillion other similar Asian horror flicks I might have liked this one a little more. There are a few scary moments... but, for the most part, this movie is not gripping or compelling at all. We barely get a chance to care about the characters. Heck, Bill Pullman throws himself off a balcony in the first two minutes. A pity that Sarah Michelle Geller has to stick around for the full 90 minutes to show off her non-acting talent. Hey, I loved her as Buffy but some actors only have one good role in them. I fear that Ms. Gellar's talents have about run their course. None of the other actors are able to garner any audience empathy either. We know is that something bad is going to happen... over and over and over... but we don't really care about the people that it's happening to. I'm sure the original Japanese movie was much better than this. I should have known better than to try watching the inferior American remake first... even if it did have the same director. How is it that the WORST remakes are made by the original foreign directors themselves? (See also "The Vanishing"... the Dutch film, not the American.)

Review title: Good horror movie that doesn't really have any horror.
Review_body: 'The Grudge' simply isn't scary.Period.But just because a movie isn't scary doesn't mean it's not good.Examples of these include 'The Ring 2' and 'Land of the Dead'. The review written on the cover title says that this movie is even more frightening than 'The Ring'. I disagree on many levels.This movie isn't scary.It isn't even creepy or reasonably suspenseful.But I liked.I enjoyed it for what it was,and it was an entertaining movie with some memorable scenes and a good cast,which consists of Sarah Michielle Gellar,Jason Behr,and Bill Pullman.I have to admit that the original Japenese version was slightly better and had 1 jump scene.Overall,this non-scary flick is worth checking out.Also watch the sequel.

The Grudge remake in my opinion transcended the horror genre in the wrong direction, even though The Grudge itself was a quality film. Too often do we seen horror films with weak stories and its purpose is to execute its share of pop scares. The Grudge from what I remembered is the first film in theaters that had multiple pop-up scare scenes that made the viewer tense up. Now this technique in horror films is over-used and movies don't have general creepiness like 70's, 80's, and 90's films used. Unlike many of the horror movies I'm talking about The Grudge had a solid story, even if it lacked originality. The key to this film though was Sarah Michelle Gellar, a terrific looker and actress, who always delivers a great performance. The American Grudge is clichéd, an unnecessary remake, and started those pesky over utilized pop-up scares but it holds a special place in my heart, for being a movie that got me excited about horror movies.

Review title: Some creepy moments but it doesn't make a lot of sense
Review_body: The Grudge has some scary moments but most of the time its just to silly to take seriously. Takashi Shimizu directs an English language remake of his hit Japanese horror film Ju-On about a vengeful spirit that spreads like a virus through the victims murdered in a house. When a social worker (Sarah Michelle Gellar) accidentally lets the spirit out, it begins to haunt and kill all those who encounter it. The plot sounds scary and even with a good cast it didn't work out so well and its a mess of a movie. There's no real plot as there's just a scary scene follow by another and so on. The scary scenes are hit or miss with some actually giving you the chills while other making you laugh or fall asleep. Also most of the real scares are used in the preview so there's really nothing new. Sarah Michelle Gellar is pretty much the movies only saving grace and she does a good job though nothing special. Other cast members worth mentioning are Bill Pullman and this is his first feature film that I have seen him in awhile. Clea DuVall is in the film for about twenty minutes so she's not very memorable. KaDee Strickland and Jason Behr are also in the film but aren't worth mentioning. Director Takashi Shimizu does a decent job, but hopefully the sequel will make more sense and they will spend more time on writing it. Japan itself looks beautiful in the film and I'm glad that they kept the story in Japan. After watching this movie I don't know if its worth checking out the original though since the IMDb rating on this site for it isn't very impressive. Rating 5/10, now that its out on video its worth a look just don't expect too much from it.

Review title: Not as good as the Japanese original...
Review_body: I found The Grudge to be nowhere near as the Japanese original. The story is about a girl called Karen Davis who is an American nurse who moves to Tokyo she arrives at a house in Tokyo. The house is possessed by a violent evil that destroys the lives of everyone who enters. she comes into contact with a supernatural spirit who is vengeful and often possesses its victims. several horrifying and mysterious deaths start to occur, with the spirit passing its curse onto each victim. this curse causes its victims to die in the grip of a powerful rage. After the nurse Yoko fails to show up for work, Karen is asked to check on Emma an American lady, who recently moved to Japan with her son, daughter and daughter in-law Jennifer. Whilst inside the house, Karen is alarmed by Emma's unusual behaviour, She is mute and sleeps through the day. When she enters her home, she finds an elderly American woman, Emma, who is lost in a catatonic state while the rest of the house appears deserted and. As she is seeing to the old woman, Karen hears scratching sounds from upstairs. When she investigates, she is faced with a supernatural horror more frightening than she could ever imagine. I found this to be a good film in the end.

Now I have seen the original and feel the first 45 minutes of the original are up there with some of the best directing of any horror movie ever made. The tension building is ingenious, leaving little details to be figured out by the viewer, but sadly the movie falls into satirical mediocrity soon after. I still rated the movie a 7 overall.The remake I went into knowing they would really speed things along and anything I loved from the original would be different and that's okay, it's to be expected, but this movie simply failed at building tension, and failed at being even remotely scary.It's like they spent all their energy trying rather then doing that it completely misses the mark.For remakes of Japanese movies, The Ring was exceptional but it had all the right people directing, doing effects, casted, etc.. it all just worked, and I am in love with the entire original Japanese series of Ring,particularly Yukie Nakama in Ring 0.Anyways, this was a rather mediocre film, definitely a failed remake. I dread them remaking A Tale of Two Sisters, the original is a masterpiece.All the CGI in this movie made it feel unreal, and more like Casper the ghost then an intensely powerful grudge stalking a house.From this movie I get this impression they tried TOO hard to Americanize it and in doing so sort of disrespected the culture involved. I wish more people would watch original Asian cinema, The Ring series, Uzumaki, A Tale of Two Sisters, Some movies simply should not be remade, because you're changing elements, elements that changed can really throw off all the chemistry to a story, turning it into a mockery of the original folklore.I am not saying I'm against cross culturization, but come on, if you want to bring the cultures together, make a NEW story about an American in Japan not constantly doing remakes.Sometimes remakes are good because they introduce us to the original films we may never have seen otherwise, but it's all in the way it's formulated. And the Grudge originally was a bit silly, but the remake lacked any of the original's tension and only held to the silliness. Every time the Grudge builds it falls flat and leaves me disappointed.In the original, we see near the beginning the woman cleaning the house then she takes a nap. A eerie gust of wind comes along and blows her things over in complete disarray, silently we understand why the house is so messy and why they don't even bother cleaning, it's because the Grudge destroys any semblance of organization once established. Sadly this movie doesn't confront such fascinating details in as intelligently a fashion.Things jump out at you but in the theaters no one screamed, they laughed,because the timing was wrong, just wasn't scary.The Grudge simply doesn't deliver. I say save your money, watch the original Ring series, watch A Tale of Two Sisters, watch Battle Royale, watch Inner Senses, watch The Eye... avoid The Grudge.

Karen is an American nursing student in Japan. When a catatonic woman's home caretaker goes missing, Karen fills in for her to get some school credits. She arrives and learns what the audience already knows: there is something evil lurking in the house.The American version of the Japanese "Ju On" is an entertaining and quite scary haunted house horror flick, but overall I left the theatre feeling unsatisfied.Comparisons to the American film The Ring seem inevitable before stepping foot in the theatre, as The Grudge is the first (in what could be a long line of) American-remade J-horror films since the huge success of The Ring. However, upon viewing The Grudge, such comparisons are fair and perhaps telling.The movie is scary, but mostly because it relies upon quick and consistent scare tactics (many shamelessly lifted from Ringu and The Ring) rather than by creating an unsettling atmosphere--which made the others movies so successful as horror films. That isn't to say that the scares in The Grudge aren't effective. The images are indeed creepy and caused me to scream-and-jump almost every time. However, there is hardly a build-up or engaging mystery to the back-story of "the grudge", and when it is revealed to Karen and the audience, it is really difficult to connect it with the terror we are witnessing.The movie doesn't offer much in terms of characterization, which is an important element in ghost stories. The audience isn't given much of an opportunity to sympathies with our leads. What we have is a handful of Americans living in Japan and being terrorized by two (croaking and meowing) Japanese grudge-holding ghosts. And their hair. From Kwaidan to Ringu, it seems that the female ghost with long black hair has long been a theme of Japanese horror movies. I am assuming that this is a cultural thing that I do not understand, as I am very unfamiliar with Japanese culture. In the American The Ring, most traces of Japanese culture are removed and the movie has no Japanese characters or mythology. Samara and her dark black hair covering her face are horrifying across the board, due to great effects and even better atmospheric build up. The Grudge goes right for the money shot: Look! She's being haunted by BLACK HAIR! The basic plot of The Grudge is apparently rooted in cultural mythology, but it is not expanded on in the film. It is briefly mentioned by the Japanese detective, who I found to be the most interesting character in the movie. The Japanese director (Takashi Shimizu, who helmed the Ju-On series), has said something to the effect of needing to change many elements of the original that would not appeal to American audiences--most obviously, by switching to an American cast. While it is obvious that changing the lead cast is for language and financial reasons, I still find it curious that it consists of three separate groups of people (Karen and Doug, the Williams family, Peter & Maria), all of which are American. Some are getting along fine with their jobs, studies and the culture, others are experiencing "lost in translation" isolation.The Grudge has a fair share of scares, and it will have you jumping out of your seat. But by the end of this movie, one can't help but wonder about the underlying narrative about Americans and Japan, especially with regards to the current trend of Hollywood dishing out the dough to remake J-horror films.My rating: 5/10

Review title: It Was Just Not That Good (SPOILERS)
Review_body: SPOILERS I always love a good and terrifying horror film. I am not a big fan of Japanese horror films, but I was interested in watching this. It is based on a Japanese horror, I know, but it had a solid cast and looked like a really scary horror film. Well, it was not a good movie. Sure, it had some solid scares but it was way too boring. I mean, there was barely any dialog. I did not find this entertaining. It was also just too weird, in my opinion. I also do not think it is a very good idea to make a remake of a Japanese horror film. You will see what I mean when you watch this.Here is the plot of this movie. A nurse named Karen, hey, isn't there a nurse named Karen in Halloween 2? Anyway, a nurse named Karen has to take care of a woman that lives in a house in Tokyo, Japan. When she goes there she finds out that the woman named Emma is basically unresponsive to anyone. She also realizes that there is a creepy little boy with a psychotic moaning noise in the house. Emma dies. Then Karen's boyfriend comes to the house. The ghost kills her boyfriend. Karen sets the house on fire. She escapes alive, but at the hospital her boyfriend's body is making a moaning noise.Overall, this is a boring thriller. There is a lot more characters in the movie but I just was not paying a lot of attention because it was so boring. The moaning noise that little boy makes is scary at times but it gets really annoying really fast. The sequel for this movie was pointless. I mean, was there really need for a sequel? What is even worse is that they are making another sequel. Enough about the sequels, though. This is a pointless and sometimes scary film but it does not succeed as much as it's Japanese counterpart.4/10Recommended Films: The Grudge 2.

The americanized version of this Japanese story is entertaining, scary enough and interesting, but that's about it. The thing that annoyed me the most about "The Grudge" was the lack of background; after you're finished with this movie you're left wondering a whole Lot of "whys" about it. Have this background info been more "hearty" it would have made me feel more pleased about this movie. For starters, I'd say a title like "Grudge" doesn't really apply here; sure, a "ghost" of sorts is p****d off, but usually there's some explanation as to WHY is this "ghost" p****d off. Shades of other superior films like "THE CHANGELING" and yes, even the Americanized version of "THE RING" come to mind right away. The acting is good and the overall mood of the film is actually chilling (my grading goes primarily because of these technical achievements!), but the rendering of this story for American (or should it be, "western" audiences) is a bit contrived and leaves a lot to be desired. THE GRUDGE is surely scary and it IS an enjoyable movie. It's just that some story elements are not fully explained and it makes you feel like you're watching an "alternate" version of THE RING!

Review title: Why should there be a remake?
Review_body: It's hard to understand why 'Ju-On' should be remade... especially when you are appointing the same director. "The Grudge", if considered as a single unrelated venture, not awful. There are some scare moments, if one calls them scary. The story is straightforward, though not clear enough grasp or interesting enough to impress. I haven't seen the original. But I assume if a director is given chance to make basically one film twice, the second one should be better. In that case I'm not going to look for the original one in DVD parlors.The cast are not bad. Sarah Gellar is fine, and that guy who played the Japanese detective is also impressing. I liked the director's idea of showing enough flashbacks in the middle whenever necessary. But Pullman's action in the beginning or how Gellar saw the actual thing in that time-travel kind of way remained unexplained. But one gotta respect the fact that these horror films always remain unexplained, perhaps.One more thing I couldn't understand. I don't know if it's a co-incidence or not. I saw two Japanese horror remakes -- 'The Ring' being the other. The basic facts are more or less the same. And some features of showing horror too. I suspect there are more Japanese horror Hollywood remakes on the way, and this is not a good sign. Why is there such lack of subject matter?

Well, it just goes to show that I'm not easily scared, but my company was, so I guess the film did what it intended to do well. On the other hand, it really lacks any sort of meaningful story. It's almost like a short film that got bloated to full length.The aesthetics of the film were pretty good, although the editing was just too jagged to keep me interested in all the stories. It's almost like Takashi Shimizu (the director) decided to be like Quentin Tarentino, except with a case of ADD. It sort of disperses the suspense (and I think it also is a clever way of hiding the lack of story and also getting a chance to put in more suspenseful "yarr ghosties!" scenes).If you're the type that scares and want to be scared, this is a good place to go for that. It looks good, it sounds good, but it's kind of empty in the end. It's not terrible, but just not particularly impressive. 6/10.

Review title: Starts out well then goes flat
Review_body: The Grudge is another one of those films based on a Japanese that somehow makes millions and millions of dollars at the box office and makes little sense. I like Sarah Michelle Gellar in this movie, but the film hits the same beat over and over again. Someone is introduced, they go into the haunted house, and something bad happens to them. It is scary the first couple of time, but then it gets tiresome. The last half hour of the movie is particularly a letdown as the climax falls flat. Trying to tell the story out of chronological order (a process I generally do not like) just makes the movie more convoluted. This movie has delusions of grandeur in my opinion when the plot is basically an 80s slasher flick with less blood and gore. Slightly better than The Ring (which I found completely incoherent) but I think we can put a stop to importing Japanese horror films.

Review title: Not as good as Japanese version of Dark Water or the American version of The Ring.
Review_body: At least The Grudge tried to be scary, and it succeeded to an extent. It was cheesy and it did use the tiresome little-kid-ghosts-who-kill cliché, but there was still something about it that beat out a lot of wannabe horror movies I've seen. Maybe the Asians do understand ghost stories better than the Americansas can be argued using (the original) Dark Water and The Ring. Maybe the movie was a little more entertaining and scary than I've seen in a while. I don't know.All I know is The Grudge does everything wrong except the core ghost story, which redeems it. I wouldn't call it original or different, but it is unnerving. Also, the content for a PG-13 movie is no different than a lot of R-rated ghost movies like The Orphanage, which this far surpasses.Maybe in the end I liked The Grudge more than I realize. It tried to use the full potential it had, and maybe that's the reason I don't give it the lowest possible score.2/10
This is the most confusing and NOT SCARY film. I struggled through it. Just couldn't get my grudge on.

It's funny because I saw this film before years ago, but I don't think I cared much for it, nor did I remember most of it. I watched it a few days ago and I liked it a lot more. Was it because I watched the director's cut? It's quite possible. Here we have a Japanese haunted house tale except that the few ghosts (or spirits) are quite belligerent and will haunt (and hunt) you even outside the house. Originally a Japanese film, it was remade for American audiences with some American actors and a bigger budget. It does still take place in Japan, has the same director as the original and several of the same actors. Those are anomalies in themselves, perhaps explaining why it's so different than your usual American horror film. There's not much gore to speak of, and the movie often cuts just before the "kill", but the film is probably better because of it, because it leaves more to your imagination. There's a general feeling of uneasiness and creepiness permeating this film.It relies a lot on smart sound effect work, seeing scenes from different viewpoints and setting up the scares slowly. It can be just a face, but the surprising way it appears is often freaky. Some of the most memorable, most unnerving scenes for me involved a simple bus ride and watching a black and white video footage. Praise should be given to most of the actors who looked genuinely scared (especially Sarah Michelle Gellar) without even screaming. In fact, for them, and perhaps the viewers, it's so horrifying, they can't even scream. There's also an interesting mystery going on about who the spirits are, giving them background and personalization. I prefer that to faceless anonymous spirits. The structure is non-linear but not too tough to understand and will make subsequent watchings more enjoyable. I think the only real not-so-negative criticisms I could give it would be that the flashback sequences were sometimes awkwardly handled and too convenient (as in, why now?). The little boy can also become silly instead of creepy depending on your mood. I think that as far as Japanese horror remakes go, I preferred the Ring, but the Grudge is also quite worthy. The best praise I could give this film is that I keep thinking about it and of what might be lurking in unexpected places, especially at night in the dark.Rating: 7.5 out of 10 (Very good) P.S. The commentary is well worth watching in part because of the good spirits of the Japanese creators doing it (it's subtitled in English, but you hear their Japanese voices and laughs).

The Grudge is led by the star of Buffy, Sarah Michelle Gellar, in a surprising twist on the standard-issue haunted house movie. The plot follows Gellar as Karen Davis, an American carer employed to take over the care of Emma, a dementia sufferer. At the house, Karen discovers strange and supernatural occurrences. The house, as it turns out, is the site of a curse that lingers in a specific place and claims the lives of anyone that comes near.The film genuinely surprises as one is never quite sure where it is headed next, all the while involving the viewer in a freakish, unforgettably nightmarish ride... with some of the most unnerving imagery and soundscapes I've seen on screen. The film is an Americanized version of a Japanese film, similar to "The Ring." Whilst not being as original, it has plenty of jumps and genuine creepiness. The precision of slow revelation is the focus, and Shimizu makes good use of it to cloak a simple plot and vague characters in enduring suspense. Fans accustomed to noisier, more graphic jolts may be impatient with The Grudge's measured insidiousness. Others may find it refreshing, curiously so. The bottom line is, The Grudge would have been ruined in the hands of a typical Hollywood American director.

SMG doesn't seem to have much luck with movies - apart from Cruel Intentions I can't recall a single memorable performance, and sadly she continues the tradition here. OK, it's a thousand times better than the abysmal Scooby films, and in places almost on a par with her portrayal of Buffy. She has real talent and I don't entirely blame her for this lack of success - it must be down to her choice of projects. Why on earth she signed up for a sequel to this is baffling - she doesn't need the money. Maybe she needs to hire new people, and get some decent advice.Perhaps the story and direction lost something in translation, and perhaps the Japanese have different expectations. The Grudge displays a definite class in some areas, but is let down by a disjointed and confusing construction. There are 3 or 4 genuinely scary moments - but they are just moments, and the overall effect is further diluted by some really dreadful, laughable attempts at horror. In places beautifully framed and lit, it is just not dark enough to be create a scary atmosphere. The effects are appalling, and the whole 'hair & eye' thing is really, sickeningly naff.At times I wondered if the cast actually knew where the scares were meant to be coming from, and when there were some real frights the reactions were confusingly mild. This movie starts well but after about 2 minutes you've seen the best - from there it's all downhill. There are glimpses of something much better close to the surface, and with a bit of tinkering this could be good. But as it stands it is unacceptably poor, and I wouldn't go out of my way to watch it ever again. Sarah I do love you but, come on - get your act together!

Review title: The Grudge Another Disappointing Horror Remake
Review_body: The Grudge is another disappointing horror remake that joins a long line of them being re-imagined these days if you want to call it that. Director Takashi Schimizu does a good job of giving the audiences some creepy moments but the lack of real scares, suspense, and character development besides Gellar's character is what weighed it down the most. The cast however are good in their roles but not memorable including Sarah Michelle Gellar, Jason Behr, Clea DuVuall, and Bill Pullman but most of them are developed enough because they're not in it much. The rest of the cast okay in their limited screen time. This movie did start off weird and there were some creepy moments but the bad outweighs the good in this one. There was a little suspense but there should have been more and there weren't any real scares because this film didn't frighten me at all. The dialogue wasn't the greatest at times either and some characters made stupid decisions but then again what do I except this is a horror movie after all so just go with it. Overall The Grudge was disappointing because I hoped it would be a good but it ended up being a major letdown. The Grudge is creepy at times with a little suspense and good performances by the cast for the most part but this horror thriller could have been a lot better.

Rating: 12.5/5 [5/10]Soooo, I'm pretty big on the Ju-On series and really enjoyed all 8 films that the original version has to offer. I didn't ever think too much about the American remakes and decided to go ahead and completely ignore them for my life. Then I realised I had seen this first 2004 film, had absolutely no memory of this, and my "must complete all collections I start" issues kicked in.So here I am, binging a series I really hated for most of my life and originally gave a 3/10 [1.5/5]. After re-watching this, I noticed a lot of little nuances.Americans panicking and speaking in English before they realised they had to speak Japanese - this is a big thing that actually happens for most people; when scared or hurt, they'll default to their native language.
The horror aspect was bad, but it wasn't too bad. There were some moments that did make me jump and caught me by surprise.It wasn't too bad at all, actually. Still a very average film but, average is decent for a film of this caliber. I'm actually looking forward to 2 & 3 and the 2020 remake.

I'm always wary of remakes.More often than not, they're never as good as the original. I'm even more skeptical of foreign filmmakers who agree to remake their movies for an American studio. It sounds like a good idea to keep the original director, but just as Hong Kong filmmakers John Woo, Ringo Lam and Tsui Hark were forced to water down their action film-making when they came to Hollywood, foreign directors seem to lose their artistic integrity when remaking their films for Hollywood. Remember what happened when George Sluizer remade his 1988 film, "The Vanishing," for American audiences five years later? He turned a brilliant psychological thriller into a pedestrian Hollywood film and tacked on a happy ending, to boot.Nevertheless, I was eager to see what Japanese director Takashi Shimuzu would do with his remake of "The Grudge." There are two things initially going for this film. One, despite starring American actors, the story remains in Japan, thereby creating potential to tap into differences in horror mythology. Two, "The Grudge" remake opens with a doozy of a scene involving Bill Pullman.Alas, after that, there's really nothing much more to this film. Part of the problem could be that while Shimuzu's original was rated R, the remake is PG-13. Japanese horror films depend much more on creating an eerie atmosphere than loading up the gore. It's a great device, since they often prey on our fear of the unknown.But this film does not tap into the cultural differences between America and Japan and does not delve into the psychological traps that each culture's folklore creates. True, there are some genuine shocks in this American remake. But none of the characters is very interesting and, despite its origins, "The Grudge" turns into just a typical Hollywood horror with characters doing dumb things like sticking their heads into dark crevices to find out if there's anything in there. You want to hazard a guess as to what happens? There's also a character who winds up in an office stairwell, hears strange noises and promptly yells, "Is anyone there?" In the history of horror films, has there ever been a reply to that question?The biggest disappointment with "The Grudge" is that Shimuzu and screenwriter Stephen Susco reveal the story's terrifying monster early. Once we've seen it, there's no more reason to fear it. So while the characters all seem scared of it, for us, the terror's more laughable than scary.The nonlinear structure isn't distracting, but it seems more gimmicky than anything else. And the horror scenes appear to work outside the story - you could easily shift the frightening scenes around in any order and it wouldn't make any difference to the plot or film. The movie's most terrifying moment belongs not to Sarah Michelle Gellar's Karen, but to KaDee Strickland's Susan Williams as she's tracked from her high-rise office to her apartment."The Grudge" spends so much time pretending to be scary that it loses much of its edge. The monsters aren't all that frightening once we see them and, after a while, I just wanted Gellar to turn into Buffy Summers. She wouldn't have put up with all this nonsense. She'd have just kicked the crap out of them. And that would have made the film a lot more entertaining and enjoyable.
Look it's not the scariest or fastest paced horror flick you'll ever see but for a 20 year movie it's fairly solid in this genre.

The latest trend in Hollywood seems to be remaking Japanese horror movies. I haven't seen the original "Ju-On: The Grudge", so I can't comment whether the American "The Grudge" movie does justice to the original. I'm sure however that it doesn't do justice to anything else.Bluntly put, this is not a very good movie. Just about every aspect of it feels fairly uninspired, boring, and uninteresting. Horror movies don't necessarily need a strong plot or characters, but this movies sets an all time low for both categories. It's basically about a number of rather dull characters that enter a haunted house and die one by one. Neither the reason behind all the deaths nor the ways in which they occur are very interesting: the plot is very obvious and devoid of any really interesting revelations of twists, and moves at a very slow pace to boot.This might still be OK if the movie at least manages to be scary. In my opinion, it doesn't, although I can imagine that many other will find it scary (it's a matter of taste). There are lots of "surprise scares" but most of the times, they're predictable (a single character enters a dark attic...yeez, I wonder what's going to happen now), and while "The Grudge" certainly manages to create a dark atmosphere, there's no real feeling of suspense since you likely won't care much about which character lives and which character dies, and since it's painfully clear that they're going to die anyway.Truth be told, the movie does some things right. Sarah Michelle Gellar does a good job, and the rest of the cast is OK as well. The camera work is also very good. Buth no amount of good acting and technical expertise can make up for what is essentially a nearly plot less and rather pointless movie that relies solely on a number of supposedly scary moments.** out of ***** (add one * if you scare easily)

I finally got around to watching this remake of the grudge. I thought it was boring and it wasn't scary. Sarah Michelle Gellar plays the lead in the remake but she don't have alot of screen time tbh. I can't believe they done two more sequels. Seems pointless to me. One time watch for me. 3/10 very flat remake and ending

The Grudge will make you jump out of your skin, to say the least. It IS scary in the extreme - oppression and death curses every scene in this absolute pant-wetter of a movie. But in favour of letting the audience wet themselves, they have just thrown away any cares about plot, real interest or character - and that is why The Ring was far better. The ending made little sense, serving just one purpose - to make a film that was 100% horror and 0% plot. None of it comes together, and from what people have said, I don't think the sequel will explain a great deal more. It's not a great movie, but there are enough genuine scares and interesting elements of Japanese culture to warrant a purpose. Lots of effort went into making this film as the special features on the DVD point out - the actors and director had to communicate even though the cast were all Americans and the director was Japanese - which made for a lot of complications and everything had to be translated. Which may explain why the acting wasn't hot. But the scares certainly were, and though this film won't make you shiver in bed all night long like The Ring (which was helped by the fact it was plain WEIRD), it will at least make you jump out of your skin every five minutes. The plot doesn't make sense, but the film, on the whole, grips. Recommended. 7/10

Review title: Fun J-horror remake with great scares!
Review_body: After the success of "The Ring" every studio was looking to cash in with their own Japanese re-make. Columbia Pictures and Sam Raimi's Ghost House Pictures set out to make an American version of "Ju-on" or "The Grudge". They got the director of the original film Takashi Shimizu to do the re-make and all things look great on paper for and epic film. Unlike "The Ring" which relocated its story to Seattle, "The Grudge" takes place in Tokyo. When "Americanizing" a foreign film something is always lost in the translation. The cultural gaps and customs are just too big to overcome. "The Grudge" does alright in this respect but is still comes up a little short. First let me say that the movie really is scary and has a great atmosphere to it. The fact that it takes place in Tokyo is a big plus and adds to the whole experience.The myth goes: When some dies in the grip of a powerful rage, a curse a born and consumes everybody who come in contact with it. This is explained in a prologue. Sarah Michelle Geller plays Karen and exchange student who lives with her American med school boyfriend Doug, played by Jason Behr. Both lead roles are miscast with Behr's part being completely useless. Gellar is no stranger to horror and she does a serviceable job, but they could've found someone better. In a bit of good casting famed Japanese actor Ryo Ishibashi plays Detective Nakagawa who investigates the cursed house. Ishibashi, played the male lead in the horror classic "Audition".The story is structured in a way that shows how each character has encountered the house. Starting the family who bought it for there invalid mother Emma. We see what happens to her kids, then her care takers Yoko, then Karen. They all encounter the vengeful ghosts of Kayako and Toshio. The curse is an unstoppable force of pure rage that seems to literally scare people to death. Karen researches the house and the curse and we find out the history of the family that use the live there. She and the Detective aim to somehow stop the curse, but Kayako and Toshio are some pretty bad ass ghosts that are not nearly ready to give it up. The ending gives some decent scares but is pretty uninspired and ambiguous. The movie spawned a few sequels that didn't even stand up to the low standards set by the original.

Review title: The beginning of a franchise that inspired many movies. Created its own kind of horror movies. Recommended.
Review_body: Metaphysical horror movie. Grudge was the beginning of a great franchise, from which many more films were inspired. Like franschise Rings, Grudge relies on Japanese films (Ju-on, 2000) and with its unique concept and style, they are a distinct kind of horror films in themselves. So according to tradition, if a violent death occurs, then the wrath of the victim will fall on the scene as a curse that will haunt everything in that area. The film is quite well-written, with very good effects, intensity and suspense from start to finish and does not get boring at all. The script, the directing, but also the actors were all excellent and are definitely among the most classic films in the genre, but also a reference film. Definitely in the top recommended horror movies.

Review title: One of the funniest movies I've ever seen...
Review_body: **SPOILERS BELOW**What's really sad is that Sam Raimi and Co. were REALLY trying to make a horror film, to scare us. I was anything BUT scared at this clichéd 'horror' film. You'd think that by now people would know the formula to a horror film: when the music intensifies something's about to happen. Some idiot is busy snooping around where they're not supposed to and ends up in a dark, secluded area...guess what?? Something's about to happen. You think seeing scenarios like these time and time again will instantly let on that someone's about to die, but no, I had to be in a theater with a bunch of silly teens who scream at every little thing. This movie could've easily went by another name: 'Follow The Trail'. What was the deal with having garbage on the floor and everyone just following the paper trail to their death? Yoko dying was one of the funniest moments in movie history, along with Bill Pullman falling from his balcony without hesitation LMAO. 'Honey, you're up early'...he slides off the railing head first to the ground LMAO! Too too funny. The only semi-smart person in this film was the cop, when he finally went to the house with 2 cartons of gasoline ready to burn the cursed house down. Too bad he was stupid to fall for the curse's trick. I don't know why he, or anyone else, didn't do that 3 years ago when the case first opened. And what was with the boyfriend? He saw what Gellar was researching, about people getting killed in that house and whatnot, but a light-bulb goes off in his head which tells him to go there by himself, hands swinging with NO weapon/protection of any kind to 'look for her'. Are you serious? Another favorite of mine is the sister who was haunted by the curse at her job LMAO! That was surprising; as I thought the curse was confined to the house only. She had her cowering like a little girl in her covers LMAO! Very funny stuff. What was even funnier, and led the movie more and more into utter comedy was the 'cry' of the curse. They couldn't come up with a better sound for it? That's some kid stuff that we used to do back in the day, trying to see who could do it the longest. How ridiculous!If you wanna have a good laugh, this is the movie for you. But don't expect a good horror film at all; it's laughable how the makers really thought they would scare people with this nonsense.** out of **** stars, because it's so bad its funny.

But low on plot. That's how I would describe "The Grudge". Like "The Ring" before it, "The Grudge" is an Americanized version of a highly successful Japanese Horror flick. (Has Hollywood no original horror script-writers left?) Anyway, "The Grudge" is okay. Not great, but certainly not terrible. The characterisation is weak, with little or no explanation as to the whys and wherefores of the plot. A house "replays" events?? Please. Tell us something we don't know. Where the film scores is the score, (see what I did there?) the soundtrack is integral to the plot, in fact it could be called a secondary character. The acting is above average with TV's Buffy and "Roswell's" Jason Behr putting in good performances. (with what little material they have to work with) The Japanese contingent are universally good and Bill Pullmann is surprisingly heavy in a smallish role. While "The Grudge" won't be winning any awards any time soon, it is a pleasant way to spend an afternoon.

I saw the original Ju-on before this came out. The original didn't rely on scarring you while watching the film, but more when it was over. I first watched this when I was fairly young and it disturbed me deeply. This film keep me up at night, thinking someone or something was there. I do prefer Ju-on over this one mainly because it was more well done. There is not much else to say besides it being scary. I recommend Ju-on over this one though. As far as story or characters go, there isn't much of it, but hey it's a horror movie.The film is just average. It's worth a rent, although you could get it fairly cheap now.

I found The Grudge, the American remake of the Japanese film "Ju-on" which takes place in Tokyo, more annoying than scary. Sarah Michelle Gellar of Buffy fame plays Karen, an American woman who lives in a house in Tokyo that is possessed by evil demons who sound like they have had too much soda, they open their mouths wide and belching sounds come out. They are meant to be scary sounds, but I found them annoying. I was never really scared, the formula for movies like this is pretty well known, a character seen walking down a dark hallway is doomed, and often is. There are flashbacks, well at least I think they are flashbacks, detailing the previous inhabitants of the house and why the ghosts are so upset and why they continue to pick on unsuspecting Americans. Based on the Japanese movie, The Grudge is the usual American-slasher film that offers very little in groundbreaking material.

Review title: Has its creepy moments but not very satisfying in the end
Review_body: My Review: ** out of ****.When I first saw previews for The Grudge, I thought it was going to be a Ring wannabe or at least along the lines of the Ring. I guess that is a reasonable thought since both were inspired by Japanese films and now being remade for the American audience. Unfortunately, when you compare the two films, The Ring clearly comes out on top.Thats not to say there is not anything good about The Grudge but I have a feeling this was just put together to score off The Ring's success. The Grudge offers some creepy moments but nothing else beyond them. You can say what you want about how open-ended The Ring was and how much the plot did not make sense, but it had a much more solid plot than what is found in The Grudge. By the end of The Ring, I was intrigued by what was left unanswered but at the end of The Grudge, I was just confused.Part of the reason, I was confused was because I just did not care what happened. The writer seemed to have no intention of creating characters for us to identify with. We have no sort of connection with them, they just seem to be here because you need people to kill off in a horror film.The other reason is because of the quality of the acting. Sarah Michelle Gellar is as uninspired as an actress can get. Throughout the film she just seems to be going through the motions. The rest of the cast, which is made up of American and Asian actors, fails to make an impression.Nevertheless, The Grudge does have some good points. The director of the film, Takashi Shimizu, was the director of the original and there is no doubt he gives the film a very stylish look. The eerie atmosphere fills every frame and there are quite a few moments where I jumped out of my seat. Nevertheless, some of those moments reminded me too closely of The Ring. There is one moment where a detective is watching the spirit on a surveillance tape and is walking towards the television. No doubt its creepy but I almost expected it to walk out of the TV. Also, even at those moments, it fails to measure up to The Ring's most memorable moments.The Grudge is only worth a watch if you want a few good scare. At its very best, it is competent as a horror film. However, like I said before The Grudge seems to have only one purpose for being made. If the filmmakers had spent more time with story and characters, then The Grudge could have been a good horror film but as it stands, its just not worth your time.

Review title: Good at building suspense, but becomes repetitive.
Review_body: Overall I though this was a good start to a movie, the suspense build up was done really well and the first visual of the monster was good. But sadly it only went downhill after that.The story and pacing is a bit meh, it's mostly doing its thing like any other horror and introduces its characters very briefly, builds suspense with random sounds a character has to investigate, and kills. And that goes on repeat for quite a while. The formula gets noticeably annoying in this movie though. And with the lack of creativity in kills or gore, it doesn't pay off either.I thought most of all that the monster(s) here were underwhelming. Except for the final scene in the house, that's when I thought it finally did what I expected it to do from the start, be scary and creepy. Though the stop motion effect was a bit funny. Most of the scares are just a person with pale skin and black hair. And the whole ghostly effects were not that great and ruined a bit of the mystery for me. Why was it even there in the first place? It's not really used for anything.The acting is fine. Directing is good, really well done and did a lot for the actual suspense build up. The music is alright.There's not a lot of gore or blood for the matter, pretty much zero violence. So if you don't like any of that but do like something a little scary, this would do well. Or if you are scared easily by pale black-haired Japanese actors.All in all it was fine. But tends to feel slow and repetitive.

Jason Behr and Sarah Michelle Gellar are a young American couple who have moved to live in Japan.Gellar plays Karen, a young nurse who is called to a house to help care for an elderly lady who suffers from dementia and doesn't speak.Within moments of entering the house, Karen starts to see creepy things happen and sees in a cupboard the house what she thinks is a young Japanese boy (with a terribly pale complexion!!).The story then unravels to show the many other people who have come into contact with the house and when nasty things start to happen to them, things become clearer to what happened there in the past.The story jumps back and too almost enough to make you sea sick, while it really doesn't do enough to either grip you, thrill you or even scare you that much. 45 minutes of material seems to be stretched over an hour and a half and the whole film generally feels like an overlong episode of the "Twilight Zone" Still watchable, but very over rated.

Review title: The scenes are creepy, but too disconnected to captivate the viewer
Review_body: THE ONLY POTENTIAL SPOILER IS THAT I DESCRIBE THE ESSENCE OF NEARLY ALL Japanese HORROR SCENES)The rule of thumb for watching any Japanese horror film that is remade in Hollywood is to go for the original, subtitles be damned. The one exception is The Ring. The Grudge remake, made by the exact same director of the original, is a series of confusing, disconnected creepy scenes until the end where you kinda-sorta get an explanation. No plot. Just typical stupid horror movie characters doing stupid things. "Oh, let's go check out that really creepy sound all by myself after I found my wife/mother/girlfriend/pet dead/catatonic/(insert-state-of-being-here)." Having seen nearly all the Japanese horror flicks, there is a clear culture of fear of long black hair, water and eyeballs or mouths that are stretched/blacked out via PhotoshopCGI. When you experience it for the first time, it's scary. The second time, it's interesting. For the third, fourth, ...., it's yaaawwwwwnnnn.

During The Grudge, you hoped that maybe the movie would mix Lost in Translation with The Ring and a couple of fresh scares. Instead, the movie sucked on all fours. The fresh scares you would expect from a modern horror movie were replaced with the same generic garbage we've been force-fed since our youth. Which is sad really, because the idea of The Grudge originally had the potential to be a very good movie. Seriously, please give this movie fifteen minutes and you can see how they blew it. When Bill Pullman opens the movie, you wish later on that you joined him.Strange things are amuck in a house in Japan that forgives neither American nor Japanese.Was there some point where you had no clue what was going on? Minutes are spent looking at scenery and rooms. There's a dim hue that becomes annoying. And sadly, there are the obligatory references to a more famous film based on yet another Japanese film, The Ring with: ghastly women, photos that intrigue and, eyes, oh no, eyes! I would encourage anyone to watch this movie if they want a headache. It's safe to say for now that it cannot get any worse than this second rate rip-off of any true horror movie you might have wanted to see.

Yes, I know this is a remake of the Japanese horror film Ju-On, and no, I haven't seen the original. I don't particularly care for horror as a genre, either written or filmed; it doesn't really grab me or speak to me, and most American horror films are just so much trash, an excuse for bloodletting and gore (the only recent exception I can think of, which was still pretty gory, was last year's Wrong Turn, which starred another Buffy alumnus).Honestly, I went to see The Grudge on the basis of two actors, Sarah Michelle Gellar and Jason Behr, both of whom I've seen in other projects, and both of whom I like. That this particular film was remade by the original director led me to believe it would have some integrity, unlike a lot of other films that are remade and dumbed down for the American audience (yes, I'm thinking of Point of No Return, among others).The Grudge is a more cerebral thriller; there's murder afoot, but we're not subjected to ghoulishly outlandish killings ala the Final Destination series. The Grudge's thrills come mostly from the two creepy ghosts and their stalking; one is a young boy (Yuya Ozeki) who howls like a demented cat, and the other is a ghastly young woman (Takako Fuji) who really makes your skin crawl. These two pop up almost anywhere, and for a long while it's uncertain if they are actually appearing or are merely in the mind of their beholders. Writer/director Takashi Shimuzu uses his frightening malefactors to excellent effect.It's too bad the rest of the movie doesn't quite live up to its potential. While I enjoyed the non-sequential storytelling and found it easy to follow and seamlessly done, The Grudge moves along a little slow for my tastes.
