There are an awful lot of gaijin in the movie as well, and it's never explained why so many westerners are involved with this particular curse (only the ghosts and the police are Japanese; everyone else is American); aside from a few brief words, nothing is made of the cultural barriers. Also, I found the root cause of the mystery to be predictable, given away a third of the movie before it's revealed. In a slower, more thoughtful type of thriller like this, preserving that mystery is key, and revealing it as early as Shimuzu (I'm thinking unintentionally) does robs the later revelation  probably the best sequence in the film  of a lot of its power (Shimuzu is not alone in this misstep. M. Night Shamalamadingdong RUINED the Sixth Sense by blowing the 'big' mystery twenty minutes in).The actors all do fine here. Bill Pullman, whom I've disliked since ID4, is actually low key and very effective as the first victim of the curse. I was disappointed Behr's role was so small (he's barely more than a cameo). Gellar is very good, conveying the horror of the situation and her bewilderment with what's going on very effectively. Her rooftop scene with the police inspector is understated and strong. Given her talent I didn't feel The Grudge to be a particular stretch for her, but she's very good here. And I'm always glad to see Ted Raimi have a cameo in anything.Overall The Grudge isn't a bad film, it's just not a very good one. It's a sort of middle of the road horror film with some interestingly creepy visuals and some decent performances, but there's nothing spectacular or compelling enough about this story or the way it is told to merit this remake. I much prefer this type of thriller to the hack and slash variety of most American horror films, but saying this is better than Jeepers Creepers is like saying having the flu is better than having leprosy. I could only recommend The Grudge for horror fans, or fans of Japanese movie-making, or people like me, who simply miss Gellar after seven years on TV and don't want to subject themselves to something including a computer animated dog. Or Matthew Lillard, same difference.

Review title: Seems Like a Ring to Me
Review_body: First please allow me to preface this whole commentary with a bit of information: The Grudge = the Japanese "Ju-on" = The Ring = the Japanese "Ringu". Now what that equation excellently illustrates is how some good Japanese horror can always be remade to make millions on the American market. Not that I'm complaining though. I thought "The Ring" was one of the best horrors in the last few years. But unfortunately for "The Grudge", it couldn't leave well enough alone and decided instead to "borrow" elements from "The Ring" and introduce it as its own. Specifically, the film has the whole Samara-from-the- Ring-bit down to a fine science, complete with the hair over the face, super-white flesh, and that strange jerky fast-forward walk (scares the hell out of me!). It then uses some good gore, a scary cat, and your classic demonic child for accompaniment. So you see, The Grudge is far from original. Even the story, about a possessed home where its owners died a horrible death isn't original. Despite this, "The Grudge" does manage to deliver some pretty powerful scares. Classic mounting suspense is delivered well and creepiness overall is excellent. Sarah Michelle Gellar (Buffy) does good on the big screen as a victim of the supernatural. She still seems just a little too cupcake to me though. You know what I mean? I couldn't rate this movie poorly despite its robberies simply because it does have some good jump-out-of-your-seat material. I wouldn't want to watch this film alone. 6/10

Review title: Belching ghost and mutant cat-child run amuck
Review_body: I gave this movie a 5/10 because I didn't need to see another horror movie like the Exorcist, but it's interesting to see what the horror genre has become. This borrows a lot of quick-shots from the Ring, and it takes a lot of scenes from the Ring and includes them here, but with less interesting things added (like the video scene where the spirit comes out of no where and attacks the video camera).Basically, Sarah Michelle Gellar plays a caretaker for sick older people and is assigned to substitute for a caretaker than has been missing. The other caretaker, "Yoko," has been missing because an evil spirit has taken over her body. Why? Apparently because the spirit moves on when it becomes bored and wants to give a good scare...that's what my understanding is. So everything culminates around what body the spirit will inhabit next, and Gellar's is on the list because now she knows too much (after sneaking around the house and finding a cat-boy...yes, a cat-boy...hiding in the closet of her client.) The movie was haunting, and seeing Bill Pullman as the love-interest of the spirit was an interesting choice. I can see why the American-made version was created because it shows you the ending first, and then tries to invite you to understand why things are the way they are in the movie. I sort of think that this was actually Ju-on's director's second chance at making the movie perfect. I see that Sam Raimi had his hand in this, but I wonder if that was the intention by the original director to fix certain things about Ju-on that were not as pleasing to American audiences.Alas, this film gets a 5/10 from me because it is average and stays there because there's nothing truly original about the film. I would've scored it a 6 (for it's modern day spooks and newer direction on how the "villains" act and move, to give it a creepier feel), but again, the Ring beat them to the punch on this one. All of that new-style direction was made popular by the Ring, and the Grudge feels like it borrowed a lot from that film and tried to make another movie just like it. I liked the music and the sound effects (even if the ghost was belching throughout the film...ha ha), and every time that thing came on the screen it had a certain appeal, but there was nothing new.

Horror films are a tough genre. I'd say maybe 1 in 100 are great and 10 in 100 are very good. "The Grudge" is one of those very good horror films. To me, it's all about creating an atmosphere of horror, making the audience feel a deepening sense of dread all the way through to the finale. "The Grudge" does this well.Japanese horror films are a great new phenomenon. I think they have really injected some fresh blood (ahem!) into the genre. And, it's cool stuff! Even when some of the plotting gets kind of crazy (reminds me of anime story lines), there's still a lot to like! I enjoyed the slow, deliberate pacing, along with the jarring moments that came at just the right times. Many talented filmmakers contributed to this film, and it shows! I haven't seen the original, but I'm putting it on my DVD rental list.7 of 10 stars

Review title: A Decent Halloween Haunted House Flick
Review_body: Not great (I think The Ring was light years beyond this one on my personal fearometer), but I'd recommend it as a fun Halloween flick that's perfect for those who can't shell out the $50+ entrance fee for an amusement park spooking.For the most part, The Grudge is an old-fashioned haunted house movie. What's new here is mainly that ghosts are portrayed in pretty high-tech ways these days, but this is definitely a "things that go bump in the night" story. It's fright value lies mostly in the technique of the unexpected hand on the shoulder. It startles more often than it scares.Sara Michelle Gellar is OK in her role as the main character. I doubt this role stretched her acting abilities much; all she really had to do was act scared every so often, and was called upon to be largely deadpan between. Her character is mainly a lightning rod for spooky things to happen as the movie moves along. I should say, too, that the movie moves backwards and forwards along the plot line in various ways, and it sometimes comes off a bit choppy because of this. Bill Pullman has a small role; he starts off the story by jumping to his death off a sixth story apartment balcony, and the rest of the film unravels the reason why he's done this.The ghosts themselves are pretty effective. The effects people did a great job of combining some truly ghoulish makeup and some choice sound effects. The ghosts are, of course, the true stars of this movie, and everyone else is more or less window-dressing.All in all, I think this movie will scare people who haven't seen a lot of horror flicks more than it will those of us who have seen so many that they've lost count. Not that there isn't something to be had by jaded horror fans such as myself, too, but I suspect that most of us who have seen this kind of thing before can see the scares coming. The startling bits aren't that startling if you already know what's about to happen. People who haven't seen a lot of movies in this genre, however, are likely to loose a scream or two, as did the audience members in the theater where I saw the movie.And please, somebody buy Toshio a new scratching post and some catnip. It'd make him very happy. Thanks.

Review title: who cares about the Japanese version
Review_body: i am not the sort of person who gets scared easily, in fact i can only think of a handful of films that engage me in that way. This film had me looking around the sofa at the end and got the spine tingling.The premise behind the film is a bit clichéd but the Japanese director did a great job keeping and building the suspense and getting a good performance from an actress as wooden as S.M.Gellar.I don't understand why so many people have to compare this movie to the Japanese original, how many people did that for reservoir dogs and the hong kong original or roxanne and cyrano de bergerac to name just a couple of examples. Film -making is all about ripping off from other films anyway and this was catered for an American/English speaking audience. Any comparison is unfair as its apples to oranges and pointless anyway, this film should be judged on its merits and its a great horror flick!!

Omigosh, this is seriously the scariest movie i have ever, ever seen. To say that i love horror movies would be an understatement, and i have seen heaps (considering the limited availability in New Zealand, that's quite a lot), but never before have i had to sleep with the light on...until i saw The Grudge.Some may say that it is a rip off of The Ring (both based on Japanese horror movies), both similar (yet different) story lines, but the Grudge holds its own as a terrifying movie - seeing at at the cinema, i even screamed at a certain point in the movie.The acting is great, particularly from the supporting characters - KaDee Strickland is fantastic and steals the show, she is such an enthusiastic person. Jason Behr is a real hottie, and William Mapother looks like he is having fun. However, while i am normally a fan of Clea DuVall's, she doesn't really seem into this movie. Of the supporting characters, hers probably got the most depth and back story, but she doesn't seem like she is all there. As for Sarah Michelle Gellar, well, she stays about the same through all her films and roles doesn't she? The ghosts were genuinely scary, the music and sound effects were chilling (particularly the noise being made when KaDee Strickland's character answered the phone in her apartment), the ending was cool too.Super highly recommended. 9/10

The Grudge is rather a mess of a film. Most obviously, the chronology and perspective constantly changes but the film is written in such a way that most of the flashbacks and perspective shifts primarily exist to give detail to information that has already been conveyed through exposition, or that is obvious through inference. As a result, most of the storytelling falls flat and the film lacks suspense since the viewer already knows what's going to happen most of the time. At the same time, none of the characters are really fleshed out so it's hard to care about them to begin with. Amusingly for an American version of this most of the principal characters just happen to be Americans living in Japan and mostly speaking English. If the film did anything at all with this cultural conflict it might be fun to ponder whether the apparitions just really hate Americans but alas, even this bit of fun is absent, and this is just another missed opportunity for some relatively obvious and easy character development that just doesn't show up. The other major problem with this film is that the actual spirit that is killing people is barely seen for the majority of the film and when it does show up it just comes across as an inferior version of the malevolent entity from The Ring, an obvious influence. Instead, most of the film uses the spirit of a young boy in a muddled way. The boy is somewhat creepy because of his appearance, which provides all the menace that can be summoned from black eye makeup and a generous slathering of corpse paint. At the same time, he still looks like a very young boy and, for me at least, this inspired the usual sympathetic feelings I have towards a young child. The juxtaposition between his appearance and this sympathy almost becomes something interesting but once the film seemed to imply that he might be responsible for the deaths of some adults the situation took a turn for the absurd because there really isn't that much menace to be had from any child unless there's something obvious to the menace beyond appearance. In any case, Shimizu overuses the child character and underuses the actual malevolent entity, not that she's all that threatening except in comparison to the boy. She's just a ghost with a "grudge" because she died in terrible pain and now she just kills people that come to her old house, because...well, the film certainly doesn't do anything to explain why she would want to kill people or why she mostly just haunts the house but sometimes leaves it to go after people that have been there before. Especially in comparison to The Ring, The Grudge fails to establish the power or motivation of its malevolent spirit at any point and in fact it's hard to imagine why she would be so powerful. All in all, this story simply isn't told very well and several aspects of it fail. It's hard to believe that this is actually the third or fourth time the director tried to tell this story given how poorly he tells it.

Basically an American remake of the recent Japanese film JU-ON, this works best on reduced expectations.JU-ON made points with its atmospheric backdrop and retreating narrative line; THE GRUDGE contains more outright scares, but also makes less sense as a plot. When a young housewife (Sarah Michele Geller) reluctantly goes to Japan with her architect husband, they land in a house that hasn't been inhabited for several years. Needless to say, it's haunted by spirits who seem particularly malignant, carrying the "grudge" of their awful fate to anyone who lives there.Various people associated with the house meet grim fates, mostly frightened to death. There's a sinister black cat, a winding staircase that's a ringer for the one in THE EXORCIST, and other devices that might lead you to think you've seen this film before. However, this doesn't detract from the simple fact that THE GRUDGE is creepy and great fun to watch. The locations give this a special flavor as well. If you just want to enjoy yourself at the movies with a box of popcorn, this unpretentious scare-fest just may be your ticket.

Review title: I'm sorry was this supposed to be scary or just a remake of The Ring
Review_body: Sarah Michelle Gellar, Jason Behr William Mapother, Clea DuVall, Bill Pullman. Directed by Takashi Shimizu. Based on Ju-on.I'm sorry was this supposed to be scary. Or was it just another one of those "The scariest movies since the Sixth Sense". Well after watching this the answer for me anyway was no, this was just like the Ring a waste of time and money. The scariest thing about this was Bill Pullman agreed to do this...this travesty of what they call a horror movie. For me it is far from horror perhaps in the "Retarded" genre.The story set in where else but Tokyo where an American nurse (Gellar) finds a scary house with a curse upon it. That is about all I know about the story really I couldn't pay attention to it. It was more like the Ring, the guy and girl look for the truth then the guy dies. JUST LIKE THE RING. Of course saying Japan hasn't had a good horror movie since well maybe Godzilla and that was a guy in a costume! The tag-line It never forgives, It never forgets well my version is You'll never forgive yourself for watching it, You'll never forget the stupidity of it. My final rating 1/10.

Review title: I've got your grudge right here.
Review_body: I liked The Grudge about as much as the original, which is to say, I didn't really care for it. Both of them shared the same nonsensical, jumbled plot and lengths of boredom (I had to fight back the yawns!). The jump scares (and ghosts) did work a tiny bit better in the remake but in the end, still didn't do anything for me. The original might have the edge in sound effects though, which in my opinion was the best quality of these two films. The story and settings were quite similar between the two, though I believe the ending was slightly different in Ju-on. Also, I don't recall the jawless ghost (good scene) being in Ju-on. Anyway, I must say I really prefer Ringu and The Ring to Ju-on and The Grudge, though I didn't find those movies all that good either. I'll take The Eye over all of 'em.

Review title: Absoulute Garbage that makes The Ring look like an Oscar Movie!
Review_body: Karen(Sarah Michelle Gellar) is a nurse working in Tokyo, Japan who gets involved in a raging curse at a haunted house.The movie is absolute garbage(as I said in the title). It wasn't scary, exciting, interesting, or thrilling. It is funny at times but only because it is so stupid! I still don't understand why the kid made a "meow" noise. I don't understand the black stuff that would spread on to the roof, even after watching the whole move. The acting was horrible and unconvincing. Sarah Michelle Gellar's acting was a joke. Come to think of it, everything in this movie was a joke. One big joke!! Overall, the movie was horrible. That's it! Horrible! I do not recommend this movie.

This film didn't have a positive effect on me as I thought "The Ring" was much, much superior not only in the scare factor but in plot and dialog as well. I just didn't really like it that much; however there were a couple of scenes that did get the audience to jump a little bit to the edge of their seats but most of them just got laughed off. One person even shouted out 'bring on Godzilla' during one of the Japanese detective scenes because it was downgrading to pure cheese relatively quickly...which definitely added some comic relief. I didn't think the actors were effective either since they usually utilized only a handful of expressions for the movie's entirety. The plot fell way short and just didn't add up and the time-line storyboard while meant to give it an intelligent feel...collapsed as well. I also felt that this whole movie was made to promote the sequel, which I don't know if they're going to make it but I certainly was overcome by that impression. The idea was there, but they exploited it instead of realizing its full potential.Final Time:Movies: Worth it in no such way!DVD Purchase: Have no intentions whatsoever.Rental: Possibly a good Halloween flick but that's about it.

Review title: This movie has always creeped me out
Review_body: 'The Grudge' isn't the best horror film and it isn't the scariest either, but there's something about it that always manages to get to me. From the very first scene, which is appropriately bizarre, to the last, 'The Grudge' is a very creepy movie and I can't quite put my finger on why.

The Grudge/2004/**Main Star: Sarah Michelle GellarIf you think it's scary, it's NOT! Well, at least I don't think so. There were a few jumping scenes, but not many. Obviously, I think the main star (Sarah Michelle Gellar) can direct a better movie than the director, Takashi Shimizu, which did an original one of this movie in Japanese (you can tell by his name). But then he thought Americans wanted to see this, too. So he did the movie over with American stars in it and in English. In my opinion, it was average. It had a cruel story to it and it did not have a happy ending. The movie takes place in a haunted house with a dead kid with a big mouth and a cat scream and a dead lady that sounds like she's burping all the time and a dead man that you don't see. Stupid movie and didn't really have a main point. It was just about haunted house with dead people cursing everyone who crossed the doorstep. It may have good actors in it but it has a mediocre plot. Also it kept going back and forth, I mean you never know when it's a flashback or what? There are just too many movies like this. Movie directed by Takashi Shimizu.

I don't get this movie. I mean, I don't get why anyone finds it scary. I admit I have yet to see the original Japanese Ju-On, which I hear is much better, but this is trash. Basically, there is some house and after you enter it, you die. Yay. This movie honestly doesn't even make the most sense. And the ghost is pretty dumb looking...and makes an annoying noise that actually made me laugh. Especially the ending, I was just bored out of my mind at least I could find some comedy in this miserable so called film. I really don't get why this scares people, is it the sound the ghost makes? It kind of sounds like a burp...almost like those farting ghosts in the Spookies. And you remember how bad the Spookies was...well, this is worse...

Boring, horrible, confusing, dumb, mess.Spoilers below:
The main actress dies and or disappears 20 minutes in, then reappears through non-linear story mess the whole movie.The ghost eats people? We think. This is never shown nor explained.Any, single, time, the film actually picks-up and gets interesting, it cuts to black and ends the scene.Ted Raimi is the best actor in this: That's when you know you f---ed-up!

The title doesn't capture the essence of the film and seems inappropriate to say the least.The film itself is highly stylized with its moments of shock and terror - at times reminiscent of "The Ring." Unfortunately, the movie's pace is slow and tedious, milking scenes of their suspense and leaving the audience with far too much boredom.Though Sarah Michelle Gellar did a great job, I doubt if this feature will be the movie career launchpad she had hoped for.There are plans for a Grudge II. If so, they'd better pick up the pace.

I watched this with my brother because we couldn't find the original anywhere, we had low expectations. The beginning was somewhat suspensful and it seemed that this could become something good, but once we got into the middle we had to give up. It started dragging out so much and our attention was just not enough. So much potential for a good remake wasted.

I have mixed feelings about The Grudge. With most movies, I have a pretty strong feelings in terms if I like it, hate it, or just think it's amusing. However, this is a different and I am not too sure why.Let me say that I have never seen the original. Since I have seen the American version, I am tempted to go and rent the original so I can compare and probably have a better view of this movie. But that will be later.This is what I liked. First of all, the direction was good as well as the effects created by the environments of the house, flashbacks, etc. The movie itself, on a whole, was well made and edited. Unlike other thrillers, the feeling of suspense wasn't too much or too little.However, here are the problems. First of all, I think Sarah Michelle Gellar's part should have gone to a Japanese actress. I know this was made for an American audience, but it would have been more powerful if a Japanese character was made central to the story. Not a American exchange student doing her best to fit into the culture. The other Americans could still be included, but a Japanese actress with Gellar's part would have added something.In reading the trivia section provided by IMDb, I read that the movie was edited to a pg-13 rating, cutting out more of the graphic scenes. I think that was another bad decision because more of the violent memories (or flashbacks, I don't know what they actually were of course), would have given the audience a more intimate sense of what happened in that house. What scenes were provided at the end of the movie, when Geller sees what happened to the woman and her son, was well done. I can only speculate that the scenes edited out where more like that.However, despite my misgivings about The Grudge, I have to say that it was better then I thought it would be. It was also better then The Ring which still baffles me in terms of why so many people liked it. More graphic scenes and better casting could have made it much better though. It will be interesting to see how a sequel works. My mixed feelings still stand, thus the reason I give this movie five out of ten.
For the remake of the Japanese horror classic, this film is interesting and I enjoyed it.

Review title: Had its moments but nothing unique in overall
Review_body: I had my expectations high for this movie, because i'd seen its ads on TV and it looked like, well like an exceptional Hollywood horror movie.After i'd watched it i felt like betrayed and very stupid. This was just another Hollywood movie. I bet they had censorship for this movie to make it available for the wider audience.Did they really think this'd be scary at all? I really thought this'd be something because it had a Japanese director and it was filmed in Japan, i presume. People disappearing, some ghost under the blanket and whooosh, there you go! Sounds and looks like a fairytale which i'd tell my children.The biggest drawback was Sarah-Michelle Gellar, whatever, i knew she'd not act well, in a believable way! According to her TV series, Buffy, The vampire slayer, she's just a b-class actress. Whatever that means, after this movie i'd rate her to c-class. But don't get me wrong, she's just a wonderful person in a wrong profession.After all, this had some classic material in it, but they just spoiled it with censorship and bad attitude. The movie ends in a very predictable way, and at a point i'd have not expected it to end. I had to ask myself that was this really IT!

Review title: Your Average Bump in the Dark
Review_body: **Minor Spoilers**My girlfriend loves horror flicks, and lately we've been experimenting with some of the more successful Japanese horror movies. We (well, more she) were quite excited to see "The Grudge" when it first came out several weeks ago.The theater was packed with teeny boppers, and the theater was constantly filled with chatter and repeating pattern of *SCREAM* *giggling and chatter* *SCREAM* *giggling and chatter* *SCREAM* ... rinse, repeat etc. etc.Nevertheless I more or less stayed focused on the film. It certainly had its moments. Shimizu maximizes his BOO!-moments with creative camera angles and shots, and occasional gore. If cheap shots that make you jump are all you want, then The Grudge is definitely for you.Where it fails is in its plain-jane, run-of-the-mill horror plot. There is nothing different, new, clever, or unexpected. There are no twists, turns, or mindbenders. The house is haunted, and that's it.Furthermore, I'm not sure why Shimizu chose to recreate the movie with an almost entirely American/caucasian cast. Since he retains the Japanese settings, an American audience nevertheless run into the occasional cultural oddity. It seems pandering that almost every major character is white while the surrounding area is Japan. If the goal was to sellout to an American audience, why not simply go 100 yards and set the movie in America? Throw in not-so-stellar acting, especially by Gellar, and you end up with a pretty mundane horror flick. I give "The Grudge" a 5 / 10 : fairly average and forgettable. If you want a horror movie with more depth, more creative plot, and a more lasting impression, see The Ring or The Others.

There's nothing really wrong with this movie, but there's nothing really great about it either. It's just kinda there, like vanilla pudding. There are some decent jump scares throughout, but other than that it's pretty much your standard haunted house story. Except this one's set in Japan, a choice which I cannot understand at all. It made all those gaijins stick out like sore thumbs and I kept wondering what Ted Raimi was doing in Japan. The writing was sophomoric, the acting was uninspired and the direction felt like a Japanese director doing an American version of his original Japanese story. It ended being the cinematic equivalent of Yoshinoya Beef Bowl. Not Japanese or American enough to be any good, it takes the worst elements of both and combines them into a $2.99 Teriyaki Chicken Meal. Five stars out of ten.

First off, at the beginning, no girl would pursue a noise upstairs, much less to the ATTIC, by herself when there shouldn't be anybody up there. After the blond was haunted at the office so late at night, she wouldn't take a cab just back to her place; she'd want to be with someone. She'd want to stay out in public. Especially when she's ultimately creeped out after the phonecall, the last thing she'd want to do is lock herself up in her place by herself. And of course, in the whole building, even late at night, she doesn't run into anybody.

Director Takashi Shimizu has done an excellent job remaking this film for American audiences. While some will argue that this is nothing more than just corporate Hollywood turning the cranks on audiences' wallets, I thought there was quite a bit of originality to this film. The institution of us seeing the demon or spirits before the characters do was something that I wasn't familiar with in other horror films. Normally, there is this big "jumping out of the darkness" scene that frightens everyone because they were not expecting it, but in The Grudge there was this element of "here I am" that frightened me more than most films do.Takashi Shimizu, the mastermind behind this film, also created the original Ju-on series that became extremely popular in Japan. This allowed his vision and purpose (with a larger budget) to continue. I enjoyed the fact that the original director was on board and that our American crew was in Japan. This took me away from the idea that this film was going to be nothing more than just a pro-America horror film. It took me to this unfamiliar place (building the fear) and showcased the talents of some unfamiliar/familiar American film actors working next to a complete Japanese crew. I thought that this kept the entire film grounded. It wasn't set in New York, there wasn't the scene of raw nudity at the beginning ... there wasn't the normal American structure to this film because we were not in America ... we were in Japan. This really helped me build the excitement and utter terror that I felt while watching this film. I was impressed.The acting, well, you don't go to a horror film expecting to see Oscar caliber acting. Gellar and Pullman knew that the horror genre is slowing coming into the limelight as a prominent figure in cinema (it was lacking for a couple of years there) and I think that is why they chose to do this project. Pullman wasn't anything to write home about, thought I was impressed to see him in this film. Gellar was the exact same. She did her part, collected her money, and went home. This wasn't what frightened me about this film. I didn't rent this movie to be blown away by the acting. I expected average acting and that is what I got. What I did go into this film expecting was to shake, shiver, and be frightened to turn off the lights after the film. That is exactly what I found. Takashi Shimizu did an excellent job of building that right amount of suspense, using amazing lighting, perfect sound, and some very freaky visuals. His knowledge and ability to bring us something new was extremely impressive and honest. Here is a director who was handed the money to make the film that he wanted, and while not everything was probably to his liking, it did open the door for more fans to enjoy his work. It also opened the door to more projects from his mind to be released. This could be the new face of cinematic horror, and I cannot wait to see what he has in store for us.Overall, I loved this movie. It was the exact level of fright that I was looking for. There were scenes that I never saw coming, there were elements that were unexpected and vividly raw, and it thankfully did not follow the ever-classic Hollywood horror formula. There was originality and emotion in this film that most horror directors do not give when dabbing in the horror genre. This was a great story, and I cannot wait to gather friends for a late night horror scream-fest featuring this film. From the opening scene, to the bus scene, to the opportunistic final moment, I had my finger on the fast-forward and I was scared. This did what it set out to do for me, and for that I can only praise this film!

Review title: Haven't seen any of the Japanese Grudge-films, but...
Review_body: Haven't seen any of the Japanese Grudge-films, but I really enjoy this one. I rarely get SCARED when watching films. I can jump, if the effect and sound is startling enough, but getting scared from a movie is a rare thing for me. But I did get scared from Grudge. Maybe because I didn't expect anything at all when I watched it. I didn't expect getting scared. I didn't know anything about it either. That was probably a good thing.This is a film that you, apparently, either love or hate. Most people seem to compare it to the Japanese Grudge-films, but even though I haven't seen them, I believe it isn't right to compare any film, actually. This film stands on it its own.The story is weak, most people say. I don't agree. The story is minimalistic, and done so on purpose. The story-telling techniques used - the broken time frame for instance - is perfectly done. The director knows exactly what he's doing, and I believe he got his vision through as he wanted it.I gave this film 8 of 10. It is a film you will enjoy watching, or hate. It's as simple as that.

This re-make of the Japanese cult hit is a new and improved version of Takashi Shimizu's JU-ON.The Grudge focuses on scaring you with very effective jump scares and disturbing images,which occur throughout the entire film a lot of the time when you least expect it.The Grudge does what most horrors do not do and that is bend the rules of the classic setting of the haunted house.In everyday American horror usually the main character is tormented by the inhabitants of the house,then they leave the house to be safe,and then find a way to stop it.The Grudge isthe opposite which is a very pleasant surprise,when you leave thishaunted house you are sure as hell not safe.The interesting thingis that generally those who die in horror films either deserve it or have something to do with the conflict but in The Grudge everyday people who even set one foot in the house are doomed to perish.I think that The Grudge is very original,very unique,and very effective at inflicting fear into it's audience.The storyline however is hard to follow at times and can be very confusing but without taking anything away from the movie.The Grudge is also full of typical horror film clichés but for the most part is very original and different.The acting is top notch as far as horror flicks go and the characters are all believable and easy to buy into.The Grudge is a must see horror film.

i saw this movie on Hallowe'en for a special preview. I must admit and think what you like but the only reason i went to see this was Sarah Michelle Gellar. I hadn't heard of this being a remake as Sam Raimi and SMG were the only names plastered on the posters and i hadn't read one review. So i went to see this and wow, i was caught after the first scene with Bill Pullman, the weirdness and emptiness of him standing on the balcony intrigued me more than the events that followed. Shocked!Up until 3/4 of the way through the movie i was clinching at the arm rests and desperately trying to look away from the screen but not being able to. Whenever there was a jump i jumped and the sequence of events that befall the unfortunate American family that enter the house including the lady who wasn't even living there, just part of the family, absolutely terrified me. When i told people about it the next day, just remembering the scenes sent chills down my spine.My only problem was that there weren't enough Japanese people in this, they were in Japan and there were only about 5 Japanese people in the movie who all spoke very good English. This could have been a great horror version of Lost in Translation had the only American non Japanese speaking people been Sarah and her boyfriend. But it rocked anyway so i don't hold a grudge. This movie just scared the hell out of me and most of my friends who saw it, quite a few had trouble sleeping. This movie rocks

Review title: Let this curse die right here
Review_body: Ten minutes into The Grudge I started to think about another recent movie, which is always cause for alarm bells. Though hardly a memorable movie, The Butterfly Effect ends with Ashton Kutcher beaming himself into his mother's womb and strangling himself with his umbilical cord, in the belief he should never have existed. Oh boy. There's a p*ss-easy metaphor for this pointless remake that should never have seen the light of day. Sitting in the cinema on my left is The Grudge's target audience: the Wide-Eyed Western Pig. A slack-jawed foot soldier for Hollywood's war of cultural imperialism, he trades the art-house for the megaplex as he prefers their fake butter flavor on his popcorn, views "Blockbuster" as a seal of quality, and wants a cute, familiar, WHITE face to focus on. Elsewhere the Horror Fetishist, a sad Pavlovian creature conditioned to lick its own d*ck whenever the name "Sam Raimi" appears on screen, is busy doing a lap of honor during the opening credits. These people have money. These people vote. These bottom-feeders are the mindless consumers the Dream Factory keeps chained to cigarette machines and Gold Lotto slips. Buds: this Grudge is for YOU. The original Ju-on: The Grudge, the story of a self-perpetuating curse centering on a family's tragic murder-suicide, was an effective if empty and ultimately silly variant on the seemingly endless Ring cycle and was itself spawned from two TV movies. At this point producer Sam Raimi, no virgin to the concept of franchise, waved a huge sack o'cash under director Takashi Shimizu's inscrutable gaze, not for him to reinterpret the movie, but to do a carbon copy of it. In Japan, with a Japanese crew. Virtually scene for scene, and in some cases shot for shot, on an almost-identical set, but with wide-eyed western stars Sarah Michelle Gellar and Bill Pullman. The message here? Money will make it better. Dance, monkey. Do a jig to the tune of two thousand megaplex cash registers all chiming at once. Jump through the hoops just a little faster, 'cos Buffy wants a new series. If the original Grudge had anything unique, it was its innate "Japanese-ness". Not so here. There's no sense of mounting horror in Shimizu's tired retread which gives the game away in the first 10 minutes, leaving its shocks all the more absurd. To add insult, its episodic structure has been tampered with by a Hollywood scriptwriter who explains away the inexplicable. Surely producer Raimi, while counting down the paychecks till Evil Dead 4, must have realized the Japanese horror film is like a bonsai tree, in its own culture a thing of symmetry, beauty and perfection. Stick it in a tiled pot in the Mall outside Hoyts Regent and it becomes a stupid looking tree. This isn't just a case of a remake, an updating or yet another pointless sequel. This is unmitigated arrogance - Hollywood saying "do it OUR way, and we can all make a chunk of change". Shimizu should have learned the lessons of history. The original directors of two effective European chillers The Vanishing and Nightwatch were both sent packing to the States to "Americanize" their movies. Does anyone remember George Sluizer or Ole Bornedal? Did anyone give a rat's *ss about the remakes? It's even more proof the Dream Factory has gone bankrupt for ideas, and Scrooge McDuck is at the helm, throwing cloth bags with dollar signs on them even further afield. This is a war, make no mistake, and for the moment the Wide-Eyed Western Pig is winning. What next? Ang Lee's remake of Crouching Tiger... with Casper Van Dien? Have mercy, and let this curse die right here.

Review title: This is a really GOOD thriller.
Review_body: The cast rocks totally. Sarah Michelle Gellar has always been a favorite of mine, and I've always liked Ted Raimi. Buffy and Xena sidekick aside this cast is both perfect and impressive. Ryo Ishibashi is excellent as the detective in charge of the investigation. His acting ability, in large degree for me anyway, made this flick. But every player does a wonderful job in bringing their characters to life, and that is one of the better aspects of the film. It flows well, continuity is very good, scripting is good, nice camera technique with good photography, good sound track, subdued special effects that work real well in a movie like this with no "over the top" silliness, and I liked the plot. What might be a down side if you haven't seen this yet: Gellar is given top billing, making it look like its her flick. It isn't. This thing is a GROUP effort, and a VERY good one at that.

I went in not expecting a lot from this movie, but actually was pleasantly surprised. Resembling parts of "The Ring" and "Sixth Sense", although not as good as those, it has it's moments. In fact, it had some very creepy moments in it. But I do have to admit that in some parts it was really hard to follow, and all the flashback scenes got old. Not your typical haunted house movie, although it takes a while to start to understand exactly what the hell is going on. One thing that I had trouble with was parts where the young girl(s) hear something upstairs, where it is dark and creepy, and they have to go investigate instead of getting the hell out of there. Go figure!!

I give this movie two stars out of ten. This movie is a American remake of a Japanese horror movie called Juon. The basic premise of the story is a bunch of deaths related to a haunted house in Japan. Michelle Gellar plays an exchange student in Japan who goes to this haunted house in Tokyo to look after an invalid American woman after the original caretakers disappeared. That's when the fun begins or lack thereof.Anyone who has seen Japanese cinema knows horror movies from Japan are heavily into suspense without much special effects. I remember reading some news magazine that was profiling Japanese cinema and one interviewee stated that Japanese cinemas do not have the budget like Hollywood movies to use many special effects. Therefore, they have to use mood, camera angles, and such to create suspense in their movies.Now I like this type of movie making. It reminds me of the classic thriller/horror genre of American cinemas in the 1940's and 1950's. That being said, most of this movie was not scary. Like a typical Japanese movie, the movie dragged on too long in some scenes and there is a reason for this. It makes the audience lull into complacency not expecting anything in particular, which makes the happening of a thrilling event much more scary. But again, there is just too many of these types of scenes.If you like Ringu, you might like this movie but Ringu was much more unique in its premise than your common haunted house theme. One of my friends told me that the Japanese version is slightly better than the American version and had offered to loan me his copy but I don't think I am going to see it. I did not like this movie and I was not scared at all.I would have given this movie one out of ten stars but I like Michelle Gellar so I am willing to give it an extra star.

Review title: Worth one watch, nothing much for a regular movie goer.
Review_body: A remake is usually made in order to take advantage to today's tools to come out with something new and better. Now, this movie is based on the Japanese movie Ju-On. I have not seen that movie so no comparisons can be made by me between the two. The plot is very typical. A house is the stage for a bizarre incident and since then the house is haunted affecting everyone that steps in it.A routine movie where someone gets affected (Sarah Michelle Gellar) and is now trying to understand the mystery behind the place to try and save herself. In a horror movie, you know for sure that unless it is totally different that when a person is stepping in dark place alone and the camera is slowing down then something is going to happen. And when you expect something to happen and it does you hardly get the goose bumps.However, that is for the experienced movie goer. But for someone not too used to movies maybe this will still produce the thrills it is meant to produce. I recall seeing only one scene where the incident or event was totally unexpected and got on my nerves. Unlike the Ring which I call as an intelligent horror movie it does not get you too involved. But nonetheless a decent horror movie worth one watch!

Finally gotten around to seeing this movie and I was quite disappointed. The concept was wrong as well as the execution. This film is not at least bit scary. In fact, I think they are reaching the bottom of the reasoning barrow when they try to explain why, what was happening was happening. I thought the sound effects blew big monkey chunks, the makeup was horrible and ineffective of bringing any type of chills to the screen and the story was unfocused. Perhaps something got lost in the translation or that Japanese horror yawns are just not that scary in the USA (although The Ring was excellent). I don't know what this movie was trying to do and I don't think the director did either. The way he treated his victim did not make any sense. Sarah Michelle Geller was just OK. She didn't get to do much in the way of interacting with the story (in my humble opinion only) and she IS the main character. I think this film try to be a bit slicker than it needed to be. It's OK to try something different, just make it coherent. Actually I found the film quite laughable in parts and boring in others. When the film ended, I just didn't care about any of the characters nor about the film as a whole. It totally missed the mark in what it was trying to do.

This film really is absolutely terrifying I had heard the hype of 'The Grudge' and happened to catch it on ITV, I started watching it and instantly approved of it because of Sarah Michelle Gellar (an actor I am rather fond off) The film has a really good plot and It genuinely is scary. There is something so creepy about the monster on the film the noise it makes still gives me chills and the music is horrific sort of like memorable music that every time you hear you associate with The Grudge and you will begin to be scared. I found myself after watching The Grudge actually scared to go upstairs alone It really did affect me and I know many off my friends felt the same way there is something about the film that is chilling. The Grudge is definitely worth your time to watch and will keep you on your toes!

Review title: Not a good crossbreed of Japanese and American films
Review_body: I like a lot of the neo-Japanese films because they dare to push the envelope. Take films like "Audition" (makes "Fatal Attraction" look sloppy) or even "Zatoichi" (which mix the ancient with the new). But there are neo-Japanese films that become redundant, like "Tomie". So when I heard "The Grudge", which was based on the Japanese film of the similar name, was coming out and it was directed by the same director of the Japanese film, I was definitely intrigued.Just came from the film, and it pretty much sucked. Yeah, sucked. Though I liked the photography (by Hideo Yamamoto of "Ichi the Killer" and "Audition") and the fact that Ryo Ishibashi, the main actor from "Audition", was in it, the rest of this movie just falls more into the American schlock-shock fest. Though the concept had great potential, we kind of get the idea from the 1st 30 minutes what is going on. On top of this, put in the usual scary faces, violin shrieks, and the little gremlin who meows creepy, and you got your general teen shock flick. Sarah Michelle Gellar really does not add much to the film, not to mention that her and her fiancée's part were really unnecessary in the film. This could have been explored more from the Japanese detective's point of view (no, this is not a spoiler). I really cannot recommend this film unless you're easily scared. Half the theatre was laughing (kind of like "Exorcist IV"). The movie had potential to be a good crossbreed of Neo-Japanese and American film, but failed miserably secondary to the greater emphasis on cheap American scare tactics and less development/innovation on the Japanese part. Even more disappointing is the fact that Sam Raimi, the great "Evil Dead" I and II director, actually produced this garbage.4/10

Review title: Do not watch this film alone at nite
Review_body: Do not, do not and again do not watch the Japanese version of this film at nite alone.

This movie shows the pattern that follows some successful films: the imitation; the girl is specially a "ring type" girl, with the blue body and the hair black over her face; in some parts of the movie, it resembles almost exactly the ring: Attention the next part could be a spoiler! (ej: in the part when the police officer put a VHS tape on the recorder and begin to watch the security recording, watch it and you will see a ring scene!!). Scary? yes but 50 times less than the ring, and in the story at the beginning of the film they say that the curse remain in the place, but if this is true, why the girl and the boy are in the whole city?, just something to analyze. If you read this comment, i don't want you to not see the film; go get scared! and grab the arm of your couple or the one nearest to you, scream!, have a good time!, but you can also analyze this "ring patterns" and have some fun.

To be honest this film doesn't have an awful lot going for it. It's Chinese, it has too many women in it, and the order is all jumbled up so you don't know what day it is or if someone is alive or dead or both. At least it bucks the recent trend of hilarious screamers which started with Scream, you know, those films that try to scare you and make you funny at the same time. There is no comedy here (though the wee boy in the cupboard was quite funny) and unfortunately there are no scares here either (though the wee boy in the cupboard was quite scary). It is a remake of the Chinese TV series 'Why Does This Lady With The Hair Have An Angry Against Me, Daddy?' There isn't really a plot or, it's just a pile of things happening involving a haunted house. One girl goes to the house; she thinks it's evil, has a look around, and gets sucked into the attic by a big hairy woman. Another girl replaces the last one, goes to the house and meets a little boy who seems to be made of chalk and speaks like a cat. The big hairy woman comes out and gets her too. The rest of the film involves police, school girls, and others going to the house and getting chased from room to room by the big hairy woman. In one frankly bizarre scene, one girl who escaped the house goes home and goes to the toilet. She sits down and begins doing her business. She knows something is amiss. The scary music starts. Is she alone? Is she safe? The door creaks! Everyone jumps. Her phone rings! Everyone jumps. Plop! Everyone jumps. She looks around the house, but no-one is there so she goes back to the toilet for more. She twitches, thinking something is tickling her bum. Again. And again. She gets up and looks down the toilet (dirty girl) and suddenly- BOO! The hairy woman is in the toilet! She grabs the girl and pulls her down into the darkness. Later, when her boyfriend comes home he goes to the toilet, opens the lid only to find his dead girlfriends head poking round the U bend, one leg bent beside her ear.As enjoyable as that sounds it really isn't. I haven't been able to go to the toilet sitting down since. Yes, I have to stand, facing the toilet at all times. I'm sure you can imagine the shapes I've had to put myself into in order to successfully deposit my mail. The rest of the film had less impact, and raised more questions than answers- why was the woman there? Why had the boy swallowed his cat? Why did everyone start crawling around the house, and why didn't someone just chuck a few grenades down the chimney and be done with it? Interestingly this Buffy spin off doesn't feature Gellar at her toughest. It would have been better if she's called in Giles, Willow, and Xander and they could have talked out the problem and then stake ass. Maybe it was all a nightmare.Best Scene: When the Chinese woman was walking up the stairs and you could almost see her pants.

Review title: Needlessly jumps around, but an OK creepshow
Review_body: Some viewers may be confused by the constant jumping back and forth in time. This may be intentional; in one of the final scenes, we see that Peter (Bill Pullman) can sense the presence of Karen in the room some three years later.SPOILER ALERT: To straighten out the timeline, this is the order in which the thirteen deaths are shown: 7,5,6,8,9,10,4,11,1,2,3,12,13. That is, although Yoko's death is the first shown in the movie, it was actually the seventh to occur. The deaths occurred in this order: The Japanese woman Kayako and her son Toshio were murdered by her jealous husband Takeo, who then killed himself. Peter died shortly after (killed by the ghost of Toshio.) Three years later, Jean was killed, followed by her husband. Yoko arrived and was killed. The mother Emma died (and Karen ended up in the hospital. That evening, Susan (Emma's daughter) died, never having gotten word that her whole family was dead. Alex (Karen's boss) was killed by the ghost of Yoko) and the police inspector was killed by the ghost of the Takeo. Finally, Kayako's ghost killed Karen's boyfriend, and (ultimately) Karen.

OK, so maybe some people prefer our American-style horror films with the blood and gore. Give me Japanese psychological-style of horror anyday. It's much scarier. For one thing, you never known all the story - just enough to leave you knowing that you missed something and you can't always figure out what. The movie stays with you longer.And another thing: Japanese ghosts are a heck of a lot scarier than American ghosts - I mean, how many American ghosts can leave the haunted house to kill someone? And you can't get rid of a Japanese ghost no matter how hard you try.

Review title: Much better than I thought it would be.
Review_body: This was great. When I saw the Japanese version first, it was probably the scariest movie I had ever seen. It was not blood and guts, it was eerie, atmospheric and terrifying. When the mother ghost lent over the bed in the Japanese version, I nearly had a heart attack... I was concerned that the American version would be watered down, and that Buffy would take away from the dark creepy nuances of the original version. I needn't have been concerned. The makers of this movie wisely kept the same Japanese people who were involved with the original movie on hand, and gave the direction of the movie to the same man. They also set it in Japan in the same location, in the same house. In fact, the Japanese director took pains to remake the same movie as it was in the original, the only difference was the casting of American actors. That actually turned into a benefit as it added the element of "Strangers in a Strange Land" to the overall horror. Not only were they being haunted by an absolutely terrifying and relentless ghost, but they were also stuck in a completely foreign land, having difficulty integrating into society. It just added to the overall anxiety built into the movie and I thought it was an excellent touch.Buffy actually does a very good job. She looks vulnerable and is able to convey her fear well. There are none of the smart aleck remarks that are so common to American horror movies, or one liners that detract from the overall darkness and horror of the characters' situation. In fact, it was easily as good as The Ring which I also thoroughly enjoyed. I hope the future of American horror follows more closely the Japanese New Wave of horror started with the incredible success of Ringu. We are finally getting movies that actually can be categorized as "Horror"!! 8/10

The Grudge is one of best ghost movies of the decade. It has scares coming out of every corner. When I first saw it I couldn't sleep for weeks. Sometimes I still can't sleep. Thats what makes this movie so scary and amazing. One of the things that just get to me so much is the main villains death rattle. When I hear something like that I just can't help but feel scared. This movie has gotten to me so much sometimes I can't even cover up at night because of some of the scenes it had. One of the things I didn't like to much was how it kept switching to new people. Besides that the scenery was dark and scary making it the perfect set up for this destructive evil to come for its victims. A must see for horror movie lovers.

Review title: Actually the face of that child is like a real ghost
Review_body: I think the grudge is one of those films that if you watched it back when it was first released then it would have felt terrifying, and it would have seemed a little more unique.The atmosphere is eerie, dark and foreboding. The Japanese cityscape in the background didn't appeal to me much but luckily the backstory and interior setting kept my mind focused on other areas of the film.The Grudge biggest appeal is it's sinister dead woman who's ghastly croaking, sticky movements, crackling limbs, and ominous facial expression really instills a different fear directly into your soul.It's still a terrifying image today and really goes to show that you can forge a truly unique character that becomes iconic and can be built into franchises.As for the story, I did feel a little let down. I mean it was good but wasn't sensational. The appeal about the family, their dark secrets and flashback sequences were the most interesting aspects of the film.I'm not disappointed or enthralled by the the film as a whole. Even though the ending was quite lame. I can't say that I am all too eager to see the next instalment although you never know I might be a little more surprised.6/10.

Little problem for me , i didn't get scared at all watching this movie.
It's quite good considering the plot but in terms of it being a horror movie I won't even scare a ten year old to be honest.
Or it's just me and I don't get scared of anything.
I really enjoyed the movie but if it where scarier and a bit more secretive in terms of the plot I would have given it and 8

The review by Togasaurus I think describes this movies structure and intent best. Americans look for ghosts (spirits) who have a reason for being, an intent, a location and a resolution. On the other hand, the Japanese believe in a more basic animism. The spirit is independent of the person who died and exists as the embodiment of an emotion - in this case rage. The spirits and the atmosphere in which they are revealed is done excellently - but there is no motivation or resolution. They are rage. They are not limited to a location, but can manifest anywhere where the victims happen to be. Supposedly, they pass their rage on to their victims. Their victims then die and new rage spirits are born. The spirits, at least in this movie, are not banished or exorcised. They continue to exist and continue to kill. Most of this is not communicated in The Grudge. You either know the culture or you do not. From what I was reading I guess this rage was passed on to most Americans who saw this movie. Watching The Grudge I felt like I was on the verge of really liking this movie, but was lacking the necessary understanding to do so - a strange feeling. Anyway, this is worth a watch on cable or DVD.

Review title: I hold a grudge.... for watching this movie
Review_body: This movie absolutely did nothing for me. It's another remake of a Japanese film. We had the Ring not too long ago, which was quite possibly the best horror film in recent history. Now, we have this crud. Who in their right mind would actually like this nonsensical garbage. I don't care if these types of movies plots make no sense, but at least have the decency to have a few scares in it. It was crap from the get go. If you want to see some good horror movies, then I suggest you see Poltergeist, The Exorcist, The Ring, A nightmare on elm street part 1 & 3, but definitely not this. Save your money for something better, please, I beg of you!

THE GRUDGE:Type: Slick Hollywood remake of a (better) foreign horror film (see also THE RING).Ingredients: A cast featuring Sarah Michelle Gellar, Grace Zabriskie, Bill Pullman, Ted Raimi, Yoko Maki, William Mapother, Ryo Ishibashi who seem out of place in a Tokyo setting, most of whom converse in English. Confused characters who basically stare at the camera and continue to walk into a house where horrible things happen on a constant basis. A disjointed adapted screenplay by Steven Susco. Aloof direction by Takashi Shimizu who made the original foreign language film called JU-ON: THE GRUDGE (see also THE VANISHING for similar poor results of a director translating his own interesting thriller to the American screen). A decent, though derivative, musical score by Christopher Young. Flat lifeless cinematography by Lukas Ettlin and Hideo Yamamoto. A whole lot of cheap thrills, unpleasant images, musical stings, loud sound effects, poorly integrated special effects, implausible situations and an ending that seems to have been added after multiple test screenings. Side Effects: May cause drowsiness, fatigue, rolling of eyes, nausea, regret at having paid to see the film. Do not operate VCR or DVD equipment in the event that THE GRUDGE is present in home. Viewers may experience a certain feeling of "sameness" if they have seen any horror films prior to THE GRUDGE. Confusion pertaining to what this film is about would not be an uncommon reaction either. A complete lack of interest in the characters (performed by a cast that has very little to do) may cause boredom, or a sense of detachment from the on-screen events. Avoid if relentless gore and violence (in place of any real plot) has a negative effect on you....In fact, my recommendation would be to simply avoid THE GRUDGE altogether.Refills: No thanks.2/10

Review title: "It's not scary, it's Japanese scary!" - Me after the movie
Review_body: Now, lets review scary... Texas Chainsaw Massacre was scary in 2003, but that was then, right before the Ring came out. That was the first Japanese movie to come out in full charge. Not many before succeeded as well. The Ring started a whole line of extreme horror films, such as: When Darkness Falls, The Village, and now The Grudge.The Grudge wasn't anything you haven't seen before, to be honest. It's not just scary, it's Japanese scary. Most American made films don't compete against Japanese films, they just don't, sorry to say. They think everything through, knowing that we won't understand. Then when we watch it, and see that half of it is in Japanese, we become confused and don't believe it's a good movie. The Grudge was a cry for attention really, to compete with the Ring.5 out of 10, nothing good, nothing bad. Very scary, but is becoming redundant. There will be a new horror film out soon trying to take this movie over. It won't be too hard, seeing as the ending for The Grudge made all the faces of the audience scrunch up in a "what the hell" sort of look. Go find out why, but do not expect your money back after sitting through the whole thing.Worth seeing when bored, or wanting to scare a friend.

Review title: uuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuu. Yes, that was my attempt of the noise...
Review_body: I'm still not convinced about this film. I mean yes it had the desired effect but it didn't chill me to the bone like people say it has. It was weird because the funny noise made me feel a tad sick, it wasn't scary but I did feel a little uneasy after watching it. I watched it with ten of my 13year-old friends and half of them thought it was silly and un-scary, the other half are afraid to get in bed because they are afraid that they will get pulled under by the Grudge... I thought that it was really just someone mindlessly killing people with no story-line. Overall I would say that The Grudge is a good film if you want cheap scares and an unimaginative story. I would give it a 7.5/10.

Review title: Not as good as I hoped
Review_body: After seeing reviews and just the overall things I heard of this film, I was hyped for it. Sadly I got let down, but it wasn't bad or anything. It was a pretty enjoyable film, to just watch on a friday night after work or something, it's nothing special in my opinion. It wasn't really scary or anything either.

Review title: No matter what people said, I enjoyed this one a lot!
Review_body: I just saw this movie last night, and despite all the people saying this movie sucks, I really liked it. Sure you guess what happened and how the cursed began and all, but still it gives you a lot of good scares and stuff.It's about this girl, Karen (Sarah Michelle Geller, not great but she wasn't bad either), who is assigned to go and take care of an old lady, replacing a Japanese girl who was missing. Anyways all kinds of weird stuff starts happening in that house to everybody who gets involved with it.Like I said, Sarah Michelle Geller is pretty acceptable in this role as Karen, she does manage to get scared and all, but we still see "Buffy" when she's facing scary stuff, that's not very cool. Bill Pullman is there for like 10 minutes, but anyways I thought he did OK, and everybody else in the cast, special mention to the Japanese actors/actresses.Anyhow, if you feel like watching a movie that I'm sure it'll give you a good scare at least once, please rent this movie :) ***1/2 out of *****

So here we have a new trend in Hollywood: remaking Japanese horror films with American actors. The only problem in doing this with The Grudge, is that they couldn't really just redo it word-for-word like The Ring because the story is so open-ended that it wouldn't have been 'well-accepted' by American audiences. I have seen the original Grudge, titled Ju-On, and was a fan of it, mainly because it incites so much discussion because it's confusing and erratic. These are actually good things about that movie though because you really 'choose-your-own-ending' in your mind.Now in the American version, we have a very neat, pat, and, somewhat disappointing, ending. The scary images of the original are still the same and I really enjoyed the directors' cool horror shots. The lightening and sound effects are just horror movie perfection! Still, the story was just lacking something for me and there isn't much to discuss when the movie is over. Out theater was full of teens though who actually SCREAMED during the film. It's been awhile since I've heard actual screaming, so it does provide some good terror. I know I jumped as well. If you're a fan of horror, I'd say it's worth the price of a matinée.

I made the BIG mistake, i bought this movie, first week it was released £15.99 and if i could turn back the clock, I WOULD! it was awesomely terrible to say the least.If your after a good remake of a Japanese horror, LOOK FURTHER, and buy the Ring, Naomi Watts.This movie was so poor to say the least, i was hoping to see better from Sarah Michelle Gellar, Lovely looking minx but she was so poor, the whole direction this movie took went from bad to worst. On a good point about the movie it would have to be the Gorgeous looks of KaDee Strickland, but her part was way to short.

Review title: Very, very, very, very, scary. Very, very, very, very good.
Review_body: *** out of **** The Grudge is definitely one of the scariest movies ever made. The images of the dead spirits were so disturbing, I couldn't even move. The plot was so serious and scary, I couldn't even think straight. The music was so chilling, I had to wear a jacket to keep myself warm. Seriously. And the acting was so good, I applauded after the movie was over. 8 out of 10.The Grudge is scarier than The Hills Have Eyes. Scarier than The Ring. More terrifying than Darkness Falls. And way more frightening than The Exorcist.The acting was pitch perfect from everyone. Even the foreign actors were brilliant. They really understood the English way of acting, if you know what I mean. Takashi Shimizu, the director of The Grudge, did a totally awesome job with directing the film. Every Japenese person that worked on the film. They also really understood the English way of producing and directing films.SEE THE GRUDGE! SEE THE GRUDGE! SEE THE GRUDGE! SEE THE GRUDGE! 8 out of 10Original MPAA rating: PG-13: Mature Thematic Material, Disturbing Images/Terror/Violence, and Some Sensuality.My MPAA rating: PG-13: Mature Thematic Material, Disturbing Images, Some Intense Terror and Violence, Some Language and Sensuality.My Canadian Rating: 14A: Violence, Frightening Scenes, Disturbing Content, Mature ThemeMy Canadian Rating for the Unrated Version: 18A: Violence, Frightening Scenes, Disturbing Content, Mature Theme

Holy cow, I see a lot of bad movies, but it's been a long time since one was this awful. There is literally nothing redeeming about this movie - I kept looking at the clock and asking myself when something would actually happen, other than the pitiful not-scary ghost nonsense I'm watching. After 90 minutes, it was over, and I was left wondering what nonsense I sat through: jump scares, not-really-scary sounds, an incomprehensible story about some deaths in a house that created a ghost?!Not scary.
Not funny.
Not interesting.
Not gory.
Not exciting.BORING.

I've seen a lot of horror movies. A LOT. 99.9% of them can't even make a single goose bump stand up on my arm. This movie for whatever reason just has my number. I've seen the original and the sequels to it but they just didn't do much for me. This movie gets it right for some reason. I couldn't get it out of my head the first time I saw it. This movie currently is the only movie I've ever seen where I closed my eyes while watching it. Out of probably 500-1000 horror movies that I've seen. The reason why I only give it an 8 is because the movie itself isn't all that well put together. It earns the 8 by pure scares alone. This movie took someone who watches movies like: Inside, Excision, High Tension, The Decent, Martyrs and turned that person into a little b*tch. That's right; this movie made me it's b*tch. Don't know exactly why this movie scares me but oh boy does it ever.

Wow, what a total let down! The fact people think this film is scary is ridiculous. The special effects were a direct rip-off of "The ring." The story? Was there one? Not in my opinion..Just a bunch of flashy imaging. The entire film was a boring, stupid, mess. I guess there is always a market for bad films with good marketing campaigns. However, this is the worst horror film I have seen in years. And that Buffy chick? Well, she's a bad actress! As plastic as Barbie and just as talented..No, wait, that would be an insult to the talents of Barbie! I suppose many kiddies helped this film at the box office as it was PG-13, and had it been rated R, it would have bombed IMO! Stupid movie!

Review title: It's still good after so many years
Review_body: With the new release of The Grudge, I went back and rewatched this original to see if it was as good as I had remembered.Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar) lives in Japan and works as a caretaker for the elderly people. Getting assigned a job, Karen visits the elder lady and begins to discover some unusual and mysterious behaviour coming from the house. After leaving the house, things become haunting for Karen with everywhere she goes and discovers a dark history of the house.Honestly, for a film that came out in 2004, it's pretty good. I mean watching it now, the graphics aren't amazing, but again the film is 16 years old. I remember when the film came out that a lot of people said the original Japanese version was terrifying, but I still think this one is scary.SMG was such an A Lister when this came out, after staring in Buffy and many other iconic movies, everyone knew who she was. She's not bad in the film, except when she runs like she's still in Buffy lolStill would recommend this film to fans of horror. It's a great watch

Without comparing it to the original series, The Grudge - on its own - simply doesn't stand up as a good horror movie. The director - whose manner of flashing back was very jarring and confusing - did nothing to set the scene and give us a sense of WHY everything was happening (of course we already knew it was a Grudge, because the trailer did a better job of informing us than the director did). When the spirits made their appearances and were menacing someone, the scenes appeared to be totally without context and only seemed like something cool the director had come up with during filming - "Hey, let's try this thing out!" The spirits were very spooky, but very poorly used. I imagine all of this has something to do with "Americanizing" the Japanese series, but liked both Ringu and The Ring quite a lot so I don't know. I can't recommend The Grudge at all.

The grudge stars Sarah Michelle Gellar as a woman dealing with a house in dire need of therapy. A tragedy happened there a while back and the house just refuses to let the anger go and move on. Basically, it's a slow moving movie, almost exactly like its predecessor, using the same sets and some of the same stars as well. Unfortunately the first movie wasn't that good either, but because it was original I gave it a higher rating than this version. One of my reasons being that the scariest moment in the first movie is about the only scene not duplicated in this remake (that of a woman staring down on the lady in bed while Toshio scratches his legs at the foot of it, as seen in the previews of the original.) Anyway, to sum things up,"The Grudge" has potential to be scary, but it's rather like an excellent set of blueprints drawn in crayon. Something's seriously wrong here.

The Grudge is obviously similar to the ring in many ways. Long black hair... freaky looking eyes and a deadly story behind it. Revolving around a cursed house based in Japan, (as you expect there's a lot of subtitles as they speak but other than that its pretty easy to follow...)a woman tracks down the origin of what happened to a ghostly boy and a freaky ghost..The film overall is very chilling the first time watching but then it doesn't seem as scary when you know when the jumpy bits are coming. Apart from the cheesy screeches and boring police scenes this is one to watch.

A remake of a Japanese film of the same name by the same director of the previous year, THE GRUDGE focuses on an American nurse (Sarah Michelle Gellar) who visits a mysterious house with a curse brought on by its rather vicious past. In a way, this was like "The Ring", which happens to be another Japanese movie. However, this was a little weird in terms of presentation.Still effective, not to mention imaginative, but seemed to get a little silly at times. When the effective scenes did come, though, they were definitely chilling. The ending was a little disappointing, too. Then again, it's a horror movie and not a fairy tale.In other words, despite being weird, this film is worth a look. The stylish direction adds to the eeriness felt throughout.

The Grudge is a horror movie in a style that has become quite popular to players of horror video games out of Japan. For anyone who has played Fatal Frame II, or a game in the Silent Hill series, this movie has that same send of creepy foreboding that can give you goosebumps. Like the games, "The Grudge" does not lay out a direct but often ridiculous premise like American horror movies. There is no lakeside retreat that has been the sight of a countless slaughters of college kids over the years but just happens to attract one more group of kids who seems intent on being the next victims. In the case of "The Grudge" we only know that there is a house, a very very strange house, and that anyone who happens to enter this house begins to experience their own private horror. We do not know why at first, tho as the movie progresses the reasons are explained through a series of glimpses into past events. I was pleased to see that even the flashbacks are handled in a truly frightening way. The movie didn't scare me, rather I found it wickedly creepy and suspenseful. Others in the audience were truly frightened, as I saw it in a very full house, and heard more genuine screams of fear then I have heard in a theater in many years. The atmosphere of the movie was superb. There were many times you did not want to have to watch the actors take another step forward into that dark room at the end of the hall. The setting in Japan worked well for me, as I liked the disconnected hopelessness of the largely western cast trying to come to terms with a strange culture and instead facing a nightmare that they cannot begin to fathom.If you are expecting "Nightmare on Elm Street Part 14" or "Scary Movie 12" then this one may not be for you. This is not all hack and slash with lots of gratuitous violence. However, if you like atmospheric horror movies, and especially if you like stylized Japanese horror, then you will appreciate this movie. The director does not even try to answer all the questions that arise, but the lack of rational explanations to the horrific events which take place actually add to the overall sense of dread.

This movie is really nothing besides an admittedly well-crafted series of tense sequences punctuated with an inevitable "gotcha!" at the end of each. Really, there is no character development and no real plot to speak of. There are only the most skeletal of motivations for the characters to do anything while they trudge forward to their unavoidable dooms. It's all just an excuse to show a creepy ghost kid (who seems to have gotten some of the family cat mixed up in his ectoplasm) and his ghost mom (with long black hair hanging in her face kind of like "The Ring") take down a bunch of cardboard cut-out, two-dimensional excuses for human characters.This English-language version of "The Grudge" is the equivalent of cinematic junk food; satisfying momentarily, but not really what you ought to be living on.Not recommended.

The viewing experience in "The Grudge" is almost identical to "The Ring." In neither movie is there really much of a payoff for the viewer at the end in terms of actually bothering to take care of any of the loose ends. I thought both films were "jumpers" that had me in goosebumps at times ... for the first few instances that called for it.
