It's really funny to see the people at the theater scraming i was laughing so hard when my friend was screaming. But if you like to get scared you should watch this movie, or if you like to see other people get scared. I don't think I'll go to see the sequel. This movie wouldn't be scary in the daytime though. The plot wasn't that good, but not many scary movies have good plots. I give this movie 5 out of 10, because it's scary but doesn't have a plot or reason they all die. It would get more if it wasn't so confusing.Me : Yeah, that's my neighbors review.... enjoy.

There was nothing worth noting in this film, and no reason to go out of your way to see it.In order for a horror movie to work it needs at least one of the following: 1) Actual scares. 2) Gore/interesting deaths. 3) Characters you either fear for or identify with. 4) Interesting sets. 5) Tension as to what characters will live and what will die.This film had none of the above. There were no scares. There was no gore. The characters had no depth and no personality. The set was a typical Japanese home with no character. You know immediately who will be left standing in the final moments, and therefore never feel tension when anyone is in trouble - you already know the outcome.The movie begins with promise. The colors and angles will feel familiar if you saw the Ring, but it begins with promise, giving a mysterious death and a very creepy child. It doesn't last, though. You soon realize that the deaths happen off camera and are usually unexplained. You realize the main ghost is a very confused looking Japanese woman with a facial expression that is supposed to be terror but is so over the top it's pure humor. And you'll realize the characters have no purpose other than to die. None of them say anything interesting, none have any unique characteristics. You could take the lines from one mouth and put them in another without noticing.*minor spoiler* The end is terrible, too. The ghost gets a character face to face, inches away, but saves the character instead of killing the character. Of course, this doesn't stop the ghost from stalking the character and giving the "surprise" in the end. Why didn't it just kill the character when it had the chance? *end spoiler*A movie with a decent concept but terrible, dull, and mindless execution. There's nothing confusing, nothing mysterious, nothing disturbing, nothing scary, nothing intelligent, and mostly nothing interesting to be seen in this movie.

i watched this movie expecting (and hoping?) to see something like The Ring. I was greatly mistaken. This movie's plot makes absolutely no sense and relies completely on their special effects to make it qualify as a "horror." It is not in the least scary and every single slightly scary scene is exactly what you see on the trailer. Actually, this whole movie is like a long trailer because the scary scenes all have NO CONTEXT. they just appear out of nowhere and then they're gone. you don't even understand why they really happened.why is it so hard to make a good horror movie? i was hoping for much better things with this movie. if you're a horror movie junkie, you'll find this movie a big flop. if you hate horror and are easily rattled, this might be a good movie to start with, you probably won't get too scared.

Review title: Most certainly not what I expected
Review_body: Like most people I had heard that The Grudge was an over-rated waste of film. But since Sarah Michelle Gellar starred in it and I loved Buffy I figured okay I'll watch it. Well the opening was pretty stupid, but after that it got better. I ended up watching the movie through my pillow! The special effects were outstanding, and the direction was very good. The only draw backs were that it was pretty predictable and that the performances weren't particularly memorable. Gellar's role was down right forgettable. How ever this is one of those rare instances where the story and effects more than compensated any other lack luster qualities of the film. Naturally the end hints at and impending sequel which I will most likely rent when it comes out.

Review title: Not Extremely Scary, but Still a Good Movie
Review_body: I have seen both the regular version and the unrated directors cut. First of all, If you are going to watch this movie then do yourself a favor and see the directors' cut version.The Grudge is a remake of the Japanese movie "Ju-On: The Grudge", both versions of the film were directed by the same man, marking the first time that an American remake of a Japanese movie was directed by the same person. The Grude tells the tale of a house in Japan. Everyone who enters this house ends up dead not too long afterward, simple enough. They are killed by the two "ghosts", a mother and her son, who were murdered in the house. Most American movies that involve haunted houses and ghosts have their killings limited to a certain range (such as the haunted house) in The Grudge the two "ghosts" are not retained by any limits they can strike anywhere at anytime. Another difference between most American horror movies is that the person who is killed is usually guilty of something, in The Grudge all that the victims have done is simply enter the wrong house at the wrong time.Sarah Michelle Gellar does a pretty good job as do the rest of the actors, the only standout is by a Japanese actor, who plays the part of the lead detective investigating the house.The story is told a a good pace and the backstory of who the "ghosts" are and why they are is explained pretty well. This is somewhat of a "jump-out-and-say-booo!" movie, but isn't extremely scary, its good story however makes it a good movie.

Now this is really what I think Hollywood should spend all their huge resources on! This is a plot that takes place far away from LA, NYC and Miami, with all the usual stereotypes we usually are fed from there. And that makes all the difference. Not only because of all the Japanese only talk going on, but also because this obviously is a very alien situation, that the movie characters has found themselves in.In this movie we have a Sarah Michelle Gellar, that has distanced herself from her usual Buffy character, and actually demonstrates that she can act also as not being a Vampire Slayer.The scares are, if not all too original, enough to make you choke on your midnight drink, and I don't think you should watch this movie alone.

After seeing "ju-on" i really get disappointed, why?, because is really weird and is not even scary. The i really was specking "the grudge", and i went to see the movie in the opening day, i was really scared, this version is very creepy, Sarah Michelle Gellar is amazing on this film, her character is original, but that's not everything, the ghost of the movie is the best part, the kid it was not scary, in fact it was really insignificant, but the mother, Kayako was very, very creepy, the best, just seeing the beginning of the film and you already can't sleep in night.A very good horror film, much better than the ring, with a lot of spooky scenes, specially the bed sequence, you' re not gonna forget that, believe me.8/10

The basis behind The Grudge is that there's a Japanese myth that when a person dies (typically murder or some type of passionate context), a curse exists in that space that continues to haunt anyone who gets involved. This curse follows the individual until they die.The Grudge is supposedly made shot for shot with the Japense version. To jump to my summary, the film does a terrific job in building suspense and making you feel incredibly uneasy. The sound effects are great! While the plot doesn't make entirely too much sense, it's believable, for the moment.Karen (a very convincing Sarah Michelle Gellar, I'm no Buffy fan) is a transplant to Japan. She lives there with her boyfriend. Karen attends a local university and does community work for experience. Her work is helping housebound elders. Karen helps an elderly woman who is frightened by a mysterious force (the curse). The backstory unfolds, about the house, that involves a Professor (Bill Pullman) who is indirectly involved in a death. The movie does a lot of flashbacks but is effective.Not as good as The Ring but worth a DVD rental.

.I watched this movie in the theater when it came out and it scared me so bad I barely remember what happens. I remember the first scene vividly. Every thing else is a blur. I'm watching it again now 16 years later with my wife and it's just as scary now.

Review title: Interesting Remake, with a dark atmosphere
Review_body: Most people would disagree with my rating of 8/10 because they say that 'The Grudge' is not a very scary horror film, but even though the movie itself is not very terrifying up-front, but it has much more stored inside...The movie starts with sort of a strange opening that leaves you confused and shocked, but all the more pleased. After the opening to the movie the plot only gets better with the blinding suspense & intertwined stories that keep you wandering until the every end where it all meets together.The acting for this film is not the greatest there could be, but i think Sarah Michelle pulls her role off quite well. Aside from the acting, the plot is very good because it never really just jumps out and says what's going on in the film, and that is why I like it, because it keeps you guessing and surprised but at the same time very entertained. I must admit the movie itself is not very horrifying the way it is presented but the very dark & strange atmosphere is what does it for me, making the story seem far more terrifying than ever.Overall, this film is no "Oscar Contender" but it delivers what is expected of a Hollywood horror film, with an even darker setting which emphasized the scare effect, and is very good for what it is.Final Grade:: 8/10 \ B+

I admit, this movie starts off a little slowly and at first you aren't sure whether your watching a poorly attempted comedy or a horror movie. About ten minutes in though you get your answer and are glad you've donated your time and hard earned cash to see this movie. The acting can be a little underwhelming at times but the script, and style of the film more than make up for it. Like "The Sixth Sense" this movie does not rely on blood and gore to achieve it's scares, but instead uses more subtle psychological scares. The story-telling style reminds me of "Memento" and is very well done. You are unsure exactly what has occurred and why until the last few minutes of the movie. For anyone needs a good, thought-provoking scare I'd recommend this film.

the grudge wasn't as good as i was hoping for, but was really good for plot. the best Japanese horror i have ever seen. quite a lot of moments that make you jump..that is probably the best thing about this film, so prepare yourself for a nerve beating! brilliant performance from Sarah Michelle Gellar! quite hard to understand at times with the flashbacks as you couldn't quite tell if they were flashbacks or not, but if you watch it more than once you just manage to understand the gist of it. mostly an enjoyable film.Seriously scary stuff8/10

Review title: A Very Scary Film But Still Great
Review_body: I thought this was a brilliant film, it was scary but enjoying and had a very good plot, somethings didn't quite add up to me though, as everyone who enters the house is meant to die but yet some people left the house unharmed. I watch the Japanese version which wasn't as good by far in my opinion even though it was the original, as i found it very hard to understand, I've watch the grudge 2 (Japanese) as well it has a good plot too and isn't quite as hard to understand as the first Japanese one so I'm looking forward to the grudge 2 American one.I think this film is great over all, brilliant acting and story but id keep a cushion to hide behind if you get scared easily like me.

Do you like intelligently-written suspense and horror films? Then the Grudge is not for you. This film has a paper-thin plot, barely makes sense, shoddy-looking special effects, overused flashbacks, lackluster performances, and ultimately makes The Ring look like a masterpiece. Bill Pullman was grossly underutilized, albeit scanty screen-time was written that way in the script for him. I just can't believe Sam Raimi produced this film, because even the Evil Dead films blow this film away. I was one of three people in the theater viewing this film, and the other two left before the film was over. Stay far, far away from this movie. It is definitely not worth shelling out money for. This film leaves too many unanswered questions, including why this film was made.

What is with Japanese people using water, flies, and freaky looking children in their movies.This movie reminds me of The Ring, which was another lousy Japanese horror picture. The Ring would have been great if not for the ending. But we're not talking about The Ring, we're talking about The Grudge. Although the two movies have a similar plot, this movie differs in that instead of a video tape killing people, its a house. A man murdered his wife and child in his house and the emotions stil inhabit the home. Karen Davis (Sarah Michelle Gellar) works for a nursing home and visits the house frequently. Everyone who enters this house winds up dead. The wife and child who were murdered are the main spooks in this film. The little boy doesn't do much but is quite terrifying. The woman is the one that causes people to die. I'm sure anyone could compare the two movies (The Grudge and The Ring) and make a list of how the two are alike, from the girl messing with the security cameras, to the bathtub scenes and flooding water. I gave this movie 4 stars because there is nothing special about it. I have not seen the original, but I presume since it was done by the same director as Ju-On, that this is just another remake that has been ruined by Hollywood.

Review title: Fans of Japanese Horror, will be surprised with Hollywoods attempt.
Review_body: With the release of the Grudge 2 in the Uk, I was looking forward to the continuation of the story. Director Takashi Shimizu is back again to continue what was started with the Grudge. In the Grudge, it is said that the rage and fury left in a house will last an eternity, getting stronger and stronger down through the ages....or words to that effect. The first film introduced us to the story and was set and shot in Tokyo and stared Sarah Michelle Geller of Buffy fame. Fans of the original Japanese films would have probably found the Hollywood versions a little watered down, but for the likes of me, who had never seen the Japanese versions, I watched them not expecting anything but a horror film. The second film opened the story up a little further and answered a few questions that remained unanswered in the first. The Director gave us the Hollywood slant but left enough of the Japanese element in it to keep the purists happy. The second film is without a doubt brilliant and horror fans will find enough shocks and jumps to keep the average bed wetter wet for decades.A+ For effort.

Review title: It's difficult to be frightened if a film just confuses you.
Review_body: It's difficult to be frightened if a film just confuses you. Maybe it lost something in translation, but a series of disconnected and apparently unexplained episodes between different characters that don't seem to have much to do with one another didn't have the hairs standing up on the back of my neck. Sure, sure, it has the scary stop-frame animation girl from The Ring, but random pools of water, small children with white-painted faces, and a hairpiece that drags itself across the floor just doesn't it for me.In the end I gave up & read the synopsis (above). I guess it sort-of explains the film, although it just seems like a bit of a lame excuse for filming several short stories without bothering to tie them together properly.

The Grudge was basically what a normal remake is: copying the original with nothing new added to it. The Grudge followed Ju-On very well actually and included some scenes from the video version. However, the acting was the first thing that disappointed me, since they were nowhere near the acting of the Japanese people.Even though The Grudge followed the original very well, it later becomes its biggest flaw. It becomes way too predictable. You already know what's going to happen. And on top of that, when the remade scene is finally shown, it's not as good as the original because the atmosphere is all missing. Instead, it's only a scary face scaring the audience. This is the main difference between American horror and foreign horror. American horror focuses on scaring, while foreign focuses of mood. Masterpieces of horror like Ju-On should best be left alone.But then again, the movie was still successful on scaring people. Worth borrowing, not worth buying. 5/10

Review title: Scared the s**t out of me!
Review_body: I know that a lot of people would say that the American copy of The Ring is a much better horror movie and I agree BUT this film scared me so bad and I'm not alone. The Ring is more clever and more interesting but it doesn't scare me as much. I was sitting on needles the whole time and my girlfriend was covering her eyes most of the film. The Ring is better while build up the suspense and the ending is brilliant but even though I was scared, it couldn't scare me as much as that white face coming crawling down the stares or the scene with the sister...horrifying. The Grudge is by far the scariest film I have ever seen and I can't wait to see the original.

Review title: Good for scaring little girls, not much else.
Review_body: What can we say...Japanese horror is the latest fad to run through our cinemas. Ever since The Ring did so well, we are seeing an increasing shift toward this type of horror film. These films feature creepy and mysterious characters, neo-Gothic type cinematography, spooky atmospheres, and plenty of tactical cinematic scares. The Grudge, however, doesn't pull it all off so well. The film presents with all of the aforementioned elements, but it lacks appeal and interest. The story is absolutely uninteresting, and the underlying premise is cliché (a house is haunted by the spirits of a family that ended in a murder/suicide type of affair). Even as simple as the story may be, it still doesn't even really make sense, like in the way the characters are connected. What you really get from this movie are two things: exposition and scare tactics; when you're not seeing one, you're seeing the other. So, there's nothing really interesting about the story; it barely makes sense. We're left with just a bag of scary cinema tricks. Nothing better than you're typical B-movie.

Review title: Scary at times but utterly pointless
Review_body: The ambiance is there, and the movie does offer some good scares, but all in all it is flat and uneven. There are some great performances, Kadee Strickland's Susan stands out, but overall the movie doesn't offer enough backdrop in the characters' lives to actually care about them. Sarah Michelle Gellar is a good scream queen, and poised to take the title away from Jamie Lee Curtis any year now, after all she stole the spotlight in I Know What You Did Last Summer and Scream 2. In the end, I felt ripped off of a story, there seems to be no story what-so-ever and the thought of getting a sequel on the way is just stupid, it didn't work for The Ring (which was actually one of the best horror movies to come out of the last decade) why should it work for a knock off?

I was watching The Grudge this past weekend while I was drunk and stoned with my cousins! When I first saw it, it was at the theater and I didn't find it scary or anything. The audience,however, kept screaming the whole way through. I told the audience to shut up. This past weekend though, I was so captivated by that one scene with Bill Pullman scared like hell in his house and finding the boy curled up like a ball. Ted Raimi's death scene was possibly the best part. Ted slipping by the stares was so startling I couldn't resist. No other horror movie I've seen in the past has been scary except this one. I give it a 7/10 next to "what lies beneath"

Review title: Great trailer, but movie wasn't even a near miss.
Review_body: I can usually tell a good movie from the trailers. I guess it was the little kid screaming like a cat that hooked me. Well the movie just isn't scary. You've seen it all before, and done better in other movies. The non-linear style of story telling has been done better by others. It's pretty funny how the movie jumps around trying to explain how we go from point a to point b, sadly by the time you get to point b you just say "huh?"My wife and I saw "The Forgotten" 10 minutes after seeing "The Grudge". We both thought the car crash scene in "The Forgotten" was scarier than the whole "The Grudge" movie.The trailer would have been more helpful if at the end it had said, "Coming to a $5 Wal-Mart DVD display near you!"

Review title: One of the worst films of all time!!!!
Review_body: This film is complete garbage. This could very well be the worst movie I have ever seen (I have even seen Bogeyman). This movie lacks suspense, creativity, and scary scenes. It is a horror movie that is not scary at all. A ghost boy opens his mouth and meows like a pet cat, creepy. A ghost girl makes sounds like she is clearing her throat, spine tingling. An old lady, who is also supposed to be creepy, says nothing the whole time she is in the film. She supposed to be frightening and mysterious with red circles around her eyes, but she simply comes across as stupid and annoying. I want my hour and a half back of my life I wasted watching this film. Why did Bill Pullman kill himself in the beginning??? Why did the police detective try to help the ghost boy when he knew ghosts were in the house. Why did this movie ever get made??? How did some of the viewers enjoy this???

The Grudge provided a very nice cheap thrill- the images were frightening, and the surprises were apt to make the audience jump. However, the lack of a decent story completely ruined this film for me. It's relatively easy to scary an audience with creepy images and sounds, but the way that these things will stay with the audience is if there is a convincing plot line. It needed to be cemented with a good story. There were too many plot holes, plus the fact that the story in itself was pretty weak, to make this a long-lasting impact. Also, I felt that much of the scary images were taken from The Ring and Ringu, so it wasn't very original for me.

Quite simply, this movie wasn't scary at all. Maybe to teenage girls and little kids. The characters seemed really stupid and a lot of the stuff they did made no sense. I know that's to be expected in this type of movie , but this was ridiculous! The ending was kind of predictable as well. A lot of the "scares" in this were just silly. You could see most of them coming a mile away. I jumped once in the whole entire movie and that was at a part where they just threw one in at a very random time. The FX were OK, but they weren't anything outstanding. The acting was about what you would expect from this kind of movie. Overall I think it was a pretty poor excuse for a thriller. All seasoned horror fans should avoid this one at all costs. 3/10

I live in Switzerland and travel to Austria to see a movie in English language once a week. Its a fun thing to do because the film is always a 'Sneak' not yet on release film in Austria. Its also a surprise movie, so no-one knows what they are going to get till the curtain goes up. This is fine because it forces me to watch films I would never usually see out of choice. As always, the 'Sneak' was well attended with a starting audience of about 150. I was a bit doubt full about the film from the kick off, I mean, a lot of Japanese names on the opening credits and some non Japanese actors I never heard of... but I figured lets hang in and see what happens... Ten minutes into the movie, after a great deal of audience laughter the exodus started... twos and threes to start with then a steady flow with me almost wondering if there might be a fire back there when they found the jawbone in the roof space. As the final credits rolled a glanced over my shoulder (I like to sit in the front) and to my amazement saw that there were just 3 of us left! Thats right.. 3! I mean the move was bad... very bad.. but never in 40 years of regular movie going had I experienced anything like this. I found the effects passable at best, the direction a joke, the acting wooden and the script writer should do the honourable thing and fall on his sword... by the way.. if you saw the movie... don't you think the monster with the long lack hair and white skin looked familiar? Awooooooo!

Review title: Good Horror Films Are For HORROR--NOT "Touching Story lines"
Review_body: Seriously, people. Read that title again, and get a grip. Or, better yet, go out and see a DRAMA if you want "pristine storytelling".I will make an incredibly long story short--THIS MOVIE CREEPED THE UTTER HELL OUT OF ME. And no, I am NOT one who "scares" easily by horror films. Usually, I find them intriguing and humorous (hence, I decided to go check this one out for some Halloween fun)--and boy, was THAT a mistake (in a good way, mind you ;)).I was not only shaken, I was downright DISTURBED by the images the director presented to us. Freaky and bizarre, it seemed he never, EVER gave you "a rest" where shocking moments are concerned. Once the spooky stuff in the film strikes, there is NO turning back.And these are images that literally haunt you LONG after you leave the theater. Plaguing your mind with paranoia and uneasy thoughts as you lie in bed at night. I am in my mid twenties, and let me tell you, the "night-light" made it's first appearance again, in years.'Lo and behold, THAT, my friends, is why this is SUCH an effective horror film. Genuine eerieness and threats of turning your "places of safety and sanctuary" into your worst nightmares--the stuff bad dreams are made of.I will end by once again saying that GOOD *horror* films are ones that SCARE you--not impress you by their intricate story lines. Because we all know, if those "stupid people" never "went back into the house"....there would be no story at all, would there?

I recently watched this movie at a friend's sleepover, and, I have to admit, I was nervous of seeing it. The trailers made it look scary, right? But, I found that it was one of the worst movies I have ever seen! I am 13, and I was not in the least bit scared!The acting was terrible, the special effects were crap, the story was impossible and there were about 6 lines in the whole film!I can't believe Sarah Michelle- Gellar got paid millions of dollars to look around nervously and have a pretty hair-do!!! True, it made me jump when Kayako's, eyes suddenly flashed up on the scene, but that was about it. To be fair, the idea behind it all was a good one, but it was presented so badly that this didn't come across. People, if you want classy chills, watch The Others. If you want a piece of crap, watch The Grudge!3 out of 10

move away your popcorn, leave the drinks. you won't sit through the movie without you're hair raising the ceiling time after time again. the whole thing playing in Tokyo is spooky. and the most scariest is that this time evil won't stay in one place. but it is like a virus once infected, you'll take evil with you to you're own house, and it will stay with you throughout the day. there is simply no place you'll be safe again!!! defiantly one of the most scarrie movie i've seen in a long time. even "the ring" seems a children's movie in comparing. one tip, you have to see this movie in full Dolby digital surround because that is going to tribute to the fear, at the end there is only one word... phoooofff!!!!

i want to give this a 0, but alas, there is no such thing.A decent plot and idea that turns out to be yet another boring, anti-climatic "horror" film.i had three attractive girls basically in my lap (i went the opening and it was packed, so i used some charm) and i still managed to fall asleep between their feminine squeals over hack-neyed camera angles and set-ups for "scares".the boy/cat meow thing was below retarded.It came out in 2004, i just remembered it today surfing around IMDb, and my brain hurts because of it.

Review title: I want those 2 hours of my life BACK!
Review_body: My husband and I went to see this movie, being the horror movie buffs that we are. Two hours later I found myself wanting both my money and time back. I was so disappointed. The teasers for this film basically contained the best points of the film. There was nothing very scary about the film other than good timing on surprise entrances, etc. I found most of the 'scary' parts to be more comical than anything. After viewing other movies based on the works of Japanese writers, I have to conclude that what is deemed frightening in Japan is not what is frightening here in the US. My advice: If you are a fan of true horror movies, save yourself the pain of sitting through this one. I can't really say that I would recommend renting it either, unless you have a free rental coming to you.

When the end credits rolled I thought, "That's it?" The line about a curse from an enraged death is consistent with Japanese cultural sensibilities but the spirits following everybody around I believe is off the mark. I had hoped for a greater confrontation between the spirits and one of the main characters towards the end of the movie leading to the spirits (at least temporary) pacification. Nakagawa should have brought in a Buddhist monk or something.I also find an annoyance with foreigners in Tokyo movies. The gal poking a hole in the ramen at the store and sniffing it. What the heck?

Review title: In my personal opinion this film is a good horror film whit a lot of mystery
Review_body: This is a film of the horror mystery The principal protagonist is a Saras Michelle Grellar in the part of Karen Davis She is a young women who work take care of old person .She go at the house of a old woman and in this house occupy a course because tho his woman and his son. At the young woman himself appear the son.The actor and actress principals are:Saras Michelle Gellar- Karen Davis . Jason Beln- Doug W. Mapathr- M.Wilians Clea Duvall- JenniferYoko Maki- Yoko Director- Takashi Shimizu
Held a screening of this film and really enjoyed it and got scared with my friends!

Yes, I was very tired when I watched this. This movie couldn't keep me awake long enough. I kept falling asleep.They could cut this movie short to about 20-30 minutes. All that happens there is more of the same. People just keep dying the same way throughout a large portion of the movie. The point of the movie was boring too. It was somewhat ridiculous, in a bad way (as opposed to "Scream" where it was somewhat funny).It was weird. Things didn't make too much sense.There weren't too many dialogs either. It didn't make me keep guessing who is the killer. I couldn't have any idea it was what it was, and it was not interesting either.I don't like giving bad reviews. Usually, I don't.

there is one certain peculiarity to this film. If the grudge is passed on to those who are killed, how come none of the Americans in the film go bad? I mean, this is purely nice American white middle class couples slashed by crazy Japanese - that's why this film is so totally not scary - whereas the ring made everything scary, from TV sets to coffee mugs, this one swims around in the typical American Angst for the Other. Yep - this film is one of many indications that McCarthyism is re-entering the stage of American pop culture, and it sure doesn't help much that the director is Japanese, and that Sarah is Jewish - she's not even good looking in this film.

I WILL NOT watch this movie again and I have no desire to see the upcoming Grudge 2. For the reason that The Grudge scared the hell out of me.However there are other reasons that I wont watch it again aside from being scared senseless. I also didn't like it, I think mainly because I couldn't understand it and even though the plot deals with a lot of back story there are no real answers to questions about what happened to get all of this started in the first place or why these evil murderous spirits came into being.Kayako(the female spirit) SHE WAS SCARY, there was nothing about her that wasn't scary from the way she looked and the way she moved to the sound she made....SHE WAS FREAKEN SCARY. I have the understanding that there was no computerized special effects that was used with her and that the actress the played her actually moved and acted that way, she is a talented actress.Toshio(the little boy spirit)If anything I either found him funny or annoying depending on what it was he was doing. First of all I was more than a little confused on what his part in the whole thing actually was and he really didn't seem to do much of anything except be creepy. The thing that I found funny about him is that he yowled like a cat and even as I was watching the movie I had visions of what might happen if someone were to dangle a string in front of him or let a wind up mouse loose.I also found the story itself confusing, one premise of the movie was that if you did whatever it was you did to incur these spirits wrath(not going to say what that was for those that haven't seen The Grudge) they were going to get you and there was no way out of that but then there were people in the movie that got out of it but it was never explained how or what they did to get out of it.Usually in movies(certainly in this genre)there are things that happen during the early scenes that have you asking "What is with that?" and usually somewhere in the course of the movie those questions are answered but The Grudge answers nothing and leaves you with more questions at the end of the film than you had when you started watching it.The Grudge is scary as hell thats for sure but other than that its not a very satisfying movie, its lack of answers, confusing storyline, characters and pace setting leaves more than a little to be desired.

Wow. I would prefer to make love to a 3,000 pound man with cheese puffs stuffed in his nostrils than call this film an actual movie. I mean its some dumb kid in a weird house terrorizing the tenants. The beginning made no sense, the script was crap after crap. However, compared to the sequel, this film is a masterpiece. Still, worst movie ever made. Kids went to see this because its a frigging summer scare. And its not even that! I laughed when the woman was eaten under the covers! Sarah Michelle Gellar might find it hard to get work after this project and its sequel. Another thing that was funny, when the kid opens his mouth, he meows. I mean, did he eat a cat at some point in the movie? Or is it still stuck in his throat after he got murdered? Seriously, a good horror film that won''t let you sleep is The Silence of the lambs, or the Shining. Not this! I laughed myself to sleep! Worst Movie I ever saw! Saw...thats a good one too!

I found this movie to very creepy. I was watching it with my friend and I kept jumping at the scary parts. The movie keeps you guessing cause you never know what's going to happen or whose going to die next. I found some parts extremely disturbing, like when that girl got her jaw torn off and her tongue was hanging out. I thought that it was an awesome movie that would be good to watch on a Halloween night, and yes I watched (even thought I don't like scary movies that much.) I watched quite a few times and I don't think it was a bad movie, I thought it was scary, creepy and I also want to watch the Grudge 2. When my sister comes down to visit, i'm going to rent it, and make her watch it

Review title: An absolute diss on the movie.
Review_body: Could a movie be any less scary? The "horror" scenes were ridiculously predictable long before they occurred on screen, and when they did appear, they were not scary at all. This was a laughable attempt at horror. The Grudge was is no better than a ghost story told at an elementary school sleep-over. What an unintendedly comedic flop. The spirits in the movie were not "caught in the grip of a powerful rage," as the previews suggested. They were simply caught in a failing, floundering film that sank like the Titanic. Funny cat noises and Asian actresses with their faces painted white do not a scary film make. The plot was poorly thought out, the acting was mediocre, and the whole thing was just not believable. Sarah Michelle Gellar should have stayed with Buffy.

Review title: Just watch it in a perfect environment
Review_body: First of all this is my first review on any movie. I was so exited after watching The Grudge, I thought I should write a review on this. It is a great horror movie. It has got most of the stuff that needed to make a good horror movie. I agree that it doesn't have a good story, it has a paper thin plot but what it has is a pure horror that doesn't depend on any story at all. If this movie has got a great story to back it up then I think it might be the best horror movie of all time.One thing I really want to say here that this movie is heavily depends on some horror movie clichés, like sudden jump scenes, character following the strange noise that came from the dark corner of the house. But that actually is the plus point of this movie. They have presented in such a good way that it creates such a spooky atmosphere in the movie.If you want to really enjoy this gem of a horror then watch it all alone with a great home theater system that supports Dolby Digital or DTS 5.1ch, without any of your ill mannered friends that crack jokes on a really tense situation. And don't forget to switch the light off.It will scare the f**k out of you.

You can check out the review at www.hollywoodjesus.com Post comments there and an interesting discusison of Spirituality and Horror, specifically Christianity and Horror. You might be surprised at these reviewers who don't see themselves as being holier than thou.At long last some horror that remembers what horror is without the sex, gore and extreme violence. Quite possibly this could be one of the best haunted house stories ever made. It would be interesting to hear about other haunted house stories that people like. This movie is not number one two weeks in a row for nothing. It is there because word of mouth is carrying it forward from week to week.

OK, I will admit it that I was scared out of my mind at some points in the movie but the constant jumping back and forth through time just confused me.There were definitely times when the whole audience jumped (ie, the bus scene and the apartment scene) but other than that you knew when something bad was going to happen. The make up and sound effects were good but the acting was so-so.I also would like to ask (not to sound like a racist) but what is up with Japanese movie makers and having really brutal ways of killing family members in their movies?!?! In the Ring she kills her daughter and in this movie it's an entire family. I understand that he was jealous of the woman but to kill the kid... why????Anyways, if you are going to go see a movie just to get scared and not understand the story than go see this one. If you like story lines and plots than skip it.

Review title: Being one who doesn't scare easily, The Grudge did a decent enough job.
Review_body: I don't watch a lot of Horror. The little bit of "Horror" that I've seen hasn't really scared me.I did see The Ring and I thought it was pretty well done, freaky, twisted, and spooky. But it didn't scare me or fill me with terror.The Grudge didn't either, but I can easily see how it would.As opposed to The Ring, which was built more around terror and a storyline, The Grudge is largely a series of jump sequences and shock-factor shots. Some are extremely cliché, others will catch you totally by surprise. If you like a movie that scares through these tatics than you should enjoy The Grudge.If you like the way The Ring scares you, you'll be disappointed. This isn't a slow-paced terror flick. This is a Halloween fright-fest.And it definitely has it's share of haunting images...The story is crap and the characters are crap. The setting isn't very good and it feels very familiar to other movies and shows. It has its similarities to The Ring but the average watcher won't notice them.If none of the above bothers you, go for it. It's a fun little film that might get you the spooks. If you are a big horror buff, I would say it's worth a matinée (sp?) just to see a few of the cooler and more unique parts.I would give it a 5/10, and that is being generous, but that's because I'm not a big horror fan. It felt just too familiar and predictable.

Review title: Just watch the Ring, skillful but not good
Review_body: I usually don't like movies like this, but I did like The Ring a lot. I went to see this to see what a Japanese director would do with an American film in Tokyo. (I am an American, but I lived in Tokyo for a while.)This movie is indeed very freaky and disturbing. I was tense the whole time. So I do concede that they were skillful in creating a tense atmosphere However, it is just basically the same thing happening over and over again. A lot of "oh no, don't open that door!". I was very quickly able to determine what happened and then why it happened. The characters did things for stupid reasons obviously just to continue the movie.The ending was poor.

Yes that's right, are you kidding me? This was a total waste of time. This is by far a joke of a movie. My wife and I watched this movie and waited, waited, and waited more for something to happen and, well those of you who saw it know what I mean. When the movie ended, my wife and I looked at each other and shook our heads wondering why this movie was even made. Not even close to being scary, not even close to being a thriller. There just isn't a point to this movie. The acting is sub par at best, the directing is terrible. Do not believe any promoting or hype you read about this movie. All I can say is pass on this one, and don't even stop to collect anything. PASS!

I repeat, *major spoilers*. The Grudge is a remake of a Japanese horror movie (Ju-on, Ju-on 2: The Grudge). Its goal is to give people chills, which I think it achieves.Sarah Michelle Gellar is an American nurse moved to Tokyo, Japan with her boyfriend, Doug (Jason Behr), and is chosen to take care of a batty old woman named Emma after her other caretaker, Yoko, has mysteriously not shown up for work. The audience knows what has happened to dear Yoko, but the cast in the film haven't the brains to figure it out. I guess they actually have to find her body before they put two and two together!The Grudge is told in two separate stories; one is the story of the Williams family (consisting of Matthew, wife Jennifer, Matthew's Sister Susan, and Matthew's Mother Emma) moving into the house which we know to be haunted/cursed. The other is the story of Sarah Michelle Gellar taking care of Emma, the last member of the Williams family, after the rest of the family has disappeared. Again, we know what has happened, but apparently the police need bodies to figure out that they're dead.The first clue that there is something suspicious in that house is, of course, when Yoko goes up into the attic and is murdered by a freakish-looking female ghost in the shadows. I might add I jumped out of my skin the first time I saw that ghost. Hehheh, hehAfter Yoko dies, Karen (Gellar), steps in. She feels something weird in the house, and hears strange noises. She goes to investigate, and finds a young boy, Toshio (creepy Yuya Ozeki), and his black cat taped inside of a closet. If you think that's weird, keep reading!After Karen calls for help, she finds Emma curled up on her futon talking to something that isn't there. That has scary written all over it, right?The ghost makes her second appearance, this time in front of Emma and Karen. What does she want? Is she after someone in particular?Afterwards, Karen goes investigating about Toshio and his family via the web. Ah, where would we be without technology? It turns out Toshio has been cutting his Mom's face out of every picture. What strange behavior! And what's this? He likes to meow like a cat and murder people, too? Well, that's just the icing on the cake!Yes, it seems our little Toshio lured Jennifer Williams into a bedroom one evening, scaring her half-to-death. When Matthew came home to check up on her, scared both of them fully-to-death. Interesting hobbies this young boy has. I wonder if all Japanese boys act like that.Matthew's sister Susan had left a message on his answering machine, and when we flash over to her at her workplace, she starts to get worried as he hasn't called back yet. Susan then proceeds down to the stairwell where Matthew phones her. Hey; isn't Matthew dead?This is where very creepy noises from the ghostly girl come in over the phone.Susan hangs up. She continues to hear the noises, only this time, they're louder. They're close by. Ack. The lights flicker. ACK. The ghostly figure starts up the stairs towards her. ACK!Susan runs back to her hotel, and she takes the elevator up to her room. On the elevator next to her is Toshio, of course, but she doesn't notice because her eyes are conveniently closed from being so relieved she got back safely. Right. Sure you did, Susan.Susan gets another phone call. This time it really is Matthew. What?! Matthew's dead, dammit! This isn't real! Only we know that, though. She doesn't.Until she buzzes him in and the door rings not but two seconds later. When she answers it, no one's there. The noises on the phone start up again, and she smashes the phone. Sorry, Susan, butbye-bye!Anyhow, now that the police can't get any answer from Susan, and now that the police have figured out that Jennifer and Matthew are dead along with a strange piece of a body on the ground in the attic with them, what are they to do? Search her apartment and find nothing there.When Nakagawa-san figures out that whoever goes into that house becomes a target of the ghost, he returns to the house to try and burn it down. However, not being too bright, he investigates the crying he hears once in the building. Stupid Nakagawa-san!Return of the cat boy, Toshio! Nakagawa-san was afraid Toshio was a poor boy drowning. Oh, boybye-bye, Nakagawa-san. Toshio so elegantly drowns him instead.Karen goes to Peter's (Pullman) house to talk to his wife about his suicide. She looks at old photographs and discovers that in every single picture, the then-alive ghostly figure appears in them. She has to find out who she is and what she wants.When Karen returns home, she finds out that her boyfriend has gone to the house. No! If he goes there, he'll be a target, too! So, of course, she goes after him.The next scenes are frightening as they are told as flashbacks relayed through the present. Karen sees Peter talking to Toshio about his Mom, and then sees him looking through pictures of his Mom. His Mom is the ghostly figure. And her husband murdered her.When Peter opens the closet with all of the pictures on it, the corpse of Kayako Saeki.When Karen finds Doug, Kayako is still haunting them, and crawls very creepily down the stairs towards them. Unfortunately, Doug seems to be paralyzed, and Karen isn't heartless enough to leave him behind, so they're both stuck there awaiting Kayako's ghost to do something terrifying to them.Karen eventually sets out to do what Nakagawa-san couldn't, and sets the whole place on fire. She's lucky that she winds up alive. Doug dies.When Karen goes to say good-bye to Doug's corpse, guess who?

Review title: A nice change from the usual..
Review_body: I have just seen this movie last night, despite all the negative critics people had about it, i decided to go and see it for myself, and i thought it was an excellent horror flick. First, the whole movie is set in Japan which is a nice change from the usual "all American cities" in which these movies are made; Second, most people have no knowledge of the Japenese horror genre, their culture and what scares them, this movie is one of thescariest thing i have seen in a while, you have to understand the culture behind such a film before you can say that it "sucks"...Those who enjoy seeing a rotting Jason, who has been killed a million times over, rip people's heads off or stab them, or cut their throats open, should keep watching such films, and leave movies like this one alone.only downside to this screening: Hollywood made a sequel to the ring...

Review title: One of the worst films of 2004...
Review_body: I had heard about THE GRUDGE in June of this summer. I was very excited to see it because I haven't had a good scare since...awhile. Although, I was a little skeptical as to whether it was just following in the footsteps of THE RING, which I enjoyed, and was just relying on the sudden hype about Japanese horror films to initiate its box office rather than containing an actual decent plot, craft, and performances. And you know what? My skepticism was correct. THE GRUDGE, in my opinion, is one of the worst films of the year. One of the main reasons it was so bad is that it is absolutely degrading to the original film in just its existence, and the fact it was advertised and promoted so well with complete deception. The plot, to begin, made sense, within its own context, but externally left many wholes involving the question of WHY? and SO WHAT? Ultimately, it was a very weak basis to deliver any scares, which leads me to my next point. There are no scares! I was absolutely disappointed with the lack of tension, and terror because there was none of it. There wasn't one moment where I felt scared or even jumped at the ridiculous, formulaic attempts to jolt you.The performances? Let me just say this... The best performance is from Bill Pullman who dies in the first five minutes (that shouldn't be considered a spoiler since it happens in the very beginning). It is probably the most shocking moment of the whole movie, actually it is. Not in the fact that it happens but more the way it happens. For the rest of the film, I envied his character. What I wouldn't give to be lying on the ground, dead, instead of having to watch this film. Sarah Michelle Gellar's performance was ridiculous and nothing short of. Actually, no other performances should be mentioned; they're all more horrifying than the film itself.To top it off, the directional skill is sloppy and seems incoherent. I was shocked to find that the same director of Ju-On participated in this film. There was nothing creative, nothing different, and nothing good. Pretty much summing up the entire quality of the film, which is structured in a senseless manner, exposing the stupidity of Americans who walked towards the sounds rather than run from them. By the way, I'm really curious as to why most of the characters are American, and if they're not, they still speak English most of the time. The film takes place in Tokyo! It makes me so livid just thinking about how BAD it is. Overall, the film lacks any sense, any scares, and any cause for care, making it one of the worst movies I have seen all year, and I've seen a lot! Best Films of 2004 To-Date: Kill Bill: Vol. 2 Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind Garden State Touching the Void Before Sunset Worst Films of 2004 To-Date: The Grudge Catwoman Against The Ropes Scooby-Doo 2 Godsend

Review title: What the, The credits are rolling? I want my 2 hours back!
Review_body: Ju-On, The Grudge. A remake with the same director. The movie is based upon a legend that if you die in a great rage, you will haunt the place you died in. People start disappearing in from this house in Tokyo and the police are investigating. That is the premise of this movie. I saw this with my Girlfriend and she was terrified. All throughout the movie She was holding on to me. I was sitting bored, watching a movie with plot holes, not so good acting, and a premise that was sub par. Then I was confused, the credits rolled, and the lights turned on. Could the movie be over? It couldn't be. I looked around for other confused souls, and sure enough, a man behind me said "That was retarded" I turned to him and said thank you.I want my 2 hours back Takashi Shimizu!!!! Frankly, this movie had no redeeming qualities. If it was scary, then where was my suspense. If it was good acting then why do I want to shoot myself to end my boredom? Bill Pullman had a screen time for all of 5 mins. SMG, while I do love her, could not save this movie. My advice: avoid this sub par movie at all costs.Oh, BTW if you liked the ring you will love this movie.HORROR/SUSPENSE 4/10

Review title: Lights off. Snuggle up to your blanket. Open your mind for this ride! Highly recommended!!
Review_body: People really need to "get" into it to experience the desired effect. They need to learn how to truly become one with the film while viewing, to absorb the tension and allow the film and atmosphere to "take" you there. They need to open up to a film and "allow" themselves to be scared, to allow the movie to show you whats its really got. That means, lights off, talking to a minimum, good sound, preferably late at night, freeing your mind of thought to allow the film to effectively and properly portray its vision, imagery, tension, ambiance, atmosphere, story etc.I cant stand people who seemingly on purpose dismiss these general rules of thumb and put up a shield of armor to stop the film/films from achieving what they set out to do, and yet they think they can justifiably say it wasn't scary. I think many people do this because they believe its cool to not be scared of a film, or are afraid there friends will say something like "Ah your a sissy, that wasn't scary!" Don't get me wrong, i'm sure for some reasons, certain films just don't get to certain people, but all to often, it seems more often than not, people fall into this irritating category. Fear can quite easily be avoided consciously and sub-consciously by closing your mind whether intentional or unintentional and by not setting yourself up with the proper atmosphere. Open up to a film! Let the film show YOU what its got, instead of showing the film what you can avoid.I don't care what anyone says: this film is a work of genius laced with an imagination that goes far and beyond what most could even possibly begin to think up. The directing style was original and the story was told with enough to get you up to date with whats going on but with enough left out to keep the mystery alive and to keep you thinking. The imagery was truly astounding. I could go on but ill just say, yes, to me and most i know, it was scary as hell!! I would not watch it by myself, but i recommend it if you really wanna "fun" ride! :) Overall: Awesome, i loved it! My 2cents.

Review title: The Best Horror Movie I've seen
Review_body: I'm writing this after seeing The Grudge on multiple times. I must say I've seen it first in a Sunday morning at 3am, and I must say that, since that fateful morning, like 3 weeks ago, I've remained paranoid of dark corners in my room. The movie is about an American couple that moved in Japan for study. They are confronted with a "slight" problem when Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar) fills in for Yoko from the Social Care Center she was working for. She unwittingly steps into a cursed house that holds dark secrets. The movie is a frightfest that reaches in the depths of your mind as sure as a surgeon's blade cuts on the line, leaving you so much as 2 minutes of "breath-catching" time. Very nicely made, the actors have been up to my expectations, and the "badguy" is the scariest thing to be caught on camera... I've had a perverse pleasure after viewing the movie, in the sense that I swore to god I wouldn't watch another movie if they'll come out with a sequel...but I enjoyed the experience it provided; it's not that I'm a scaredy cat... it's just that I'm afraid I won't live through it. My advice is don't watch it just so you know you've watched it, watch it in such a manner so you "feel" everything this little "gem" has to offer

I went to see this movie when it first came out over here..... It was exactly as I thought (and feared) it would be; Ju-On 1, 2 (and even small parts of the less successful-straight-to-video-prequels) were used to make this nice and easy to digest for the western viewer. I do not blame the director though, the most common used comment on "Ju-On" by the western viewers wás that they never understood a d*mn thing of the movie because there were too many flash-backs. And so, they make it chronological and easy to watch, throw in some "scary" moments, cut out the things that made the movie really SCARY in the first place and PRESTO, more raving reviews than the originals ever got. Mr. Shimizu probably wanted to re-do this movie on a bigger budget, but it would have been appreciated by me (and a lot of people I know) if some of the edginess would have been saved in this remake instead of fancy rendering/ animation. Sometimes less ís more.

Review title: Good, Fun Horror Flick; Perfect for a Date
Review_body: I'm going to keep this simple, because it's somewhat of a simple movie. If you enjoyed The Ring, you will enjoy this one. It's good for some suspense and screams in the theater, and it had my wife (and a friend's date) hiding under their coats for most of the movie.Nothing here that has not been done already, but it is a clean fun horror movie that probably works better in the theaters. Don't expect a great ending, and don't expect deep character development and you will have a good time.Sound and image quality were good, and some of the suspense scenes are right up there. This movie peaks a few times and gets you into it. Gellar was mediocre at best so don't go see this if you are expecting an Academy Award winning performance.

This movie made my skin crawl! I think it scared me as much by what it didn't show on the screen as by what it did. This film is proof that what is scary isn't necessarily gore and guts and boogymen per se, but rather one can be scared by reaching into the mind's repository of fears. It was nice to see Sara Michelle Gellar break out of the Buffy persona and take on a different character for a change. Jason Behr is sexier than ever as Doug. I sincerely hope that a sequel is being considered, since this move was part of a series in Japan. Oh-- and that creepy sound scares the hell out of me.

Review title: another remake of a Japanese horror movie
Review_body: Karen (Michelle Gellar)is hired as a nurse for an old American woman in a Japanese house. As she is nursing the woman they are both exposed to a supernatural scary event. It turns out that a crime has been committed in that very house three years ago and there's a Japanese saying that whenever someone dies in a rage this victim will come back with a vengeance and kill everyone who enters the house in the same rage.Though it's easy to see that Sarah Michelle Gellar plays the main character she never gets interesting (besides her looks of course). Moreover, if you have watched "the ring" and "the eye" this movie will certainly disappoint you even though it has its moments. The ending is also very easy to spot after a couple of minutes, but, of course, it shouldn't be revealed here.

When I first saw the trailer for this movie I thought that when the little boy meowed and he was blue that, that part was freaky but then i just thougth well this is probably just a copy off of the ring and its just going to be another corny scary movie. So i went and saw it, and it was sooo scary. I mean your hearing this from a girl thats watched the exorcist at least 100 times alone in the dark. I love horror movies. But this movie made me sweat so much. It should be a classic in my opinion because movies that scary the hell out of you must be really good, and this movie scared me. I definitely recommend it. Especially if your one of those people that don't get scared easily.

The grudge was scarier than i expected it to be. (Japan)Mainly it's about a woman and her son who's murdered in their home by the husband.. The woman and the little boy haunts the house and kills everyone who comes in contact with it. The film acts out three years after the murder and an American man lives in the house with his wife and mother, there is also a woman named Yoko, who helps out with the mother. When Yoko goes missing, Karen(Sarah Michelle Gellar) get's to substitute for her, and she goes to the house to care for the mother (Emma). Karen finds a scarred boy in a closet, she doesn't know that the boy has been murdered three years earlier. She calls her boss and tells him about it. She goes in to check on Emma who is lying down staring. Karen looks in the direction Emma is and she sees something really creepy. When her boss comes to the house Karen is sitting shaking in a corner, Emma is dead and they also find Emmas son and his wife in the attic - DEAD. It goes from there.. with a lot of death and other scary things. Karen discovers why they were murdered, and finds out that since she's been in contact with the house she is in a real danger zone. Sarah Michelle does a great job acting scarred and I give a lot of credit to the Japanese film makers. They really know how to give you nightmares (remember the ring?) Haven't seen this film? then i suggest you do..

I love it how most people here claim to be big time horror fans but never venture out any further than some retarded sequel to Jeepers Creepers or something like that. I think if your going to rank on a film but down at least 3 points of references of films that you actually thought were good before you act like you have a valid point. I myself, am obsessed with horror films. I watch them all and 95% aren't worth it. For anyone to say they are bigtime horror fans you would have to venture out to foreign cinema since right now there really isn't anything good coming out of the US lately.Anyone that goes to "the ring" references really doesn't know Asian horror. Even in the movie Kwaidan long black hair has its place which was made ages ago. Its always been associated with decay and death and is pretty creepy in itself. Any movie that uses it is not automatically a rip off. Most people associate The Ring with this film since its probably the only two Japanese born films they have seen and the fact that unlike most horror they use technology as tool. Most Asian horrors have that formula some can be called rehash but others have their own places. I don't think these two films are alike as much as the movie "Phone" or "One Missed Call"( both OK films btw) have ring similarities. I don't think The Ring was as good as Ringu even after seeing The Ring first. I think with horror you have to weigh the pros and cons and see if your happy with it after the fact.The original theatrical release of Ju-on was nothing special in the lines of plot and pissed me off at the end but I still liked it. My girlfriend wouldn't go anywhere upstairs without me and the second film I think she screamed for a minute straight from Ju-on 2: The Grude. Just like "The Blair Witch" it effects people differently. For people who have seen any version of this film before your going to be jaded since any version you see first is going to be the scariest or what have you. I don't think you can compare it when you have a remake which half@ssly combines the TV and Theatrical Japanese versions yet still manages to be confusing. I don't think it had the umph but I do think it has its own niche with people who haven't seen it since it is better that most of the crap out there. I would take the US remake over Saw anyday.horror seen lately:Hypnosis :great ending nice pacing and plot Saw :only for amateur horror fans The Grudge : good if you haven't seen the Japanese versions but only one scene done as well as the original theatre version(the sister) Tale of Two Sisters : Now that is a story told well try and pick that one apart you anal peepsrecommendations:Kairo Ravenous inner senses the eye the shining the thing the others audition

Just finished watching this fun horror flick, and it is loaded with a lot of mini bursts of horror moments! Sam Raimi has done quite a good job at intertwining the original movie (ju on) with this version. It is unusual-- especially for such a mainstream horror blockbuster, the Grudge does a good job representing or at least putting Japan out there as a trendy one of Hollywood's source for scary movies these days. As for the Grudge vs. the Ring... Definitely, the Grudge would be my pick. The Grudge, especially with Sam Raimi at the helm, packed a lot more rapid camera action movements(mimicking heart beats) that is classic in Raimi's films.

Review title: Good story line, just disappointing climaxes
Review_body: The movie overall is quite good, but most of the frightening scenes are quite expected (if you watch a lot of horror films). Sarah Michelle Gellar does an okay job, but i think her representation of fear is not realistic enough.To be honest, I didn't find this movie really scary. The noise that the ghost makes is quite disturbing, but apart from that it hardly gave me a scare. I thought the Ring was better at the crucial moments.SPOILERS: The first bit where Yoko encounters the woman in the attic- i thought that was a pretty crap moment- the makeup on the woman was really bad. Some of the scenes weren't subtle enough- it was too 'in your face'. i like it better when there's more suspense and less confrontation, as in monster lurking around... blah blah. I hate actually seeing the 'evilness' because it no longer has an element of suspense, and the grudge is like that. Just my opinion.So, for people who are hardcore and REALLY liked being scared, don't watch this.

Many of my friends has said to me that "The Grudge" is one of the scariest movies they have ever seen and that they couldn't sleep at all after watching it. So I watched a couple of clips about the movie and I was quite terrified afterwards. I definitely wanted to see the movie cause I really enjoy horror films even though they scare me to death.This on the other hand, didn't. I watched this quite easily and I didn't even have to hide behind our couch and that is saying a lot, trust me. Sure, Kayako is pretty creepy and all but I didn't get the feeling which I usually have when I watch a horror film - the chills and all. My expectations were pretty high, I admit it, but still, it needed something more to be actually scary.I did like watching this film nevertheless - all at least it wasn't wasted time that I used. The plot is quite interesting and Kayako's story is just sad. The idea about that much of rage and grudge is scary but the implementation wasn't.Anyway, I have to say - I am disappointed.

As I've noticed with a lot of IMDb comments, certain reviewers seem to demand that every film they see have smugly intelligent plots that wallow in there own cleverness. I am not one of those people. If I watch an action film, I want to see explosions, gunfire and heroics. If I watch a comedy, I want to have tears of laughter in my eyes. You get the idea. Therefore watching a horror film, I primarily want to be scared. The Grudge is a very scary film, in both it's well executed 'jump' scenes, and it's creepy imagery. I've been a horror film fan for many years, and I'm talking about the masters such as Dario Argento, rather than directors of some of the treadmill teen horror flicks that are churned out these days. If you want to be scared, watch this film. Way scarier than the original Japanese 'Ring' (which I also think is a great film).

If you go see this movie you'll be holding a grudge against the movie theatre, the director, the producer, the actors and the person that told you to go see it! Shame on you, Sarah Michelle Geller, for putting your name and face to this poor excuse of a movie. It may have been more scary if the Japanese actors would have just spoken in Japanese instead of attempting to 'act' in English. I wanted to boo when the movie ended...a true disappointment after all of the hype on TV and movie trailers promoting this lame money maker. Sarah Michelle really didn't have to act at all to make this movie...she just practiced her frowning skills. Don't waste your time or money on this film.

Review title: The Ring outdoes this film many, many times over
Review_body: I just got through watching The Grudge, and I have to admit it's at the top of my list of worst "movies" ever - up there with "Jeepers Creepers" and "Final Destination." And yes, notice how I refer to it as a "movie" - it's not worthy of being called a "film." I got the feeling this movie was trying to be something like The Ring, but it failed miserably. The Ring was the first (in terms of popular American movies/remakes) of its genre, and it achieved a level of suspense, mixed with equal amounts of originality, and intrigue. On the other hand, The Grudge is nothing more than a few highly predictable startling scenes and a bunch of rip offs from The Ring. Feel free to go about your normal routine with this movie playing in the background - nothing you'd miss could be critical to the plot, since there really isn't a plot at all.If you're considering renting or buying this, save your money. Instead blindfold yourself in your backyard, and have your friends jump out at you as you stumble around. The end result is the same - a few mild scares, with nothing to think about afterwards, and nothing worth seeing during.

I saw the movie and all though the whole concept of a house being cursed is considered unscary this movie had me freaked throughout the whole thing. I was actually so freaked I screamed at the top of my lungs at the beginning when Yoko was in the attic. This probably is the scariest movie I have ever seen it is a lot scarier then the ring. Most of the top rated horror movies in North America today started in a Japanese or Chinese theatre. Such movies as the ring and the grudge. (I guess Chinese/Japanese people have a better idea of what gives people nightmares three weeks after they have seen the movie.) But I guess the theatre make the movie much scarier then if you saw it at home. I hope you enjoy it.

this movie is stupid it is not scary at all and the storyline is not exactly great. i have to say it is more of a humorous film. like the part where the man dropped of the balcony on to the street.i couldn't stop laughing i was choking on my kit kat i was eating for god sake. its a very poor effort to make someone scared. he people who were scared obviously looked at this the wrong way. i thought the security guard was the best actor. i liked his facial expressions he made it all seem real. if they make a grudge 2 i don't think it would get high applause i don't even think they would be able to make another one of them daft trailers they made. the company would get bankrupt.

it was a good movie... i liked it , i hope that if you watch it you will like it...it was pretty scary...it had a touch of disgusting things...end the end was the best...one of the best endings i have ever seen...my favourite movie (house of 1000 corpses) had a shitty end...it was not so very surprising but the grudge...it was good, i mean great...better then the Texas chainsaw massacre...the center point of the film could of been more interesting..but the directors probably wanted to keep it as real as possible so thats why they made all the long investigations... all and all...a great flick that you just should miss

I saw the Japanese version of this movie, i've heard there is an American version which i haven't seen and well right now i don't dare to watch that version yet... I get scared easily with many movies while i'm watching them, but let me tell you that this one made my chest hurt, and i couldn't sleep in like 2 or 3 days, and if my husband tries to make the noise one of the ghosts made in the movie i get those terrible images in my mind. So if you like scary movies i recommend this one, but the Japanese version of course since i haven't seen the American one, and I personally like the original stuff better so try it. The movie i watched was spoken in Spanish so the sounds were awful bad, but still got scared. Anyways it is a good movie, i never saw an Asian movie before and this one is a really good one.

Review title: If you've seen Ju-On, you've seen "The grudge"
Review_body: Unfortunately, I have seen Ju-On and "The Grudge" seems to be almost identical to it. I don't think Sarah Michelle Gellar can act her way out of a small box, and she adds to this mess. I think some of the noise effects were good, and if your watching it at home on your surround sound, it may give you a few jumps here and there. The problem is that if you've seen Ju-On you know what is going to happen or not happen and that made me have less interest in the flick. so if you've seen ju-on, don't bother cause you have seen the movie. If you haven't seen ju-on, i guess rent "the grudge", but then go watch ju-on, because that movie is a lot better at providing you with horror.

this movie was horrible. I could barely stay awake through it. I would never see this movie again if I were payed to. The so-called horror scenes in it were increadably predictable and over played. There was really nothing about this movie that would have made it original or worth the $7.50 I payed to see it. Don't go see it, don't rent it, don't read about it online because any of these things would be a complete waste of your time. Sarah Michelle Geller gave a lackluster performance and really should be ashamed of herself for sullying her good name with this movie. Shame on you Sarah for being associated with this horrible, horrible movie. Horrible movie, no need to ever see it.

Review title: Good, but why all the remakes?
Review_body: The Grudge is a spooky film, and mostly free of those cliché 'turn around, he's behind you!' shots. In short, its scary and moody and is a good horror film. Its just not exceptional. And its not helped my a few points...Sarah Michelle Gellar is, I'm afraid, pretty wooden. I wouldn't make a big point of this, but she is the main character, and you are supposed to empathise with her. She does cry, look worried and look afraid, but (in my honest opinion) she always appears to be 'acting' and never really 'being'. There seem to be many people who disagree with me on this, but I'm going to go out on a limb and say I think its because most of these people are Buffy fans, and so, SMG can do no wrong. She's always appears likable, but never believable. (Personally, I find this really annoying now, because she is the same in everything, yet still gets picked to star in film/TV shows, despite being very lacking in the acting department.) I fear she was picked for her fan base (her looks don't hurt either), and certainly not her ability.There is, however, some good acting to compensate. Bill Pullman is good, even though he doesn't have much screen time to work with. And the actor playing the Japanese detective (I don't remember his name) was especially good in the scene watching the security camera tapes. He looks truly uncomfortable/petrified. His eyes do all the talking, and he doesn't succumb to (*cough* Sarah Michelle Gellar *cough*) being forced to cry, quiver his lips, or go all goo-goo eyed.Another slight bug with this film: it looks like the American version of Japan. All the main characters (with only 3 exceptions) are American! What? There were over a dozen Americans leads, yet only 3 Japanese characters! IN THE MIDDLE OF TOKYO!!! Every other job shown in the film was occupied by an American! In the film's defence, there was a reason given for all of these, but still... Again, I don't want to write a sociological essay on this point, but it did strike me as beyond suspension of disbelief and more than a little patronising to the targeted American audience.I haven't seen the original yet, but I would like to now, just to see if this was an improvement (although I doubt it). If you're usually put off by American remakes, this is actually quite good.5 out of 10

I enjoyed this movie somewhat, but I didn't find it horrific at all. You would really need to be easy to scare in order to be tensed up about it. Some scenes made the movie look cheap, as half of the stuff could be easily reproduced in your own home. Only two scenes off the top of my head were really clever and got me startled. The story itself was pretty well thought out. I enjoy the time frame jump around. Seeing different time periods throughout the movie, piecing together what happened and what is going on. However, the ending was terrible! If you really thought about it as deeply as I did, the ending made no sense. You start to feel as though the main character is learning what happened, and everything will be okay, and then after other events, you're left with thinking "What was the point?".

Review title: Seen the original? This one is worth watching too!
Review_body: I have seen both Ju-On 1 and 2 many times; such amazing movies. When the American remake happened, I was skeptical; Gellar? Clea Duvall? Americans in Japan? Well, take comfort, Shimizu fans; this remake is actually decent and worth watching. It is different than the original in many ways, but take heart that it is tastefully re-done. You will see familiar faces, such as the original Saeki family. The house is different, but only slightly so. More care is taken to explain Japanese culture for those new to it. But the scares are just as scary, the make up and effects just as good!I don't want to spoil anything, so if you are an Asian Horror movie snob like me, don't snub this film.

Review title: Subtleties is what makes this movie great
Review_body: From reviews I've read of this movie, you either love it or you hate it. Although the majority of actors are American, this is a Japanese movie and I think most of the negative comments by reviewers are grounded in a lack of understanding of eastern aesthetics. Unfortunately, a good many American moviegoers won't like a movie unless the plot just absolutely pounds you over the head, something this movie does not do. The atmosphere and psychological component (a sense of real tragedy - something that's lacking in many American horror movies) makes this film as interesting and terrifying as it could be.

Review title: snore - sarah michelle should stick to vampire slaying
Review_body: this film was passable, but the plot didn't really seem to be going anywhere. its watchable if you are really into your Japanese remake films, but as always they miss a certain something that the original has in spades. whats that, you ask? ACTUAL SCARY BITS. possibly its just because you have to actively watch the film in the Japanese version due to the subtitles but they know how to hold you in suspense, whereas the American version made me laugh or go talk to my mates on my phone, make a cup of tea...it just bored me to tears. my advice? go rent the original along with the Ring and Ring 2 Japanese versions and appreciate them, rather than watching the dire crap American attempts. poo poo poo.

In my opinion, horror movies can be roughly divided into two categories. The visual and the story driven ones.
