This movie is almost driven entirely by the visual side, and as as such has received a lot of bad reviews by people who does not find those sort of movies scary/good.For my part, I think visual horrors are by FAR the most scary. Intelligent dialogue and an interesting plot, I admit, would make a technically better movie. However, for pure "scare-effect" this movie is superior to anything I have ever seen before.Describing the visual details will not rightfully describe the horror which they can produce, only a viewing can accomplish that. I only want to stress that this is, in my opinion, the most haunting visual horror ever made.9 of 10 - For being perfect in its particular genre

Review title: Can't believe how many negative reviews
Review_body: This is what a scary movie is supposed to feel like

This was one of the worst movies I have ever seen. These people are in Tokyo, one of the most densely populated cities in the world, yet are always alone. It jumps around with no sense of story continuity and is filled with startle moments are telegraphed like a neon sign. Sarah Michelle Gellar did a decent job as the star. The only redeeming factor in this movie is the acting. It even has a cheap, silly Friday the 13th (the first one) ending.The only movie that I have seen that is worse is Battlefield Earth. It's a shame IMDb does not allow negative ratings.Stay Away!!!

Review title: This might be the stupidest movie i have ever seen
Review_body: As the one line summary says---this might be the stupidest movie I have ever seen. By the end of the movie (which I almost left), most people were talking and completely bored.The films biggest problem was its shock, or lack thereof. NOTHING was scary. NOTHING was frightening. For the most part, the attempts at scaring the audience, which included popping the same face from some inane direction, caused irritation, rather than fear.Bah, just trying to write a summary about it makes me relive it and be bored again. Enough is enough. Gellar, go back to Buffy if you want to make something scary...this was not a good movie.

This movie made me laugh...it's a combination of awful, low-cost horrors and a good black comedy. I saw it twice, i don't know why i watched it for the second time, but i know that when i hear the word "grudge" i think about one of the most bad movies. Know, why am i so harsh? because every minute i watched "The grudge" i thought about "The Ring". The two seem to be alike, but "the Ring " is pretty OK. Maybe not everybody saw the similitude between the two but i think it is obviously. The symbol of the child who had a not-very-nice childhood, the child that walks on the hall of the building, chasing the woman, seems to be the twin sister of Samara, the fact that people die one by one, and they are attracted to the house, etc etc. Now speaking only about "the Grudge", not about "the Ring"...there are fun things like : boo-hoo, the bad spirit lives - of course - in the attic, and innocent-looking persons die first...if you want a really good, equilibrated, thrilling movie of the genre, watch "The Exorcist" (the old one) ;)

Review title: With no embellishment or exaggeration, this is singlehandedly the worst horror movie I have ever seen.
Review_body: The interesting thing is the original was not any better (unlike The Ring). I have heard people say they were scared when they saw this movie. My current policy is to slap them in the face once, and lecture them on how they are leading an ignorant life. This movie really has no saving grace whatsoever, I couldn't even laugh at it. There were a few moments (read 2) that were moderately amusing but the rest was a dull slow burn lasting 2 hours but seeming to last 10. On a technical level I found nothing redeeming in the direction or score, and the editing was really really poor and detracted from any moment that could be considered scary.A side note. I have heard that the original originally went for 4 hours and was produced as a mini series. It was cut to fit an hour and a half which may go along way to explaining the plot holes and pointlessness of this film.I award this film 1 out of 10 (the second I have ever given that mark) and condemn it to the dustbin.

the grudge was a good movie with a lot of fascinating scares in it. i think it was better than the ring 1&2.Sarah Michele Gellar character was well thought out. who would had thought a girl from the hottest action television series(Buffy)could play a dramatic role like Karen? she really did good and the rest of the cast did good as well. i was very surprised that the grudge grossed in so much money. i thought they would think that Sarah couldn't do a horror movie. well she did and it was the best movie she had ever done. the director really took out his time to direct a good movie like this. if you like mystery, this one is for you.

i went to see this movie not knowing anything about it. True it is adapted from the Japanese original. The best way to see any horror movie is not knowing anything about it. And this one did freak me out.The urban settings, large concrete city, people like you and me and a simply macabre presence make this movie identifiable and stays with you much after you have left the cinema house.The treatment is very slick, the performances credible, though Gellar does not look too credible as an American who has gone all the way to japan to live a life on her own.The back and forth story sequences do lend it even more enigma but also force you to concentrate... which means that you get involved with the storyline while the ghost creeps over your back.looking forward to the sequel.... which has incidentally released but not here in India. waiting for the DVD to hit the stores here.

This movie was the biggest waste of money i have ever spent. The plot was absolutely terrible. I do not think i can even call anyone's performance in this film acting. If you enjoy a good horror movie with good writing/directing/acting this movie is not for you. The movie did what it was supposed to do: make money and give you a few jumps. I came out of theater after seeing this film hearing people say how good of a movie it was. The only positive this movie had was good camera movement and lighting. The negatives could go on forever.If your looking for a good movie DO NOT SEE THIS FILM.If your looking for a waste of time and money, i would recommend it.

Review title: worst movie of the genre ever made
Review_body: This movie is laughably bad.Before you watch this movie ask yourself: "do I like predictable buildups, such as slow deliberate walking into "creepy" environments followed by loud noises intended to "shock" the viewer" "do I get scared by 5 year old kids wearing too much eyeshadow that meow like cats" If you answered yes to those questions than this is the movie for you! For the rest of us, this movie was the epitome of silliness. If you must watch it, watch the rifftrax version where Mike Nelson makes fun of it because it is actually enjoyable then. To know that this movie received a 5 on here, as well as doing well enough in the box office to elicit a sequel makes me weep for the idiotic masses. I guess teenage girls make up a significant portion of the public...

Review title: Made Me Jump, but Not What I Was Expecting
Review_body: When I first saw this movie, my friend and I had gotten it on Pay-Per-View. We had expected the movie to be absolutely terrifying, the commercials we saw, were scary, so we decided to watch it. So late one Saturday night, we rented it. Now on with my review: First off, when the movie started, my friend and I were on the edge of our seats, and excited to see what was going to happen. As the movie progressed I wasn't too enthusiastic about the movie. The acting, was phenomenal!! I mean Sarah Michelle Gellar did a great job in this movie, and considering, I thought she was amazing in "I Know What You Did Last Summer" I knew she was going to do the same in this movie. Well the plot itself was mediocre. Of course I jumped a few times, considering the way "The Grudge" looked, but for some reason, the way she looked reminded me a little too much of, Samara, from "The Ring". The acting was great, it was just, to me personally, the plot was a little on the "eh" side. The movie overall did have me scared, but it didn't give the same effect as other horrors/thrillers in the past have.

This movie really gave me the creeps (maybe because i was sitting in my basement late all dark, having my friends around me all freaked out because we "phyced" each other out 12 and 13 yrs old) Big screen and surround system.Just scary simple as that, nothing more to say. f u want to be freaked out for an hour and a half see that movie.If not, i suggest to not watch this movie. It's OK for me if you do, but don't come crying'to me..I give this movie 8 out of 10 because it is possible to improve certain stuff. It is possible to make it even more scary (as always.) (In Norway It's age limit is 15+) If it was 18+ it would be more scary because you will expect much more of it. (butthis got nothing to do with the film really)

I went to this movie expecting an artsy scary film. What I got was scare after scare. It's a horror film at it's core. It's not dull like other horror films where a haunted house just has ghosts and gore. This film doesn't even show you the majority of the deaths it shows the fear of the characters. I think one of the best things about the concept where it's not just the house thats haunted its whoever goes into the house. They become haunted no matter where they are. Office buildings, police stations, hotel rooms... etc. After reading some of the external reviews I am really surprised that critics didn't like this film. I am going to see it again this week and am excited about it.I gave this film 10 stars because it did what a horror film should. It scared the s**t out of me.

Review title: The best horror film since "The Exorcist"
Review_body: Flat out scariest film in thirty years. Not since the "Exorcist" has a film scared me. This one gave me the shivers at least four of five times. Although the reviews on this one are all over the map the fact that so many comments are registered is a testament to the impact this film has had. Not recommended for children. The creative innovation of not giving the characters or the audience any breathing room or break was highly effective. If you watch this one alone you will be looking over your shoulder for awhile. Although I don't gravitate toward horror films I wonder if the fast paced style employed (like a Indiana Jones paced horror film) has ever been attempted previously. It was unrelenting and offered no hope for the victims. I recommend this film and marvel at its impressionistic flavor and ability to tap into basic childhood type fear scenarios. Scary stuff.

Review title: This movie was great. Scared the hell out me.
Review_body: This movie was great. Scared the hell out me. I loved it and the second movie. I am such a huge fan. I wish they would continue with the whole entire series. BTW I found a sweet tribute video to the grudge on the net. You'll laugh your ass off. Here is the link... http://www.(you)tube.com/watch?v=1b82kXlmPFU . Anyways I definitely give it a 10 of 10. If I hear that throat gasping noise or see a little Asian boy now it creeps me out. LOL! Yeah but definitely check this movie out if you want a good scare. I haven't had a movie scare me that much in a long time. I thought the second movie wasn't as good but i'd give that one 9 of 10 but it was still great. I just thought it lack the storyline that the first one had. Do you have a grudge? Oh google "Do the Grudge" if you want to see that video also. Hope you all enjoyed this movie as much as me.

As a self-proclaimed horror movie 'junkie' it doesn't take much to draw me in. The trailer really pulled through for this movie, if it had not made it look so great, I would have never even bothered. Needless to say, I was severely disappointed. I think they threw only the remotely decent parts into the trailer... and made it look pretty darn good.But it wasn't.Throughout the whole movie, I recall one time I had almost jumped. Aside from that instance, I was trying not to pull my hair out at the rest. I found it more hysterical than frightening. Over all, I felt it to be very cliché and over dramatized.I do not think there is a movie that I regret watching more than this one. Give it a try if you want, but if you're looking for a thrilling horror movie, you are probably in the wrong place.

Review title: Took everything good from the original and wrecked it.
Review_body: If there's ever a university course entitled 'How to mess up a fairly good movie by having Hollywood remake it', the grudge should be the course's main focus.I was lucky enough to see the original just a few weeks ago and was drawn to see the remake, mostly because the original director was attached. This, as it turned out, was a mistake.The Grudge takes everything unique, creepy and scary from the Japanese original and manages to make it mediocre. If you think I'm one of the naysayers who frequently trashes Hollywood films just for the fun of it, guess again. Sam Raimi makes an all-too conspicuous cameo in the remake, miscasting himself and lowering what little tension exists by appearing goofy and out of place, not to mention that the guy is NOT an actor. Is ego why he casts himself? It can't be because he's the best candidate, can it?The absolute scariest moment for me in the original (a character's encounter with the black-haired woman in the washroom) is a wasted, barely noticeable moment in this version and I'm not even getting to the horrible cgi... Hollywood thinks that by employing computer geeks to make something vaguely mysterious (the black form overwhelming the elderly woman in the original) all high tech actually makes it better? Sorry guys, it didn't.This movie is making money hand over fists, but as far as leaving anyone with anything but a bad taste in their mouths, it's done little else.Sequel? CAN'T WAIT!

I watched this film hoping for a shiver or two like I got from "Ring" (the US remake). I wasn't disappointed. So few films have given me a genuine scare since I was a child I had begun to despair of ever feeling scared by a film again, but The Grudge delivered chills aplenty. I suggest you watch it alone, in the dark, at home, and all in one sitting. I doubt that you will be disappointed either. To my surprise even my father liked it. He said he hadn't been that scared since he saw The Exorcist thirty years ago! The Grudge deserves a 10 rating simply because it is, without doubt, the spookiest film I have ever seen as an adult. Rent it!

This movie was awful. I just watched it today on DVD and was so disappointed. I should have read the reviews before wasting 4 bucks on this garbage..I really like Sarah Michelle Gellar as an actress but this movie was totally screwy. I admit a possible jump scene is when the "dead chick" flies into the scenes at times, but overall the plot was a total disaster I mean what is it that kills them exactly? Being scared to death by seeing the dead kid and his mom. I have to admit this is a lame excuse for a film. I think Sarah made the mistake of making this film thinking it was a good opportunity to come back into the picture after her exit from "Buffy the Vampire Slayer." The movie is short and the cutting away so frequently to the past events it makes my head hurt..I realize its necessary though, for such a poorly crafted film. This maybe a good movie for the preteen, but past this it is a rotten tomato.

Review title: EXCELLENT THRILLER...Laugh @ yourself for SCREAMING like a BABY!
Review_body: I went into this movie not knowing what it was about! I HAD A GREAT TIME watching this in the cinema! E-body was into the movie...screaming together as if on queue! Not a gory movie..but monster in the shadows of your room...under your bed scary.There is not too much dialogue either. The mood is consistent through the film....creepy.10 points for the costume / makeup persons. The film poster provides just a hint of how well the 'scary' character is presented.I had a good time and that surprised me. I am usually very disappointed with the offerings in this genre.

For the genre, I thought this was pretty good. And with good I mean it had its scary moments, when you jump out of your seat. It's not the best acting around, or the best of anything really, but if you're looking to get scared for an hour and a half, this is a good choice. I think Gellar did a pretty good job in the lead, perhaps her Buffy experience made it easier for her. The plot needs some more explanations I think to be believable, but it works OK.Small spoiler.... that little boy that starts appearing on the house when Gellar gets there is a scary little bugger :-)Overall, pretty straight-forward scary-movie stuff, but effective and different enough to scare you, so it's worth a look.

this is one of those movies that are so bad that they just start getting funny after awhile, the greatest moment of the movie was when the mommy ghost pulled a classic loony toons move (she was in front of Gellar's character, then Gellar backed up opened a closet, and the ghost popped out behind her) some of the effects were pretty good, like Yoko's ghost/zombie looked good and creepy, but the movie failed to give enough plot for the visuals to be able to be scary beyond the initial shock factor. I also liked how they did the one ghosts hair, but yet again, it's just good visuals. I like a movie that can give you a reason to be scared after it's over (i.e. The Exorcist) The Grudge was totally dependent on cheap shock horror, and left you with nothing after the credits started. It was mostly horror eye candy, there wasn't much to it. I'd give it a 4/10 just because I liked it visually.

Review title: This movie just as bad as The Ring
Review_body: Scary in some parts but overall just dumb. The ending felt me wondering why pure evil just wins out with no explanation, rhyme or reason. That is the same way I felt after watching The Ring. I understand there is an audience for this type of movie and that is fine but I felt I wasted my time and money. I don't mind seeing 'bad guys' win once in a while but not evil winning. Leaves you with no hope that good will triumph over evil.The little boy screaming and hissing just made me laugh.A few parts I thought were good. One was when SMG first saw a ghost while taking care of the older woman. Another was in the sister's office building, the security camera video.After I got home I went on this site to see if The Grudge was made by any of the same people as The Ring because it was so similar in many ways. I was waiting for one of the ghosts to say "7 days..." in a raspy whisper. The Ring - you see the tape, you die. The Grudge - you go into the house, you die.

I agree with many of the other viewers who have found this movie much better that THE RING. In fact, I rate this movie an 8 on a scale of 10. Personally, I found THE RING somewhat hokie. But, as someone who considers THE FOG a horror classic (guess I am dating myself); I thoroughly enjoyed this film.Since Hollywood considers films such as the Friday THE 13TH series & FREDDY KRUGER series the best in modern day horror genre; I found this film quite refreshing. It lacked the usual "slasher for the sake of gore" mentality. Though you were often thinking to yourself, "No don't go in there"; as another viewer pointed out characters are not supposed to know that they are in a horror movie. So, even though you are thinking those thoughts it doesn't minimize the rationality of the characters actions or thought processes.I feel that the flash back sequences helped to establish the "history" of the curse & though somewhat disjointed, this worked for me. While my partner criticized that many of the "jump" scenes frequently faded to black; as another friend pointed out that this effect helped you to re-establish reality/calm down before the next scene.Again, if you are looking for a scary movie that is not cast from the general slasher mold; then I feel that you will enjoy THE GRUDGE.

So I went with my friends to go see this movie with very low expectations. Why I had low expectations are odd, because I liked The Ring, but they were still low nonetheless.Line was forming, so we started to join it. It was 7:30 at the time. We start to walk in, and luckily, it was still a little early, and seats were not an issue.Once the movie started, I noticed that the theater was FULL. Not surprised. Movie starts, first ten minutes and already, I feel suspense. Audience was a blast. (Screaming their heads off, etc.)The movie followed some scenes and sections very well to the original JU-On:The Grudge.SMG was OKAY. Just OKAY. I'm not a fan of her...Some scenes are very creepy, and you will jump once in while.I liked the fact that they kept the same people to play the little boy, the girl, etc.The movie left me surprised and happy that I saw it.I'm giving it a solid 8/10.

I found this movie almost unwatchable. The first half-hour made absolutely no sense to me, whatsoever. I almost shut it off, because I had no clue what was going on; each successive scene contained characters different from anything we'd already seen, at different places, doing different things.I thought maybe they would all connect, and they did, eventually, but by that point, I'd forgotten who everyone was and why they were there.Sarah Michelle Gellar's acting is terrible. You don't really know why she does anything, it seems...The "jump" moments are okay, which is why I gave it two stars, but the end was so not-scary I just laughed, the entire time. The woman, groaning, coming down the stairs... that noise that's supposed to be scary but just sounds like someone with a dying radio in their throat coughing up a hairball everywhere... and then the woman in the closet, "oh no!! be scared!" Hated it. I refuse to see The Grudge 2...

I was not very scared by this movie at all. Others I have talked to said it was the scariest movie they had seen in a long time, but I was not that impressed. It made me jump once, after that, I realized that that was all the movie was really going to do to try to scare me, was make me jump. Other than that, the movie really doesn't have much substance. The acting could have been much better, but wasn't totally horrible. It really seems to me to be one of the usual, bland, fad-horror movies that don't really deserve to be called horror. However, Sarah Michelle Gellar is cute, as always, and some of the scenery is great, the Japanese architecture is awesome! I suggest waiting until it comes on TV so you don't have to waste your money at the theater.

Review title: This ones a rental (if you and a few friends like to heckle films)
Review_body: Thanks to many of the assurances by the press and a few cast members of this film, I am less likely to attempt to see the original Japanese version.This movie was predictable, and boring, in every aspect.The acting left much to be desired, the fear on actors faces looks like they fear the slum this film might put their acting careers into. The scary noises that the boy ghost makes are about as frightening to me as the same sounds my niece produces to annoy people at dinner time (little more that breathing slowly while holding your throat closed to produce a croaking/popping sound).The film reminded me mostly, of The Ring meets 21 grams, with its jumpy cutting between past and present.The only way this film will frighten you, is if the audience riots demanding its money back.Any suggestion of this film containing anything of the "strange horror" that is found in some of the newer Techno-age Horrors coming out of Japan and many other parts of Asia is a blatant lie. This film was filmed in Japan, and yet aside from some subtitled conversations, and the sceenery, it comes across as almost completely American.If you payed to see this film, you should feel cheated. If you had the opportunity of receiving a free ticket to it like me, you'll want to ask for a refund of your wasted time.To those of you who liked this film and actually got scared by it, i would like to suggest some much better horror films. Such as Sweating to the Oldies 1-4 because Richard Simmons is vastly more frightening, and the scariest part, he's real! And for those of you who want plot line to go with your mind numbing terror.I can suggest anything staring the Olson twins, I know they've scarred me for life.

This movie has gotten mostly negative reviews from critics, and so many people who saw the movie were probably prejudiced against it from the very beginning, and so not able to enjoy it for what it's really worth. You've got to allow yourself to be scared, and be drawn into the Japanese city and the small, cursed house. This movie is actually quite scary while you're watching it, though the problem is that it doesn't have enough substance to leave a strong after-effect, like the kind that makes you keep your lights on at night. The acting isn't superb, and the characters are rather stereotypical, but that is all suitable for this kind of film. On the other hand the directing and cinematography are both very good. The suspense never lets up, though the movie's main flaw is that it reveals the ghost too soon and too often, and the ghost actually looks pretty comical. We fear what is unknown, and as long as the ghost is hidden from the screen we fear it.Overall an enjoyable and frightening movie, though there is nothing in it to ingrain itself in your memory and haunt your dreams (and maybe sometimes that's a good thing).

Asian films do not translate well to western culture, which is probably why Sam Raimi tried to cross the divide by setting The Grudge amongst the American community in Japan whilst retaining the original Japanese director. A bold move for a Hollywood movie, but it really didn't help much. Apart from an insight into what it might be like for a westerner to live in Japan, I found the whole experience unengaging, incongruous and mystifying. What was mean't to be scary was actually quite laughable, and when I went for a meal afterwards I found myself mimicking that strange rattling sound every time I saw a Japanese girl with heavy make-up. The Box Office results for this film are the result of three key ingredients; the producers reputation, the actress from Buffy, an excellent poster and the financial P&A might of the studio. None of it has anything to do with the film itself. If you want good horror, check out the following; Saw, Switchblade Romance and The Last Horror Movie

my friends told me they really liked this movie; that is was tense and frightening, relentlessly terrifying the audience. I have learned that my friends must be compulsive liars.the plot, little that it is, is quite awful. But hey, its a horror film, and as so many people would say, 'fuck plot.' fine, i'll do that. forget about the plot. the entire basis for scaring people in this film is "shock." and apparently, swift moving objects and sudden loud bursts of noise are the most horrifying things on earth. There was maybe one scene of extended suspense, but even then my heart wasn't racing even close to the speed that it beats after a big cup of coffee. I got really annoyed with the 'creapy' spirits too. I'm sorry, but a naked little Japanese boy with a habit of screaming does not make me jump out of my seat. Was he a little unnerving at first? oh yes. Does this sustain throughout the movie? apparently for a lot of the cackling, shrieking, obnoxiously-yelling-at-the-screen audience, it did.and, the ending... i wouldn't want to spoil it, but there's not much to spoil.

Review title: It Grips The Hell Out Of Me
Review_body: Usually, movies which are remade turns out either good or bad. I've watched The Ring and I thought, well, it was not that bad although the standards of horror dropped slightly than the originals. Then, here comes The Grudge, the remake of one of the scariest Japanese film. My mind was always saying "Crap! Not another The Ring".. But then, after seeing the well-displayed poster on my neighbourhood theater, it looks convincing for me to watch.. And so did I watched it. The opening sequence is a Classic Moment. Scared the HELL out of me. As for the storyline, it did lack of a certain things which was left out from the original. The scripts is in a way SIMPLE but the casts made the SIMPLE script into something WIDE just by their acting. Sarah Michelle Gellar (known for her role in Buffy and 2 Box Office Horror Movies for Scream 2 and I Know) brings out the character really well. I personally think she should just stick to acting in horror movies because that's her specialty. She maybe Hollywood's well known horror queen if the right movie comes. Jason Behr, Clea Duvall, Bill Pullman and KaDee Strickland also gave their fair best work in the movie. But credits for scaring will have to go to the "MOTHER AND SON DUO" because after i left the theater, i felt like they are just behind me.. Scary! And the Spooky House as well.. Good location and the right atmosphere has been spread out really neat. Overall, THE GRUDGE has in a way do justice for the original.My rating : 7.5 stars out of 10

One Great scary movie! Keeps the suspense and thrill throughout. Just accept that the supernaturals do have powers in this film, and you will find this a truly fun roller-coaster ride!!It keeps you wanna scream and laugh and engaged at the same time. It is funny cos you know that the ghosts are just so fake and unrealistic, but then the music and the way it was shot keeps you engaged, makes you wanna hold your breath at lots of points.Watch this in the theatre or a place with big screen and good sound system. Try not to watch this if you have jobs that does door-to-door surveys or in-house visits, or if you are prone to heart attacks, otherwise, this won't haunt you like when you stand in front of the TV at night after you watch <The Ring>, but it gives you a good heart/lung muscles exercise, and you will find yourself having lots of fun in the theatre!

Now at they, it's hard to watch a good horror movie. This production of THE GRUDGE, it is very good. I usually don't like horror or scary movies, because they seem more of a comedy than horror. But this movie have a very good plot, a very good punch scenes and fairly good performances. I am invited to watch it again, and I sugestt you go and watch it too, it will be better if you go with someone if you get afraid with ease. The very first minutes are just amazing as well as the last once, however, like I said before, it is very worth watching. Believe me.Ricardo Urroz, Flmmaker Student

Excellent performance by Sarah Michelle Gellar. Story line was not void of interesting plot and the movie moved at a very good pace. Only beef is that the ending leaves you feeling a bit like you've just seen the ending to Blair Witch Project.There was also a good mix of frightening scenes that didn't need to be embellished with gore. I was surprised to learn that Sam Raimi had produced the movie, but, I know he has a life outside of Spiderman. Good return to the days when he was with Bruce Campbell.Overall, a great movie to take a date to and good for a scare.

Another Japanese film made remade for the world market that hits the spot for shocks but fails due to a poor story which isn't explained fully and has a predictable ending.Karen Davis (Gellar) is working in Tokyo as a home help nurse.When an employee fails to show for work Karen gets the job to care for an elderly lady at her house.All is well until strange noises take her to one of the bedrooms where she finds a small boy in a wardrobe,from then a series of events make Karen realize that all is not as it seems and that the house has a terrifying history that takes all who enter.The films scary moments have the desired effect (my wife missed most of the film as she was too busy hiding behind her hands)but the film lacks the flowing story of The Ring and fails to tie up the loose ends and a predictable ending leaves one feeling underwhelmed and cheated with the inevitable sequel to come in the future

I didn't have a chance to see it in theaters so I had to wait for the DVD. I thought that it was a decent horror movie. There were some truly terrifying scenes that had me cringing. As a rule, I do not take Sarah Michelle Gellar seriously as an actress, though I thought she did a passable job. Bill Pullman did not have much of a role. I thought he should have had more screen time considering he is a rather good actor. The one thing that brings this movie down is the weak plot. Good Lord. I can understand when people say that this is SCARIER than the Ring, but no way can it even touch the Ring's story. Don't expect a mind bending plot filled with great twists and turns. Expect a rather basic story with a bunch of scary scenes. Some aspects of the film were either not explained or simply left open to interpretation. The ending was sorely lacking. It ended on a cliffhanger. Overall I would not recommend spending too much on it. Borrow it from a friend if you can. Renting is up to you. Five bucks seems about right if you want to see it just once. Sequel coming in 06. Maybe it will be better.

Review title: Alright this is a review for the movie "The Ring" oh wait no, sorry "The Grudge", oh wait no sorry my mistake it was "The Ring" wait wait wait alright I don't know, but they wer
Review_body: Alright, just in case you were wondering, the summary up there was a joke. This IS a summary for the grudge but it was almost exactly like the Ring that it was surprising. First off, they were both directed by the same man, Takashi Shimizu. That might explain their uncanny resemblance but who knows?Anyway.... This movie was not to good. It was totally unoriginal and had a horribly boring plot. You could almost always tell what was going to happen which made it even less scary. There were parts of it that were totally overdone and didn't make sense that I wont talk about, but I know that if you've seen it you know what I am talking about. I gave it a one out of ten which I guess was kind of harsh, but it was just so bad. At least there was a shower scene with Sarah Michelle Gellar. But aside from that, nothing. I advise you not to waste ten bucks to go see this awful movie.

Review title: Alright this is a review for the movie "The Ring" oh wait no, sorry "The Grudge", oh wait no sorry my mistake it was "The Ring" wait wait wait alright I don't know, but they wer
Review_body: Alright, just in case you were wondering, the summary up there was a joke. This IS a summary for the grudge but it was almost exactly like the Ring that it was surprising. Yeah, it's scary. One jump after the next with some great scare tactics to make you wet your pants. I have to hand it to the lack of gore horror, it's great. The movie was...however...not. A scattered plot, a sea of death...it was basically a slasher with no sex or blood. (spoilers ahead)...Now, there are some definitely haunting images. The girl, of course, has that look of panic, and you're never quite sure what it is she's after, but the whole stair scene is just creepy, she makes it work. The desperation that she has to kill is something that isn't seen in many monster films anymore, and I do note this is a monster movie. Yoko missing a jaw...that one is going to give me nightmares. It was a short scene, albeit a haunting one, but not completely unpredictable. That was most definitely the problem, the movie was FAR too predictable. If you've ever scene a jumpy movie, then you'll know far in advance when something is going to jump out at you. The creaking sound is creepy, but never given reason, which makes it less scary. A great sound effect, but the editing team and writer could have taken lessons from the team that did the remake of "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre", or the various Friday the 13th movies. If you have a scary sound, use it wisely. Basically, this will appeal to any idiot who wants to scream their heads off and have steamy sex afterwards, but for anyone who is looking for a well-plotted intelligent film, I'll be waiting for "The Ring 2" with you.

so, being a fairly deep fan of horror movies, it's been a while since i've seen one that really made me jump (or fidget nervously.)definitely going to get this on DVD when it comes out... a hell of a lot better than the ring. the thing that i don't get is that so many people that we talkd with after the movie thought that it was horrible, well, if that's what you think, then so be it... i know what i liked and it takes a fair amount to get me to actually feel scared, so i have to say that this one is worth watching.now, you might be disappointed in the story if you need everything in a neat and tidy line, because the plot goes back an forth a little bit to help build the story (i think that if it was shown in chronological order, it would have ruined the whole thing.)i'm actually glad that this movie had very little bloody messes in it... maybe the rest of you studio writers and whathaveyous will realize that you don't have to splash the red stuff all over the set to make people afraid.

I would first like to state that this movie did what it was supposed to do..scare you and creep you out! it was a great ride and I hope there will be a sequel done for us over here in America. We loved "The Ring", but we have to put "The Grudge" ahead of it..this movie created fear, jumps, anxiety and rates high on the "freak-out" meter. As far as being a movie that people were laughing at, as some reviews have stated, in our "Grudge" experience the laughter was NERVOUS laughter covering up for the fact that people were getting scared and freaked-out...MANY said exactly that after the movie was over. virtually everybody in the theatre that night LOVED this movie and I, for one, cannot wait to get it on DVD. If you are a fan of horror flicks, ESPECIALLY ghost movies, then RUN to the theatre to see this right away! You will not be disappointed! (contrary to some of the uptight reviews...ignore them).

*sigh* the only part of this movie that was laughable was all the awful comments from people trying to prove their intelligence by ripping the movie apart with big words they must have just learned. This movie was GOOD. I'm sorry that because the scenes jumped around many of you were confused, but it wasn't THAT hard to follow. There WAS a plot, and I think people misunderstood many parts. It is when someone dies in a fit of great rage or EXTREME SORROW (just like the officer said to SMG) that it leaves a stain on the place of the event. It curses the place where it happened. I loved the way the movie jumped around, because it leaves you wanting to know more, but also learning what has happened before. It is a technique that Stephan King uses in many of his books. It drives me nuts, but I love it at the same time.Now maybe I'm a wuss, but i was squeezing my boyfriends arm the whole time. I don't like long drawn out gore sessions, but I do enjoy all the waiting for them to happen. The sound the girl made was CREEPY because its a sound that isn't manufactured like that of the video in "The Ring". This movie dealt with average people, and people that died simply because they entered the wrong house. That's what made it so scary. They didn't go looking for the curse, and they weren't bad people. It was innocents dying for no reason.The ending was fitting for this movie. Everybody who has pointed out that they left it open for a sequel.....DUH. You think? This movie is a remake of a movie that ALREADY HAS A SEQUEL. Oi, people...come on.In closing.....this movie was good if you have the intelligence to follow it. It's good if you're going to sit back and enjoy it. It will haunt you afterwards if you have ANY type of imagination. This movie's plot isn't just handed to you, but if you think about it, it will come. It's a great movie for guys to take their girlfriends to ;)!

This is one of the most un-scary movies ever. It was a ridiculously stupid ending. I can't even delve into how bad it was because it is pissing me off, but umm I will.... It was just bad. The direction was at least decent, but it was way too much like the Ring, it seems like they used the same type of cinematography. They sure used the same type of scares..... the really stupid kind. Why did they have that stupid old ladies' hand hit the ground, and then add a really loud bang which in no way could have been caused by her hand hitting the floor? Thats plain stupid. Its those kind of cheap scare tactics(sorry I know there is a retarded show of that name)that make horror movies bad and not scary, thus not really horror movies. But overall Sara Gellar is hot, I would send it to her.

I saw this movie yesterday and actually was a bit bored with it. Sure, i got scared by the countless scenes of another scary looking pale boy/woman popping up in an unexpected place (properly triggered by a typical gloomy low pitched sound), but that can't quite cover up for the lack of tension and consistency and the one dimensional characters.Maybe it's the American version that does it. I saw the original Japanese versions of "The Ring" and "Dark Water" and they scared the living daylights out of me. "The Ring" is a movie that still scares med today, several years after watching it.Back to "The Grudge": The cast, in my opinion, feels way to big for a minimalistic thriller like this. What are all these people doing there? Bill Pullman is absolutely wasted in that little part that he plays. It feels like the director tried to squeeze the cast of three movies into one.The ending: It seems that they are all going to die anyways, so what's the point in getting emotionally involved? And of course the body of Karens boyfriend has to suddenly move under the sheet. How surprising. Spend your money on a more original thriller/horror movie than this.

Review title: Don't Judge It Until You've Seen It.
Review_body: Overall, an good horror remake. It's full of scary scenes and Sarah Michelle Gellar puts in a really good performance. I suppose the only bad thing about it is that it doesn't create much suspense to build up the horror and some of the stuff used has been done before, (But most of it is original).At the end it's left at a cliffhanger. Bring on Grudge 2, See this if you liked 'The Ring'.My movie rating: 7/10

But i still recoommend you watch the grudge- it will stay in your head for days!

Review title: The Grudge is an unapologetic ghost story that delivers A+ shocks and thrills and a truly eerie sense of foreboding.
Review_body: As a lifelong disappointed horror film fan, I was finally sated with the Grudge! I must say that to all those people out there like myself; a long suffering fan of the horror film genre, this is our movie! A true horror film achieves what the Grudge does: scare the s*&$t out of you. How many times over countless decades have we been let down by one numbing slasher, ghost story, cheesy monster flick after another. Filmmakers in this genre seem to have low opinions of their target audience. Predictable plots, boring characters that you HOPE will die in some gory way, and black cats jumping through windows at just the precise moment while all along a soundtrack plays in the background giving away everything and telling you when to be scared and when to take a breather, seem to be the rule. Now we have The Grudge, which shoves its way past those pretenders, re-inventing the genre. I will admit, when I first noticed this film open last Fall and Sarah Michelle Gellar headline the poster, I was skeptical. Here we go again, another dumbed down Horror film targeted at the teenage Saturday night date audience. And it was rated PG-13! Wrong again I was. Think of Gellar as one of those quarterbacks on a great football team: not such a fine athlete or prolific Hall-of-Famer, but a team player who blends in with the others. She doesn't make mistakes that cost the team a victory, throws the ball away when there is no play, and realizes she is not above anyone else on the field. She is adequate and appropriate for the role. In fact, the entire cast in the film is of the same comparison. They are merely vessels that carry the narrative, chess pieces in an ultimate game of fear and dread. I won't say too much about the plot because most of the other reviews have done a fine job in describing its non-linear progression, even though it was a good deal less episodic than the original; a positive in my opinion. It is also a film that will stay with you for a long while afterwords. I just saw it and it is all I can think about, and I have a feeling it will be with me for a few days to come. Perhaps our young American "Horror" filmmakers should travel to Japan and get schooled by this fresh crop of Asian newbies to the genre. We will all be the better for it! I want more!

this movie was absolutely the worst i have seen in a very long time, and I've seen some pretty bad movies, i mean it couldn't get much worse than napoleon dynamite, but oh wait then the grudge came out. this movie was at best a scare for 16 year old girls who just wanted to get held. it was predictable and way to choppy. the touch of "the ring" there in the middle was cheap at best. the story line was almost impossible to follow until you realized there was no story line and that this movie was going no where, fast. i wouldn't recommend this to anyone, as a matter of fact, i think ill ask blockbuster for my money back.

The last ghost movie I've seen that made me feel a bit uncomfortable was "What Lies Beneath". A suggestive movie that had the touch to really creep you out with the occasional scares.When a friend of mine asked me if I would like to join him for a movie night out for The Grudge, a new horror movie with Buffy, my expectations were low. I don't like too much blood, gore and all that other stuff that's actually more hilarious than frightening. And when he said the word "horror", that was the first thing that popped into my mind.But from the first scene of The Grudge, I immediately had the feeling that this could be another kind of terror. And, my oh my, during the entire movie, I held my hand in front of my face, scared of what was coming next! I never thought a movie could be so extremely psychological terrifying. A good horror movie is a movie that scares the h*ll out of me, and The Grudge did more than that. Perfect camera angles, creepy music or just nothing but silence. Excellent.My friends and I still talk about it and we all agree that this is the best horrorfilm we've seen until now. Props to Takashi Shimizu for making this film as it is now! It worked ... it definitely worked. ;-) Can't wait for the second americanized installment.

Japan has a long, ghostly tradition with beings from beyond the grave. Nemerous stories and legends in Japan of these otherworldly visitors abound. Ghosts often play key roles in Kabuki theater and were a favorite though perhaps somewhat overly-used character by Kabuki playwrights. Many of the ghosts that appear in plays and stories are females seeking revenge for wrongs done to them during their lifetime typically by cruel, heartless husbands.In the old ghost stories, vengeful Japanese ghosts would continue haunt their victims until they went insane, died, or at least made some form of restitution to appease the angry spirits. Some Japanese ghosts were born out of tragedy or sorrow and would haunt any person who came near. These spirits were particularly feared because they represented a danger to all unless they were somehow put to rest.Although I knew about the horrific nature of old Japanese ghosts, I had thought modern Japanese ghosts would be more polite and demur. I had imagined a modern Japanese ghost timidly coming up to someone and saying "Suimasen - Excuse me! BOO! Gomen naisai -I'm sorry!" before whisking away. "The Grudge" showed me how wrong I was about modern Japanese phantoms."The Grudge," starring Sarah Michelle Gellar of TV's "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" fame, depicts a haunting by very impolite spirits. Gellar plays an American student nurse in Tokyo who accidentally gets involved with a haunted house that has the nasty habit of killing visitors. The ghosts of the house were victims of a tragedy and now they rudely kill anyone who comes in contact with them.The spirits' motivation for killing is explained at the beginning of the film in a brief written prologue which states: "when someone dies in the grip of a powerful rage, a curse is left behind." For Western audiences it may seem unusual that the two main ghostly antagonists who having been innocent victims of a violent death themselves would seek to cause the death of another innocent person. This flies in the face of a Western audience's sense of justice and fairness.In many Western ghost stories, ghosts despite their spookiness are often motivated by the same things as living people namely the pursuit of justice for wrongdoings. The ghost of a murdered person will seek vengeance on the person or persons responsible for their death.If a ghost is malevolent, it often turns out they were a bad person in life - as in the back-story to the main ghost character in the "Poltergeist" movies.To understand the nature of the supernatural entity of "The Grudge," one has to understand Japanese belief in spirits and the supernatural.In the book "Ghosts and the Japanese: Cultural Experience in Japanese Death Legends" by Michiko Iwasaka, there is a passage which is a direct echo of the opening lines of the movie: "Anyone who dies under great emotional stress creates an energy which is not easily dissipated; these yurei - ghosts, thus, have an impact on the local environment..." This type of spirit is called a "goryo" - vengeful ghost. A goryo, however, is less like a consciously aware ghost that plots revenge like those featured in Kabuki plays and which would be more familiar to Western audiences. A goryo is more like the energy of the emotion created at the time of death. And to some degree it represents the unconscious mind free of the limitations and morals of the conscious analytic side.Formal belief of goryo can be traced to the Heien Period (794-1185) when goryo were believed to be the angry spirits of political enemies that had died in exile or had been executed. The noted scholar Sugawara-no-Michizane became one such goryo. Through guileful manipulations, his enemies at the Imperial Court engineered his banishment from Kyoto. Sugawara died in extreme sorrow while in exile. Shortly after his death, a number of natural disasters occurred from droughts and epidemics to lightening strikes. It was believed to be caused by the angry spirit of Sugawara. To appease his goryo, Sugawara was given ceremonial promotion at the Imperial Court and eventually he was made into a god-spirit whom modern-day students pray to for success on their exams.Director Takashi Shimizu has built on this old concept to create a deadly goryo of a very frightening ghostly Mother and Son duo. "The Grudge" is an American remake of the original Japanese thriller "Ju-on" (2003). "Ju-on" is Shimizu's horror franchise. "Ju-on" grew out of a short TV story to become a successful and scary theater-release movie which was followed by a sequel. Famed Spiderman director, Sam Ramie, who helped produce the American remake thought "Ju-on" to be one of the scariest movies he had ever seen."The Grudge" opened in America during the Halloween season last fall but it has only recently opened in Japan. One notable difference is the inclusion of a few extra violent moments that were left out in the American version in order for the movie to keep a PG-13 rating in the States.Overall there's not much of story. Some people die, then some other people die. Most of the film is just one scare after another with little character development or plot. "The Grudge" is more like a series of creepy vignettes strung together to make a film. However, these vignettes are quite scary. Its the cultural nuance of the goryo-type spirit that "The Grudge" represents and the genuinely frightening moments that makes the film an interesting experience for Japan-o-philes and horror fans alike.On the Scare-O-Meter, "The Grudge" rates about 4 out 5 Screams.On Plot, it rates about 2 stars out of 5; however the concept behind the movie rates about a 4.

Review title: The Ring for those with a brain
Review_body: Having started with the inevitable comparison in the title, I'll side-step the whole "Ring vs Grudge" argument for later. The Grudge is actually a remake of a Japanese film Ju-on: the Grudge aka Ju-on 3, the third, (obviously), in a series of movies.It's impossible to tell you the storyline, without giving away some of the "surprises" in the plot, so go ahead and skip to the next paragraph if you don't want to spoil those surprises. The basic story, set in Japan, is that of an American family taking up residence in a house whose previous occupants had been involved in domestic murder/suicide. Enter Sarah Michelle Geller as the new American care worker for the disabled mother, (the first care worker having been dispatched in one of the opening scenes) and all manner of spooky goings on ensue. It seems that anyone entering the house, is subject to "The Grudge" or curse that now haunts the house, and after a short period of time is visited by an apparition which.... well you don't actually see what it does, but you know its just not pleasant.To judge The Grudge is not that easy, it's rather non-liner style does mean that the viewer has to carefully pay attention to the movie as the story unfolds. Unlike The Ring, (which I thought was pretty excellent), which washed over and enveloped you into the storyline, The Grudge is far more subtle in it's scares. For example, when one of the characters is in an elevator, going to the top of her building, if you don't pay attention to what's going on in the background, the scene just looks like a woman in an elevator. Nothing scary there, right? But by paying attention, the viewer is left with an impending sense of dread, as the character alights the elevator, and enters her apartment, oblivious to her fate. It is subtlety such as this, that will escape anyone who thought Friday the 13th was a demanding experience, and leave them a bit cold. This is NOT an in your face movie.It's ironic that perhaps The Grudge's biggest strengths, could also be regarded as some of its biggest weakness'. The film is shot in such a way as to make the viewer is a rather dispassionate voyeur on the unfolding events. This approach is good, in that we get to see all parts of the story, and are able to piece things together in a way the characters cannot. However, it can leave the viewer feeling a little uninvolved also. Too, as mentioned in the storyline paragraph, all the actual killings occur off camera. Wonderful for those of us with an imagination, not so good for the "if it don't splatter, it don't matter" brigade.The Japanese certainly have their own style of movie making, and Takashi Shimizu who directs, (I believe this is his first film for western audiences), thankfully does not compromise that style too much. The time line jumps, are used to explain events after we have seen them, and rather than the usual "creepy" music, a soul chilling sound is used to build tension, and let us the viewer know of an imminent attack by the apparition. This certainly will not to be everyone's taste, but then I like my movies to confuse me, then give me a chance to work things out, rather than spell them out to me one syllable at a time.I started this off side-stepping the whole "Ring vs Grudge" debate, and will address that now. Let's start this off by looking at what they have in common. Both were based on Japanese films, (Ringu for The Ring and Ju-on: The Grudge aka Ju-on 3 for The Grudge). Both have apparitions with lots of hair. Both have creepy kids in them, and and both are ghost stories. Its there that the direct comparisons really end. To have seen one is definitely not to have seen the other. Was one "inspired" (read ripped off), by the other, quite possibly, but who cares? Tarantino has been making movies "inspired" by other movies for years, and we love him for it.The performances by the actors are adequate, nothing Oscar winning, but certainly good enough to keep things believable.To summarize. The Grudge is a good little movie, to be watched when one can give it ones full attention, and at night with the lights low and someone special to cling to for the scary bits. Watching it with distractions, (kids going to bed, won't go to bed, friends visiting and insisting on talking all the way through the movie, etc.), is NOT going to work.Overall, a good ghost story, and well worth the watch.

Review title: The scene about the innocent girl at the beginning of the movie...
Review_body: I have to admit that, even though I am a 20 year old man, the scene where the tongue slipped out from a certain part of the young Japanese girl's face (I have no idea how to describe it; however if you saw the movie, you know what I'm talking about) scared the sh*t out of me! Review title: Scare after scare, it never forgives
Review_body: The Grudge, a remake of a Japanese film (Ju-on), is pretty well-made. The music adds suspense to the scenes and moments that make you jump and spill your popcorn are thrown in everywhere.The story is set in Tokyo when Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar) is assigned to care for Emma, a woman who appears lost to the world, when her previous caretaker, Yoko (Yoko Maki), disappears and doesn't return for work. After first meeting Emma, Karen goes to explore the house and then the scares begin soon after she finds a duct taped closet.This movie is not like any horror film I've ever seen. Some say it's too much like the Ring, but I think otherwise. The ghosts, spirits in this movie who are left because they died in powerful rage or sadness, don't just pop out, say "Boo!" or "Seven days.", Kayoko is welcomed into the scene by the noise she makes through her throat since her throat was crushed by her jealous husband and Toshio is recognized by his cat or his hisses and meows. It's not just a haunted house, either. The house isn't really haunted, it's the people who spend time in the house. Kayoko is found haunting many other places elsewhere.I hope this comment helps and gives you a new view of the movie. I rate it 9/10 because it scared the crap out of me.

My younger sister was so excited about this movie, she watched it about 5 times. And forced me to watch it with her on a boring Sunday afternoon.The truth be told the pictures where not that scary but the sound! I suffer of tinnitus and the beeping all the time was not the healthiest thing.And those sounds deep from the throat! I was so scared that I stayed awake for about 48 hours, even my bed was not a shelter anymore for me. You know what happened to the girl hiding under her sheets.It took about a month until I was able again to find some proper sleep. And now we know...there are things much worse than death...

To be honest, The Grudge, in my opinion is a fantastic film. The way it is written and the settings and the actors, everything about it is good. The girl that plays the actual 'grudge ghost' is brilliant. She looks amazing and does the whole thing really well. From what I can gather, the director is a brilliant director. It's not really gory and I suppose some people might find it quite scary but I didn't. I'm completely stunned by the film and I've become obsessed with learning Japanese language and doing other Japanese stuff. I think maybe Sarah Michelle Geller kind of spoils it a bit but only slightly. I guess its because every time you see Sarah Michelle Geller you stereotype her as Buffy and therefore cant imagine seeing her in anything else. All in all its a great movie. No hang ups about it. ITS A MUST SEE!!!!!!!!!!

When i borrowed this movie off a friend, i wasn't expecting an amazing movie. I was expecting an entertaining horror movie with some bad lines and a few jumps to keep me entertained. What i got was an insufferable bore. The characters are all without development or personality, the plot is virtually non-existent and the film is full to the brim with long, slow paced scenes which leave your mind to wander off on unrelated tangents for five minutes or so ("what shall i eat for dinner tonight?") when suddenly you realise that you're supposed to be feeling tense! The only good thing i can think of to say about this film is that in parts, it's so bad that it's funny. My recommendation - don't let this film rob you of 92 minutes of your life, you'll never get them back.

I watched this movie when I was 13 years old and it literally traumatised me. I am now 27 years old and still can't watch it as I have panic attacks. It's well made but I won't ever watch it again. Can't handle the noise she makes.

I'm a big fan of scary movies but it seems like lately there has been a lot of crappy flicks that just don't have it, not The Grudge. I had to wait until this one was on InDemand so I could watch it after my lady went to bed since she doesn't like the scary stuff. I dug the hell out of this flick. It was pretty creepy and had just the kind of stuff I'm looking for in a scary movie. Also, I'm not at all a Sarch Michelle Gellar fan but she was good in this, I have to say. It's worth a look for sure. The one thing that I expected (as I expect with all movies of this genre) was a B.S. ending which The Grudge certainly has but what the heck, right? You can't have everything. Definitely worth a look.

Review title: Holy....fuji (no pun intended). Advice: don't leave creaky doors in the house untreated after this one!
Review_body: "Oh...my...effing....god...." That was all I could say after the movie began and the first little chills started the goosebumps going. I've seen this movie four times, and to tell you the truth, it just gets better and better. I'm still paranoid. I am waiting for one of the ghosts to pop up in a really stupid, random place (shower, wardrobe, behind door, in locker, etc.). Paranoia factor: 10. --WARNING!!: Following contains plot spoilers--The film opens with a quickly-quick-quick explanation of the term 'Grudge' (in the movie's sense). What would have made it creepier is it as a dictionary entry. Strike half a point. Next, we see Yoko, a caretaker for Emma, an elderly American woman who appears to be catatonic (did I spell that right?). Well, lah de dah. The house is trashed. By 'trashed' I mean 'rubbish everywhere, newspaper up the stairs' you get the idea. It looks like a bomb hit it. Well, Yoko, being a caretaker, understandably starts the cleanup, whilst chatting away in Japanese to a friend on the phone. Whilst diligently picking up paper, she hears a sort of walking noise above her. What's the room above her? The attic of course! (cliche #1) Well, her being a girl, she heads off to investigate. Finds a room, with a crawlspace all boarded up. Here's the stupidity factor: She climbs up the crawlspace, lights a cigarette lighter and promptly begins exploring. Who does she run into? None other than Kayako, the Grudge-girl (as I have happily dubbed her)!Well, I'll be very sketchy now, I felt like describing the opening scenes well. Now, there were many jumps in here, and many points where I yelled out "YOU IDIOT!" at the television screen. For example, when one character gets into bed and pulls the covers up, it's pretty obvious that it'll attack her in bed (hence the term, 'mattress monster'). Although, the security camera scenes were especially scary, owing to the fact that we now know how Kayako moves around and appears (see Ju-On: The Grudge 2 for a clever example). At another point, where Karen jumps in an elevator, you think 'Now you watch, it'll get her in the elevator coz she's a stupid blonde and didn't think!' WRONG!! Karen actually manages to survive through the movie...presumably past the end. Well, to cut it shorter, there were some scenes which were apparently cut from the American release, particularly a scene that was later reused in Ju-On 2, the scene involving the (presumed) husband of the late Kayako, hanging from Kayako's hair being swung by little Toshio (who you will creepily notice seems to pop up before each Kayako appearance). Also, the scene of Toshio being drowned in the bathtub was meant to be cut, but never was. The creepiest scenes of all would have to be the diary scene and the scene unenthusiastically titled 'Kayako Crawls Down The Stairs', which I would have called 'Goodbye Karen'. But that's me. That scene was especially creepy in the way that Kayako moved. Reminiscent of Samara climbing the well in The Ring (or so people tell me), her movements are jerky and insect-like. Rigor mortis, perhaps?The only major error was in the 'Jawless Kayako' scene. Didn't the director ever do Biology in year 8? Or look at the bottom of his tongue in a mirror? If he had, he would know that the tongue is attached to the jaw. I rest my case.All I will say to cut this review a little shorter, is this: Never watch without lights and a teddy bear. --Aurabesh out--

Last two years were a very poor period for horror movies. Movies like House of Wax with Paris Hilton running around like mad trying to sound desperate or The Ring 2 which had become "over-digitalised" with water coming out of the sofa. I gave the 2004 horrors another chance by going to The Grudge and I must say I'm glad I've done that! It's the one of the scariest horror movies in the last 10 years. Even though the main plot is very simple, you don't care much and you simply let yourself flow into the story full of scary scenes and frightening characters. Some of the things didn't make sense to me even after watching it for the second time but maybe I missed something. You really have to watch every frame ;)I loved this movie so much even though the end was typical for all newer horror movies, but check out yourself!

This is a great film if you want a creepy, unnatural experience.It's not the blood and guts of traditional American horror films and I think that is what makes it so great. I think so many American film makers feel if they can put in gore, it makes a good horror flick. To me, the scare factor is what makes a movie downright frightening and I think the Grudge does that.I was stuck with images and sounds from the film for days afterwards - I couldn't get some of the sounds out of my head. Even after the source of the images and sounds were explained in the film, it was still very disturbing.I'm giving it a 9 out of 10 because I do not frighten easily and this scared the living s---- out of me. I haven't had a film cause me to have problems sleeping for years and this one did the trick. Wasn't quite a ten because there were some slow areas and I felt it was slightly unorganized in sparse places.

Review title: Movie theaters nationwide are now cursed...
Review_body: ...by the ghosts of people who died (laughing at how bad this film was) while in the grip of a terrible rage (because they realized they actually paid money to see this).Not going to waste a lot of time explaining here. There was nothing truly scary about it. I'll admit there was a scene or two that startled me a bit but nothing that will keep me up at night. Less than half way through the film I could see all the "scary" parts coming long before they occurred and they weren't that scary when they finally happened.*spoiler*The one thing I did enjoy was the detective. For about 5 minutes there he actually had a brain when he made the decision to burn the house down. But then his brain left him when decided to go inside to do it! Its a Japanese house you idiot! It'll burn well enough from the outside!*end spoiler*My advice, save your money. If your curious wait for a showing in a dollar theater. The best part of this movie is, now maybe Sarah Michelle Gellar will go back to making Buffy.

A completely unnecessary remake of the original. What's the matter with the American producers, or even worse - the audience? Is subtitling really that scary?Is this movie only worth a 1 as compared to the 8 I gave the original then? Well, in all fairness perhaps not. After all it's the same director who's done them both and he's still - despite the bigger budget - been very careful with adding special effects (which usually are the dearth of all American original horror stories). However I maintain that the original was far more effective and a lot more unpleasant to watch.Unpleasantness is after all that which we're looking for in a good horror movie. :)

Review title: If you like them creepie, this is it!
Review_body: If you like creepie movies that will get some real laughs, some nervous laughs, and some real creepy times than this is the movie for you. If you don't like them creepie you should skip this one. The characters seemed well chosen, the acting mostly believable, the sets simple but effective, the story deep enough. If you liked "The Ring" you will probably like this movie, too -- the feel is similar. While I am not a huge fan of Sarah M. Gellar she did a credible job. Bull Pullman is credited but his part is pretty small. While there is the inevitable "why would you do that", it is far less common in this movie than it is in many movies in this genre. All in all, for this kind of movie I would rate it quite highly.

Review title: Scariest horror flick in a long, long time.
Review_body: 'The Grudge' has scenes that will make you jump. It also contains scenes and sequences that will make those hairs on the back of your neck stand up and your skin tingle. The movie is full of energy, flows well, and doesn't contain any dull moments. I thought it was not only more frightening than 'The Ring', it was a better movie overall. If you are a fan of this type of horror genre, you'll enjoy this movie.*SPOILERS*Do not read unless you've seen the movie!There was one scene in this movie that really scared the hell out of me, and it was by far the scariest out of any movie - ever. The part when the detectives climb up into the attic, and eventually find the two bodies holding each other in the corner. I really didn't want to have that picture imbedded in my mind. What did you guys think of it?*END SPOILERS*

There are not many good horror films. But Grudge is one hell of a film without doubt. The whole atmosphere is creepy to the limit. Great Camera and the Sound is scaring you right to the bone - Uhhh that sound. And "Buffy" is pretty cute and helpless in that (hmmmmmm). I will put the film in my top ten with fog, alien, nightmare 3, dellamorte dellamore, ghostship and that stuff.Never seen the original film, but i don't think it can be as good as this one. And forget the ring - Grudge is much better.The story is straight and thats OK only one thing: Here's a curse and he will sneak up from behind and club your ass straight to hell. If thats the curse i hope i ll never met him :-)

Review title: The Grudge; Review from head to toe
Review_body: My boyfriend really wanted to show me this movie. His quote, "It's amazing!" But really, he thinks all horrors are "amazing". So, thinking that it was probably stupid. (like most of the movies he loves) I settle down on the couch, and what do I get? Just what I thought.My boyfriend loves this movie, "one of my favourites" as he said. Me? I would complain if I had to watch it again.The reason this movie was made was to scare you. It didn't do a good job of it though. Okay, it did make me jump at least twice. But I didn't find the movie scary. Most people who haven't watched the movie will say: Ooooooooooooooo, the cover of the box is scary looking! The movie must be sooo scary! Ha.The story itself is okay, except it's with another cliff ending. *sigh* Too many movies these days (in the horror genre) leave with cliffies just so they can make more money off of another one. If The Grudge 2 comes out, I'd actually go to see it. Only if I can rent it though. It's probably a rip-off to see it in the movies.The movie box (the Canadian one that I am talking about is different than the one shown above) makes the movie look terrifying when really it's absolutely not. It is a nice DVD/VHS cover, though.The music (as I can remember) is pretty good. It flows with what is happening and when there isn't music, something important (to the plot) is usually happening.(note the "usualy")And last, the graphics. Well, to put it simple, the computer graphics suck, and the make-up is superb.Did I like this movie?: No. I know the story is okay but I like horror films by there gore/scariness. This didn't show any of what I'm looking for.Pros: The music is pretty good and so is the storyline. Cons: It leaves people with a cliffhanger ending and claiming to be scary, but isn't.The Storyline: 7 The Presentation: 7 The Music: 9 The Graphics: 5Overall: A 7 average

I saw this movie last night at a pre-screening where both Sarah and Jason attended for a few minutes, I had fun and everyone was eager to see this movies...and of course the actors.The ReviewI did not see Ju-On The Grudge, the Japanese version of The Grudge because I wanted to see this movie first and not sound like so many others who hate on remakes because they claim Americans / Hollywood damages everything, which is not always the case...like this movie.*******************************SPOILERS******************************The film starts out with Bill Pullman committing suicide because he witnessed the murder of the family that end up being the mommy ghost (Kayako) and the son (Toshio). The order in which the scenes are shown is random...first is Bill Pullman's character suicide, then 3 years later Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar) comes to the house after a home nurse, Yoko, disappeared (killed by kayako) then it goes back to when the old lady and her kids (clea duvall;daughter in law, Kadee s.;daughter) move in then killed.The plot wasn't strong per say, but enough to lead you on through the whole movie, also the scare factor was high but very little gore or blood. Scary scenes pop up randomly and everyone's performance was great...even Ted Raimi (JOXER!) was good.Sarah was very good and played the victim part to the T, I was happy with it, excellent career move. Jason, Clea and the rest were also good and I agree that even though Sarah was the main attraction, it was an ensemble cast.This is my OWN Opinion but I guess a sequel might be done given Karen doesn't die, who knows.The scary scenes were a real thrill whether you scare easily or not. Things makes you scream...jump...or laugh but I can guarantee that you will have a great time.I give the movie a 4 out of 5.

Review title: The Grudge: It never forgives it never forgets
Review_body: In Japanese legend, there is a curse that occurs when someone dies in a grip of powerful rage. The curse gathers in the place that the person frequented in life, anyone who comes into contact with curse will be consumed by its fury until the curse claims their life, and then spreads to its next victim.The Grudge is an amazing horror story, with a fantastic use of jump scenes to keep you on the edge, or maybe even hiding behind your seat. The creepy imagery and sound effects make it impossible not to be scared, even if you close your eyes! Many people compare The Grudge and The Ring. However The Ring is too drawn out and confusing, but The Grudge keeps you guessing adding the element tension and anticipation.The Grudge keeps you on the edge of your seat because you never know whats round the corner. Much better than the original, its less confusing and a lot more scary, plus you don't have to read as many subtitles! I hope you enjoy this film as much as i did!

Review title: Who's afraid of "The Grudge"? That would be me.
Review_body: Being a fan of 'scary' or 'horror' movies almost from conception, I can honestly say that there are very few movies that have knocked my socks off, but The Grudge is definitely one movie that has done just that. I recently saw "Hostel" and quite honestly, the appeal was the gore, blood and guts. Nothing is to be feared from a dead body. But in The Grudge, it is understood that everything is to be feared from spirits, particularly if they are angry spirits. The movie was genius simply because of one thing: You can't beat something in 2 1/2 hours and have a nice happy ending. Everybody dies, but that's okay. It truly shows that in Japanese culture, it is known and understood that there are things in the world, and in life, that are much bigger than you, and stronger, and more powerful, and sometimes, you just can't beat them. That's just it. That's why the Scream movies s**cked, why the Ring movies really weren't so frightening when you think about it, and why the Saw movies made everybody cringe, no matter how tough you thought you might have been. The story line is great, the lighting and music are perfect, and even in the end, IF YOU REALLY PAY CLOSE ATTENTION TO THE CHARACTERS.....you'll be asking questions when it is over....

Review title: First horror movie i ever watched
Review_body:
I wish I Could give this a 5.5/10 stars but that seems impossible. Anyways,
This movie is medicore to me. There is nothing special to this movie, other
than the horror and slow burning tension ( Which is great ). Here are the
pros and cons for this movie.
Pros:
I dig and really enjoy all of the horror scenes.
It keeps its setting in Japan
Has a great atmosphere
Has a BRILLIANT score.
Horror scenes are intense
Cons:
A Slow burn
Characters are all flat
Dialog is forced at times
a Medicore movieOverall, i think that both of the sequals are better than this movie. Here is how my ranking for the 4 movies go ( Have not had a chance to watch the original 2 movies.)
4. The grudge (2020): 5/10
3. The grudge (2004): 5.5/10
