(sorry if I rambled it required at least ten lines)

I'm not sure I understand where all these enthusiastically anti-grudge people are talking about here, perhaps it's just that some people like to rant about things.The movie was certainly imperfect (uneven acting, some may have had difficulties with the time-changes, actors all too willing to go places I'd really rather not go, etc.) but IMHO there were some things that more than made up for the imperfections.First and foremost, I LOVED the 'breaking of the rules' bit. NORMALLY when you leave the haunted house the baddies leave you alone, giving you time to regroup, get friends, and find the token mysterious paranormal type. NORMALLY (semi-spoiler alert) when you're hiding under the covers they can only get you through that little opening you peek through. NORMALLY at the end the ghosts somehow have become less creepy because you've found out they're just misunderstood, or they've been freed, or whatever.Secondly, the production was exceptional. While the movie was hardly special-effects-laden the supernatural bits while brief were extremely well done.Probably not the best sort of movie for those who think Freddy and Jason are the ultimate sort of horror (nothing against 'em, they've got their place), but great for those who've begun to take the conventions for granted and who don't have trouble with the time distortions.

I thought this movie was horrendous, awful, stupid and incredibly boring. The Grudge is a movie of confusion, so the premise is that because people that were killed in a rage would leave a curse on the place they were killed. Fine, good idea, too bad the movie wasn't as good as the trailers and tag lines. If everyone that entered the house subject to the curse why did it take so long for Sarah Gellers character to die and why didn't they show the real estate agent dying. Also if the "grudge" was the one that killed than why did peter kill himself, it didn't explain. and why was the story only explained to the main character. Another thing is find dumb was the fact that the suspense was not maintained thru out the movie. one saw the deaths coming a mile a way, the music always came to early and was trying to hard to be eerie and the parts that were supposed to be scary were actually laughably funny, especially the part when the dead lady climbed in bed with the sister. I think the movie could have been more than what it was, it only did not try hard enough, unlike other movies it didn't try to trick us or offer some other sort of explanation, it didn't tease us with areas that you expected to be scary, it was pretty straightforward with the scare, and thats where i feel that it made its biggest mistake is when they didn't use opportunities to scare us psychologically, it didn't.

There's so many things that I want to just scream right now, scream at the top of my lungs. Unfortunately, most of these things would be inappropriate for this forum and must be watered-down for the sake of social values. GRR!Anyway, let's get right to it.This is a good movie. Don't be fooled and don't let anyone else tell you any different. In fact, I'll even go so far as to say this is EASILY one of THE best horror movies I've ever seen. Now I absolutely understand that this isn't exactly the popular view right now so for all of you that are cringing and trying not to kick things or hunt me down to "teach me a thing or two" - don't get'cher panties in a bunch. I'm gonna explain myself.I've heard and read a lot of things, bad things, about this movie. "Remaking Japanese horror movies is as big, and over-rated, as reality TV", "The plot is thin, or not there at all", oh and the WORST of all is "Where does the opening scene with Bill Pullman fit in?". Oi...First things first - I've gotta be honest with you. I've never seen 'Ringu' ('The Ring') OR 'Ju On' ('The Grudge'). I've heard great things about them and I'm sure they deserve it too but I have no interest in reading a movie. That's why I watch movies in the first place - so I don't have to read. ESPECIALLY when it comes to movies like this! Horror movies are, by nature, visually driven. If I'm busy reading subtitles to tell me what's going' on I'm not gonna get to fully enjoy the VISUAL experience intended to be had. Thus, let's take this really great movie and redo it in such a way that it will appeal to, and can be enjoyed by, more audiences (i.e. those of us that don't speak Japanese).And yes the plot IS thin. It's no different than any other horror movie out there. So what? It's a horror movie! It's not meant to win Academy Awards or make you ponder some of life's greatest mysteries. There's a whole separate genre for plot-driven movies. They're called dramas. Horror movies are meant to scare you and make you jump. And even if it doesn't make you jump there's something addictive about that rush of adrenaline you get when you know SOMETHING'S about to happen. It's fun! And who doesn't think that little boy is pretty creepy? Or the jerky movement that ghosts have taken on in horror movies of late? Gives me the willies just thinking' of it!And finally, if you don't understand the significance of the opening scene with Bill Pullman, I don't know what to tell ya. I mean I COULD tell you but, you should be able to figure it out for yourself.So to sum it all up, The Grudge IS a good movie. It's a GREAT horror experience that has plenty of creepy images to settle in your head for quite some time. You'll jump all up out your seat once or twice (or more if you're like my girlfriend). Just enjoy it. Don't try to make an epic out of it. Just...let it be, and enjoy it.

I felt like this movie was the best horror I had seen in a long time. The previews of the movie that I saw on television did not do justice to this movie. The Grudge kept me on pins and needles from the very beginning to the end. The Grudge grabbed my attention from the beginning and held it until the end. Sara Michelle Gellar did a terrific job in portraying her role. If you are someone that enjoys horror movies without all the gore, this movie is for you. I'm not much into the "slasher" movies, so I enjoyed watching this movie! The movie and the happenings were not what I had figured out they would be. A total surprise! I can't wait until it comes out on DVD so I can watch it again.

The grudge was an awesome movie. it kept me startled till the very end.The starting is a little vague, but they build into excellent detail at the end. The casting in this film was excellent and the actors really seemed to get into their parts. You may have to read a few subtitles, but it is well worth it.also the special effects and makeup are extremely wicked.Just the blood and guts alone were enough to keep me interested.The audio was as scary as it possibly could be. There was a little too much screaming though. i recommend not watching this before bed because it will keep you awake.

i like my horror films and have become accustomed to your average "jumpy" film... the same old tricks, reflections in the mirror yada yada... not this film though!! if you want to be scared see this film, OK the story's not to strong and the characters shallow but who cares when its just this scary!? we even had that nervous laughter in the cinema when you just know everyones scared sh*tless and are desperate to comfort themselves. If you liked the ring see this, if you like horror films see this, if you like films see this....... i think you get the picture! who lives in a house like this?? not bloody me thank god!9 out of ten...even after three days i still don't like the dark!

Review title: Not as bad as I thought it would be...
Review_body: Every few years, a new trend in Hollywood Horror comes out and everybody jumps on the bandwagon. In the mid-90s, it was Scream that started the trend of horror movies starring the hottest teen hunks of the day with plots that seemed to be self-satirical or one of the least important aspects of the film. Now, in the mid-00s, a new trend has emerged. In my mind it started with The Ring, but the true starting point is probably up for grabs.Horror directors these days seem to think that by throwing a bunch of weird, off-the-wall images and concepts on the screen, that somehow this will translate into a scary picture. Unfortunately, it does not accomplish this goal. While the shock factor may be high in movies such as The Grudge, as soon as the lights come back on in the theater, the fright is gone and I, as an audience member, am left unfufilled. That being said, The Grudge was not the worst of these type of films, and I thought it did have a few interesting plot points. I thought that the cop who was obsessed with the house was the most intriguing character, and Bill Pullman's character was also unique. Overall, though, it wasn't scary or fufilling.

I think that this is quite possibly the worst movie that I have ever seen. The 13 year olds screaming in the theater was scarier than the movie itself.The movie does not answer many questions throughout. I love a good scary movie that answers all of the little questions that you ask yourself, but this... When I left the theater (w/2 of my friends) none of us could figure out what we just watched. It was a waste of time to see. It made no sense.The "scary" noise that the ghost or evil thing kept making was the same noise that we all made as a kid. There was no real explanation for how the movie all got started and I'm assuming that "the grudge" just keeps going. Still, there is no explanation of this.

i have to disagree with those of you who did not like this movie i loved it. They just don't make scary movies very well anymore but this had me jumping and screamed twice. I did not find the Ring scary at all but this one made it hard for me to fall asleep after seeing it due to the attic entrance is in my closet. hahaha yes i had a hard time falling asleep from it. Excellent movie. I cant wait for it to come out on DVD so i can buy it and add to my horror movie collection. It was well worth paying to see it in the theater. I would pay again and again to see it. If you have not seen this movie and want a good scare you must go see it. I have not been that scared ina long time watching a movie.

Finally! A horror movie for people with brains!This is one of the best horror movies I have seen. It blends the best of all the recent horror flicks and delivers action, suspense and real terror. It has many twists and will have you thinking about it for days to come.WARNING: If you are the type of person who prefers a movie that is completely cliché, then this is NOT the movie for you!In other words, if you like Tarantino classics, you will appreciate this gem. If, on the other hand, your tastes in horror lean toward the Seed of Chucky, you will probably come out of the movie scratching your head.

Review title: Phew, its only a cat, wait, whats that? Oh no.
Review_body: Reviews of this film which involve some element of comparison with The Ring are inevitable, and this is no different (Comparisons with The Grinch are less usual, and again, this is no different). There are certainly stylistic similarities to The Ring and its Japanese predecessor (The appearance of the films primary béte noire, for one). Whereas that film is concise however, wrapping a simple idea fairly neatly, The Grudge, like any unwelcome guest, leaves a bit of a mess. Criticism of this film may also revolve around its undeniable usage of horror genre clichés (See title). On the other hand, I think the fascinatingly mind-jolting ever-so-slightly-alien style of this movie more than compensates for this. The haunting images, (Don't even pardon that pun, shoot, shoot me now) combined with the plethora of strangely teasing loose ends leave parts of the film replaying through the mind over and over again. And ultimately, it is tense, and it is scary, which is why you're going. If you're after character development, or uniformly high-quality acting, (Back to acting school with you, Ms Gellar) see Finding Neverland, perhaps. If you wish to be heebeed and then roundly jeebeed, I do urge you to have a go at The Grudge, if you think you're hard enough..

I saw "The Grudge" yesterday, and wow... I was really scared, a good thing. I love horror-movies, and I really liked this one. There were so many 'surprise'-scenes (what's the English word?) that made you jump in your seat. Though, too much screaming from the audience made it difficult not to laugh. I think the most scary scene was... on the bus, when the face flashes by on the window, or when Yoko's walking without her chin. The make-up is also VERY good. Sometimes you could really see it was there, but it was still adding a freaky look to the scene. The boy was very good indeed, so cute without make-up and so terribly scary with it on. The next time I hear a cracking noise I will probably feel pretty scared...

Review title: OMG i was so scared i cried!
Review_body: This is definitely the scariest movie i have ever seen in my life!!! I had about 40 minutes left into the movie and was so petrified i had to leave! I watched this film in the last I.T lesson of the year, and spent the majority of the time hiding behind my eyes with the other girls in the class. I would not have even chosen to watch this film if it hadn't been a democratic vote and I hadn't got a load of bloodthirsty people in my class. But i have so I was stuck with it.The film starts alright, from memory a woman wakes up just in time to see her husband to throw himself over the balcony, thats alright I an deal with that, but then the story seems to jump to different places and times constantly, not allowing a plot to develop.As my I.T lessons are only an hour long I didn't see the entire film, but what I saw was enough to put me off, a monotonous plot that seems to only consist of people walking in a house, seeing something and screaming in fear. In some cases the Grudge follows the characters elsewhere e.g. to work.I think the music in the film, is probably the best aspect, it enhances the development of each scene and adds some interest to some of the more boring areas of the film. I could tell this from hiding behind my eyes, being told by the boys when the scary bits were! So in conclusion, only watch this film if you are heartless, fearless and love scary faces! Enjoy!

Review title: One of the best horror films I've seen!
Review_body: Only one word describes this movie: Awesome. This movie draws the viewer in and holds them from the first scene to the last. As some may know, this is a re-make of the Japanese horror film Ju-on. I own this movie and the original is much better than the re-make, but the American version is wonderful. I think that the Grudge is so good partly because the director from Ju-on is used for this movie. They left the story true to the original, unlike The Ring, which wasn't anything like the original, Ringu, other than the main plot line. Anyway, back to The Grudge. The only thing different from Ju-on in this movie was that the main characters were American and they left a few scenes out. I'm glad that at least the setting was left in Japan. Over all, I'm very pleased with this movie. I highly recommend it to anyone.

If you've read about the premise of this movie and it sounds interesting to you, skip it and watch the original (Ju-On). The Grudge is such a carbon copy of Ju-On that I'm starting to suspect that the only reason it was made was so that Sam Raimi could enjoy a Nihon vacation and give his brother Ted a job. Just kidding, Ted Raimi is a fine character actor. Seriously, though, there really was no reason to make this movie except to cash in on the Ringu trend. It reminded me of the Steven Wright joke where he talks about somebody breaking into his house and stealing all his stuff, then replacing it with exact duplicates. Only in this case, the duplicates all happen to be American citizens living in Japan. And what's up with that, anyway? Is the point of view of this movie that if Americans decide to go live in Japan, they will have to contend with vengeful rage-ghosts? Does the tourism council even mention it? And fair warning, don't eat any rich cream soups or drink a large glass of strawberry Nestle's Quik before seeing it, as the slow motion belch sound effect that is so pervasive in the movie (both movies actually) is likely to have an ipecac like effect on you.

Review title: Great example of what horror should be
Review_body: Yes, it's PG-13, and no it's not excessively bloody and gory. This is exactly what a real horror movie should be. Relying on messy gore and violent men with a lot of makeup and a cheesy story is rather weak in my book. This movie is not a slasher, and that's why I liked it. It's a movie that provides atmosphere and story, the two most important aspects of a movie that's meant to invoke the type of reactions one should expect from a horror flick. It doesn't follow the regular rules, so if you're out looking for the next big horror flick, or if it's the blood and violence you go to a movie for, then yes, you should probably look elsewhere. If you enjoy the types of movies that play on your mind and emotions, then I recommend giving The Grudge a look.

Review title: oh my gosh, you'll love this movie
Review_body: oh my gosh. This a terrific movie. i have been watching horror movies all my life and no movie has ever scared me like this. especially if i was alone in the dark. I was so scared to look behind me, when i went to sleep. i would be lying in bed and start to cry. because i thought that the girl was there. i had to cry myself to sleep, that is how terrifying this movie is.this is one edge of your seat, go home crying to your momma kinda movie. it was great. i promise you'll love this movie. but please don't take my opinion or anyone else for that matter. go see it yourself, and you will undoubtedly love it. It is a kind of movie you'll love to own.

Review title: a good scary film for late at night
Review_body: It has been awhile since I have seen a movie that makes you look over your shoulder for about a week straight. A lot of people did not think it was all that, but everybody's different. I did like Ju-on a bit better, but the effects made this movie happen for me. I had to keep the lights on for awhile at night when I was trying to sleep. Simple concept of the film, however, I had a good time. I would like to suggest this film to people that like a quick scare and a good one time viewing. This is not the kind of movie that you would want to add to your collection so just go out and rent it. I don't think you will be disappointed about it.

Review title: This movie didn't get critical justice, but it's great
Review_body: I mean, if you went into the movie theater thinking, "this movie will be terrible, predictably not scary, poorly acted, and ridiculous, you could find plenty of examples. But only because you created a self fulfilling reality in which you were determined to not care about this movie.I don't think The Grudge is spectacularly original. Most movies, especially horror movies, aren't. The test is to find something special and unique within the well-worn genre.The unique thing about The Grudge is that it defies the typical American horror relationship of "if you can understand what is haunting this place, you can beat it", or "you only die if you've sinned". The idea of using the Japanese notion of the curse, basically throws all that nonsense away and decides, hey, if you come near this place you will die. The Place Is Cursed, OK? Thats it. There is no taming it. Too bad for you. This movie has the best jump effects I've ever seen.

dumb dumb dumb dumb dumb dumb dumb. If the creators of The Ring thought they had the worst movie ever made, they're sadly disappointed. This was the stupidest movie I've ever seen. No plot, no explanation for weird, gruesome stuff that happens. Every character is alone for entire scenes. Does no one live in Tokyo??? Naturally, the "alone time" leads to instance after instance of seemingly intelligent people breaking all the Scary Movie rules. E.g., don't work alone, don't enter a room alone, don't follow strange noises. Your BASIC rules of survival as explained brilliantly by Jamie Kennedy. Did Buffy and friends miss those lessons? C'mon! And if you've seen this garbage, my parting thought: bwaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaahhhh

Review title: Worst movie in a long long time
Review_body: This movie isn't worth watching at all. The "scary" parts you can spot from a hundred yards and never surprised me. It's a total "ring" rip off. The plot has it's good parts, but isn't brought well, not to say very very bad. As for the acting, all actors look like they wanted to be somewhere else, which they better did. This is a very good example of marketing, make a good trailer and a cool poster and hope this will attract people to come and watch. Without giving them any entertainment what so ever. The only Scary part of it is That there may be a second movie.Let us all hope this isn't going to happen.

This is another example of a great Japanese horror movie ruined by changing things, its not a bad movie don't get me wrong I enjoyed it but come on was there really any reason to remake a movie that was only a year old and better than it in every way. The original is so much better that if you have seen it don't waste your time or money seeing this one. it changed large parts just so sarah michille geller could get more screen time. The original Ju-on focused on creeping you out as well as scaring you were as this version while still a little creepy cant measure up to the original. It was changed for American viewers by adding cheap scares that last all of about 10 seconds were as the original one is EXTREMELY creepy. And the final most important reason this is not as good they completely ruined the ending because they want to plan for a sequel, it seems like a small difference but the changed ending wrecks the entire movie.

I just watched the movie, i was expecting a typical 'I know what you did last summer' type of cliché, but it was actually quite different. The sets are well thought out, something that seemed most unsettling was the actual Japanese house that it occurred in, the mise en scene was very well planned out, and was indeed a little scary.I liked the little 'glimmers' of face you see throughout the movie, which created a general sense of mystery, which was obviously revealed later on in the film. The only thing that irritated me was near the end when The cursed one approaches the girl after her little observation, she had ample time to escape but no typical horror movie with the desperation, and inability to move oneself or partner, and to end up being caught... Not bad though, 7/10

Review title: What a grotesque excuse for a remake
Review_body: I recently got the movie pass at Blockbuster. Thank God I waited until after then to rent this movie. Otherwise I would have felt that I wasted my money on this terrible movie. The original (Ju-on) had a great concept and was well-done. However, it seems as if the makers of this movie simply took the exact original, copied it, and pasted American actors in as the main characters. They seem completely out of place in their Japanese environment. Most of the complaints I make about remakes generally revolve around the fact that the remakes are nothing at all like the original, however there was no imagination or originality in this movie whatsoever. Beyond this fact, the acting was poor. Sarah Michelle Gellar further proved with this film that she cannot possibly make good choices for starring roles.

It freaked me out, made me jump a couple of times, but it didn't scare me.I'm a big wuss when it comes to horror films, but psychological horror is more convincing than this type of film, where they try to induce fear but really end up invoking a curiosity in my mind.So I ended up being more curious about the happenings than getting scared.Unfortunate.The last scary movie that I watched that gripped me was Texas Chainsaw Massacre.

How do you call a movie with a plot line that is barely tangible, hard to understand, somewhat poor acting, and really intriguing (in a bad sense) sequencing? I think that "the grudge" would be it! I don't want you people to believe that i have a grudge against this movie... However, if you haven't seen it yet, here it goes: it's a story about a house that bares the curse of a slaughtered family, and basically kills ANYONE who enters it... The movie starts with the classic stupid curios girl wandering around in the house hearing funny noises,when she gets grabbed/eaten/whatever by a scary woman-like "thingy". Then Sarah Gellar gets in the center of attention, by witnessing the murder of the old lady, by the matter-less hand of the house spirit. After that, the pieces and sequences run pretty incoherent in a dazzling vicious circle, not letting the viewer the chance to put the pieces together and figure out what is actually happening. As the movie advances, the curse is finally revealed, BUT, there is nothing poor "Buffy" can do to stop her inevitable death that is drawing closer and closer.Conclusion: Plot: a house that kills everybody, there's nothing anybody can do about it! WoW!! FX: so and so, though the purring lady made me laugh quite a few times Sequencing: really bad Suspense: almost none - very predictable horror action Acting: good enough, considering the bad script, and bad camera angles.The reason that i gave a 2 out of 10 for this movie is because i truly enjoyed the sequence with the transparent door elevator going up and the little boy appearing at each and every floor.

Review title: Wow, some people really missed the point of this movie...
Review_body: OK OK OK... I will admit this movie has very little plot. And the plot that there is is pretty weak. And yes, I am sure something was lost in the americanized version. But do you really go to a horror flick to analyze the characters? Come on people! This movie is to scare the living crap out of you. Which it did, quite well. Now, I think the most impressive parts of this movie were the camera angles and the sound effects. It just gives you a shiver down your spine. You knew someone was going to die but it would torture you horribly until they did. Again, I kind of missed the point of Sarah Michelle Gellar (wt hell?) but luckily she isn't in a lot of the movie. Just sit back, watch the movie (SILENTLY PEOPLE, it ticks the rest of the watchers off when you laugh and comment about the freak'n movie when you are watching it!), and enjoy the scare scene after scare scene. I was one of the lucky ones. I saw the movie and there were only four other people in the theater. And we were all scared senseless. (Btw people, when reading these comments, pay attention to the level of writing. Distinguish the A.D.D. teeny boppers with avid movie goers.)

To make a movie with just a Cat-boy doing his Meooooow, and his Gothic looking mother crawling around sounding like she is trying to belch up whatever meal killed her and base that as the "Scary Movie". I happen to be a horror movie addict, so it wasn't an unusual thing for me to call my two friends over to watch stuff with me. This time, we chose the Grudge. Not even halfway through it, we were piled on top of each other like a pile of kittens. Then we walked each other to the bathroom. This movie is tense and creepy, but with a good story too and I do recommend it. It's one of those things that creeps you out just thinking about it, and has decent special effects, which a lot of horror movies lack big time these days.Beware: this film may give you a phobia of hair combs, since that creepy ghost-popping sound is made with a hair comb. I mean it, I could not pick one up.

Review title: About as amusing as being anally probed with an eggbeater
Review_body: The review contains SPOILERS! I saw this movie on a date. The date didn't go very well because I spent most of my time too scared to look at the screen and actually stared at my date's right shoulder for an hour and twenty minutes. However, I went back and saw the film a second time with a group of my friends, determined not to wuss out again. My date's right shoulder was much more entertaining...The movie tries to create an atmosphere of foreboding evil and suspense by having maybe 20 spoken lines in the movie and music only at the most frightening parts. However, the lack of dialog also leaves anyone watching the film utterly confused. Throughout the film, people will randomly die and you have no idea who they are or why they are dying.Example: there is a woman who works in an office building at least 20 miles away from the 'evil house.' The monster from the evil house randomly shows up at her office building (empty, of course) and follows her home. All the while, I'm telling myself 'Well, its creepy, but what am I watching?' The movie does not even build the horror element, more of the something's gonna pop out and make you wet yourself element. Granted, there are parts of the film that will make you wary of being alone for a while, it utterly has the same effect as someone jumping from behind a wall: a second of shock and a few minutes of anger.When I watched the movie in the theater, the viewers were divided: there was the group genuinely frightened, and the group laughing at this pathetic garbage.Overall: the acting is horrid, the setting confuses me, there is no plot, and the music is nonexistent.

Review title: Conjugated plot about a "house" that destroys all those who enter it and the curse that began it.
Review_body: The absolute worst movie of all time. This movie displays the non-existent acting abilities of Sarah Michelle Gellar in the starring role as a "house-keeper" or something or other. The assignment she is given seems harmless until the people living in the house, and those involved with people living in the house, turn up dead. Also, a weird little boy is seen in parts of the house that have been closed off for years. In an attempt to complicate things, the plot also includes the origin of the curse placed on the house. All in all, the plot is only a front to stick as many "don't-go-in-the-closet" scenes as possible in one movie. This would have been fine except for the fact that all the scenes are shown in agonizingly slow and predictable style, with a scream, whoop, holler, or shriek around every corner. When the "shocking conclusion" finally comes around, you're to strung out to care, still trying to recover from the last random blood-curdling scream. Some of my more weak-willed and easily scared friends have called this movie the "scariest movie of all time." To me, this movie is a run-of-the-mill Hollywood product without a mind of its own.It is a sorry attempt to take a movie that was a hit in Japan, throw it through the "Americanizing" machine, and send it to a "theater near you."Bottom of the barrel shriek-fest.

Review title: This is not a yell, clap and scream horror flick. This is about feeling the fear.
Review_body: It's simple. If you want to see pretty people being killed off one by one in new and inventive ways, rent Scream. If you want real suspense, a creepy atmosphere and the feeling of fear in the pit of your stomach, The Grudge is for you.Yanks living in Japan - not quite what the global audience might want to see. And Sarah Michelle Gellar is either wasted or unnecessary in her role, I'm not sure which. Seeing Bill Pullman always makes me wonder if a movie is really going to be any good, but in this case he is perfectly cast and not overused. There's one piece of expendable female eye candy, which American horror films are notorious for (Kadee Strickland), but at least she can act. For me, the various rooms of the house kind of represent the scenes within movie - you're not sure which room is which, and how they fit together , but you are sure the house is one really creepy place. Similarly, the scenes are placed out of sequence and feel disjointed, even blocky, but they all add up to a purpose - to continuously raise the level of fear and uncertainty within the viewer. This is not the kind of movie that tries to be too clever, twisted or trendy. It places fear first. It builds and builds in you, and makes you want to leave your seat, to give yourself a little relief. But if you stick it out, it might just be the horror film you've been waiting for. Well worth watching.

i gave this film 10 out of 10 because it was a horror film, they aim to scare, and this film scared the absolute bejeesus out of me. my god. i don't usually get scared by films but i suppose i'm used to western horror films, not Japanese originated ones, this film was something else! it's so relentless as well, i loved (or hated depending on how you look at it) the way there was no fighting as such, it was just the horror over and over. i am typing this to kill time and keep my mind active because when i let my mind wander it wanders back to those eyes. thank you the grudge, i can now never sleep again. good one. don't watch this film it is too scary.

This movie really had potential. I had two big problems with it. First, it moved just a tad too slow. There is something to be said for not trucking along, but every scene included too much of people moving at snail speed, breathing heavily, waiting for the next scary moment. I did think it was interesting how it did not follow a chronological timeline. The second aspect that I did not like was how everyone kept getting suckered into the same stupid scary movie mistakes. In my opinion a well done scary movie should be one that has people doing realistic things.Spoilers below: 1. In the part where the detective went to burn the house, he should have known better by that point not to investigate any weird noises.2. Susan was stupid to go to her apartment and be alone. She should have gone somewhere where she would not be alone.Anyways, I could list a million of these. I finished that movie completely upset.

Review title: Lack of Adaptation for the Non-Japanese to Grasp the Horror
Review_body: At a measly 92 minutes, the story lacks, and very little gore and quick cuts to cover it up. Unlike some of the other Japanese to American horror films, the movie stays in the Japan, and the reasoning for the curse relies on knowledge of Japanese culture or catching the one line in a small and somber conversation that when someone is killed in a rage, they will become a curse upon the living. In this case the wife killed by her enraged, jealous husband, and her son drowned by the husband in the same fit of rage, become a curse upon the house they lived in for anyone else that enters that house to never escape. The main character enters the house, sees the boy and the woman, and she finds the diary. You could say she investigates, but the investigation is just one web page, and then her having a small conversation with he police officer that says the previously mentioned Japanese belief. The movie needed to be longer. There needed to be more people cycling through the house, the first that just go unexplained and no one cares and slowly escalate to cases that really get the law enforcement to think about it. I realize that the original family that is now the curse upon the house were the same from the Japanese flick and there needed to be more time spent on the woman's affair. There needed to be a depiction of the wrong done to her and her son. So that for a time in the movie the audience would feel compassion for the woman and son and try to prod the main character on to helping the curse move on, to be free from being a curse. Since this is not a romance picture, there would be that turning point where the main character realizes that the curse cannot be lifted, and then the main character comes up attempts to end it. Which the policeman does, when he goes to burn the house down, and then the attempt has flops in it, and eventually you sense resolution, or not. Cut to a scene feeling all is resolved, and then the quick flick of the horror will never be gone. The last bit of the "should've been" was there, but the beginning part of the "should've been" is very lacking in the film. The lack of story leaves those untaught in Japanese culture not as terrified because of different belief systems. In "The Ring" you felt compassion for Samara, and she tries to save Samara, and then realizes, there is no saving Samara, so just save yourself. "The Ring" took the story out of Japan, and changed the content of the tape. "The Grudge" did not have to leave Japan, but it could have made us feel some more compassion for the woman and son. When the main character takes her "boyfriend" to see the Buddhist ritual, I actually thought she would try some Buddhist ritual to save the woman and son from being a curse. Sam Raimi, I enjoyed every other film of your's I have seen, and I hope that when you do "The Grudge 2" you create much more story, stretch it two hours.

Review title: I have some unanswered questions about "The Grudge"
Review_body: If "The Grudge" is suppose to get everyone that enters the house - why didn't it get the assistant to the policeman, the photographers, the finger print people, etc.. Why didn't the movie show the crime scene investigators being killed by "The Grudge". The assistant to the police man that was killed even went upstairs with him to find the phone and he wasn't killed in the movie. Any one besides me noticed these things? I also wondered why the sick mother wasn't killed immediately - it seemed like "The Grudge" allowed her to live and die later on in the movie. I was also confused as to whether or not the boyfriend of Geller in the movie was allowed to live or not? Also does anyone know if the original version is for sell with English sub-titles or voice overs? I thought it was a pretty good movie but it left me wondering about so many things in the movie. Why was "The Grudge" lady in every picture with the professor - Did he know she was in love with him? Why didn't he notice her following him so she could be in the pictures? Would someone please help me understand the movie better.

the grudge is without a doubt, truly terrifying! not only did i lose sleep after seeing the preview on Halloween day, but, it haunted me for days after. the other thing i like, is that it challenges your thinking by giving us a very difficult and complicated plot, but, that doesn't spoil it, it just enhances your thinking. trust me on this film (i'm training to be and expert critic and screenplay writer) it SCARY! with overall good acting and a unique score, it also delivers nearly 2 dozen scares! true masterful film-making. i'd chose this over the ring any day. it's also great to see for the 1st time ever, the director of an original movie come back for a remake, which makes this film even more great. filming in japan seemed to do even better for the grudge because it kind of made you feel awkward, especially watching Karen Davies (gellar) trying to fit in. if it was made entirely in Hollywood, i predict it might've failed, as we probably would've got another modern horror, but, filming away from the usual territory has almost made it look ancient and mythical. the grudge is the stuff of nightmares and nothing will come close to it, except perhaps for the sequel.

Review title: a jewel in the history of scary movies
Review_body: Ever since Carpenter's "Halloween", I was disappointed with so-called Horror Movies: there was a quick trends towards splatter & gore, without any subtleties at all. So that when a friend ask me to go watch "the Grudge" I was rather reserved: I'd seen the Japanese original, as well as "The Ring" both the American and the Japanese version and neither of them had given me the creeps, though the lack of chopped-off hands & feet, or too predictable shock effects were definitely a nice (unpredicted ;) surprise. Don't get me wrong, though, the original "Ju-On" is a brilliant movie in itself, but it is just not scary and "The Ring" is just plain boring.So, as I said I was very reserved and, to be honest, even more so knowing that Sarah Michelle Gellar starred as the main character: I considered her far from being a good actor. In fact, my friend only wanted to see the movie because he's such a fan of Sarah. Well, he got me to watch the movie in the end and, boy, was I in for a surprise: AFTER ALL THE WAIT A REALLY SCARY MOVIE, FINALLYFor all the fans of blood, intestines, torture and whatever: go watch Texas Chainsaw Massacre - this is no movie for you! This is a movie to feed your paranoia, your fear of darkness and of empty houses. It makes you watch the door to your cellar or the attic with goosebumps, lets you hear sounds in the night and makes you feel watched from behind. In short: IT GIVES YOU THE CREEPS.Notably, the movie does not rely only on the subtle effects of old movies to build up tension: not just quick glances of creeping shadows to hint at a monstrosity. You'll get all that, but sooner or later you'll be confronted with "the monster" face-to-face: no highly sophisticated latex Hollywood masks (that are more funny than scary), no rotten flesh and all that stuff, but still VERY SCARY (don't ask me why though).I must admit, though, that some of the surprise effects are very predictable, as many critics have observed before me. And yet, you won't mind them, because as opposed to many of the other movies where there is just the odd dismembered hand floating into screen to give you a quick scare without any real "justification" in the story, these shock effects just belong there: they are not scary because they are "surprising", but because YOU KNOW YOU CAN'T AVOID THEM. And finally, Sarah Michelle Gellar turned out to be a convincing actor after all ;)I bought the DVD the moment it appeared on the market and later also the Director's cut (which is not worth the extra money, unless you haven't seen "Ju-On" or liked it better: it is much closer to the original) and I MUST HAVE WATCHED THE MOVIE 5 TIMES BY NOW AND IT IS STILL CREEPY.If you're looking for subtle scares and, like me, are longing for the "good ole" creeps of early horror movies, this is just the film for you.
